grade_9_10.name: Introduction to Programming & Computational Thinking
grade_9_10.short_description: Foundation of computational thinking, problem decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithm design. Introduction to Python programming language and development environments.

sub_topics.name: Computational Thinking Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Core computational thinking concepts including decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithmic thinking.

sub_topics.name: Problem Decomposition
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking down complex problems into smaller, manageable sub-problems that can be solved independently.
example_tasks: Decompose the problem of planning a school event into smaller tasks such as venue selection, guest list management, and budget tracking
Break down the process of creating a simple calculator into sub-problems: input handling, operation selection, calculation, and output display
Analyze a real-world problem like organizing a digital photo library and identify the sub-tasks needed to categorize, tag, and search photos

sub_topics.name: Pattern Recognition
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying similarities, trends, and patterns in data or problems to develop general solutions.
example_tasks: Identify patterns in a sequence of numbers (2, 4, 6, 8...) and predict the next three numbers in the sequence
Analyze multiple word problems to recognize common patterns in how mathematical problems are structured
Examine different sorting methods (organizing books, files, or contacts) to identify common patterns in organization strategies

sub_topics.name: Abstraction and Generalization
sub_topics.short_description: Filtering out unnecessary details to focus on essential information and creating general solutions applicable to multiple situations.
example_tasks: Create a general template for calculating the area of any rectangle, regardless of specific dimensions
Design an abstract model of a student information system that focuses only on essential attributes like name, ID, and grade level
Develop a generalized approach to solving 'finding the largest number' problems that works for any list size

sub_topics.name: Algorithm Design Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Creating step-by-step instructions to solve problems systematically and efficiently.
example_tasks: Write an algorithm in plain English for making a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, ensuring every step is clear and unambiguous
Design an algorithm to find a specific book in a library using different strategies (systematic search vs. using the catalog system)
Create a flowchart showing the steps to determine if a student passes a course based on multiple grade components

sub_topics.name: Programming Environment Setup
sub_topics.short_description: Installing and configuring Python development environments, understanding IDEs, and basic file management for programming projects.

sub_topics.name: Python Installation and Configuration
sub_topics.short_description: Installing Python interpreter, understanding version differences, and setting up the development environment.
example_tasks: Download and install Python 3.x from python.org and verify the installation by checking the version in the command line
Configure environment variables to run Python from any directory in the command prompt or terminal
Install and set up a code editor like Visual Studio Code or PyCharm with Python extensions

sub_topics.name: Integrated Development Environment Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding IDE features including code editor, syntax highlighting, debugging tools, and output console.
example_tasks: Create a new Python project in an IDE and explore features like file navigation, code completion, and syntax highlighting
Use the interactive Python console (REPL) to execute simple commands and see immediate results
Customize IDE settings such as theme, font size, and auto-save to create a comfortable coding environment

sub_topics.name: Writing Your First Python Program
sub_topics.short_description: Creating, saving, and running simple Python programs using print statements and basic syntax.
example_tasks: Write a 'Hello, World!' program that displays a greeting message when executed
Create a program that prints your name, age, and favorite hobby on separate lines using multiple print statements
Write a program that displays a simple ASCII art picture or pattern using print statements

sub_topics.name: Basic Python Syntax
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Python syntax rules, indentation, comments, and writing clean, readable code following Python conventions.

sub_topics.name: Python Syntax Rules and Conventions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning Python's fundamental syntax including statement structure, indentation requirements, and naming conventions.
example_tasks: Identify and correct syntax errors in a given Python program, such as missing colons or incorrect indentation
Rewrite a poorly formatted Python script using proper indentation and spacing according to PEP 8 style guidelines
Compare Python syntax with natural language to understand how programming languages use structured rules

sub_topics.name: Comments and Code Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Using single-line and multi-line comments to explain code purpose, functionality, and important details.
example_tasks: Add meaningful comments to an existing program explaining what each section does and why
Write a program header comment that includes program name, author, date, and description of functionality
Practice distinguishing between helpful comments that clarify code and unnecessary comments that state the obvious

sub_topics.name: Print Function and Output Formatting
sub_topics.short_description: Using the print function to display information, format output, and understand escape characters.
example_tasks: Create a program that prints a formatted receipt with items aligned in columns using spacing and tabs
Use escape characters like \n (newline) and \t (tab) to format multi-line output in a visually organized way
Write a program that prints a personalized certificate with the user's name centered using string formatting

sub_topics.name: Understanding Error Messages
sub_topics.short_description: Reading and interpreting Python error messages, identifying error types, and using error information for debugging.
example_tasks: Analyze a SyntaxError message to identify the line number and nature of the error in a program
Distinguish between different error types such as SyntaxError, NameError, and TypeError based on error messages
Use error messages to debug a program with multiple intentional errors and fix each one systematically

sub_topics.name: Pseudocode and Flowcharts
sub_topics.short_description: Planning programs using pseudocode and flowcharts before coding, visualizing algorithm logic and program flow.

sub_topics.name: Writing Pseudocode
sub_topics.short_description: Creating clear, structured pseudocode to plan program logic without worrying about syntax details.
example_tasks: Write pseudocode for a program that calculates the average of three test scores
Convert a real-world process (like checking out library books) into structured pseudocode with clear steps
Compare pseudocode for the same problem written in different levels of detail, from high-level to detailed

sub_topics.name: Flowchart Symbols and Conventions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding standard flowchart symbols for processes, decisions, input/output, and flow control.
example_tasks: Identify the purpose of different flowchart symbols: oval (start/end), rectangle (process), diamond (decision), parallelogram (input/output)
Match flowchart symbols to their corresponding programming concepts like assignments, conditions, and loops
Analyze a completed flowchart and explain what each symbol represents in the algorithm

sub_topics.name: Creating Flowcharts
sub_topics.short_description: Designing flowcharts to visualize program logic, decision points, and process flow using proper symbols and connections.
example_tasks: Create a flowchart for a simple calculator that takes two numbers and an operation, then displays the result
Design a flowchart showing the decision process for determining if a student qualifies for honor roll based on GPA
Draw a flowchart representing the logic of a vending machine: selecting item, checking payment, dispensing product or returning change

sub_topics.name: Converting Pseudocode to Python Code
sub_topics.short_description: Translating pseudocode and flowcharts into working Python programs, maintaining logical structure and clarity.
example_tasks: Given pseudocode for calculating sales tax, write the equivalent Python program with proper syntax
Convert a flowchart showing a number guessing game into a functioning Python program
Take detailed pseudocode for a grade calculator and implement it in Python, testing with sample data

grade_9_10.name: Data Types & Control Structures
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding fundamental data types, variables, operators, conditional statements, and loops. Building blocks for creating dynamic programs with decision-making and repetition.

sub_topics.name: Variables and Assignment
sub_topics.short_description: Creating variables, understanding assignment operators, naming conventions, and variable scope basics.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Using Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Declaring variables, assigning values, and understanding Python's dynamic typing system.
example_tasks: Create variables to store a student's name, age, grade level, and GPA, then print them in a formatted sentence
Write a program that stores the price of three items in variables and calculates the total cost
Create variables for length and width of a rectangle, calculate the area and perimeter, and display the results

sub_topics.name: Variable Naming Conventions
sub_topics.short_description: Following Python naming rules and best practices for creating clear, descriptive variable names.
example_tasks: Identify which variable names are valid in Python: student_name, 2ndPlace, my-variable, _private, CLASS
Refactor a program with poorly named variables (like x, y, z) to use descriptive names (like price, quantity, total)
Write a program using proper snake_case naming for variables and explain why good naming improves code readability

sub_topics.name: Multiple Assignment and Swapping
sub_topics.short_description: Assigning multiple variables simultaneously and swapping variable values using Python's tuple unpacking.
example_tasks: Use multiple assignment to initialize three variables in one line: x, y, z = 1, 2, 3
Write a program that swaps the values of two variables without using a temporary variable
Create a program that rotates values among three variables (a becomes b, b becomes c, c becomes a) using multiple assignment

sub_topics.name: Constants and Immutable Values
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the concept of constants and using naming conventions to indicate values that shouldn't change.
example_tasks: Define constants for mathematical values like PI = 3.14159 and use UPPERCASE naming to indicate they shouldn't be changed
Create a program that uses constants for sales tax rate and minimum wage, then performs calculations with these values
Explain the difference between variables and constants through examples like TAX_RATE vs. purchase_amount

sub_topics.name: Primitive Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Working with integers, floats, strings, and booleans, understanding type differences and appropriate usage.

sub_topics.name: Integers and Floating-Point Numbers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding numeric data types, their differences, and when to use each type for calculations.
example_tasks: Create a program that demonstrates integer division (//) versus regular division (/) and explains the difference in outputs
Write a program that calculates the cost per ounce of a product using float division and formats the result to 2 decimal places
Compare the behavior of integer and float arithmetic by calculating 7/2, 7//2, 7.0/2, and 7.0//2

sub_topics.name: String Data Type
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and manipulating text strings, understanding string concatenation, and basic string methods.
example_tasks: Create a program that concatenates first name and last name with a space in between to create a full name
Write a program that takes a sentence and uses string methods to convert it to uppercase, lowercase, and title case
Build a mad libs program that takes user inputs (noun, verb, adjective) and inserts them into a story template

sub_topics.name: Boolean Data Type
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding True and False values, boolean expressions, and how they're used in decision-making.
example_tasks: Create boolean variables to represent conditions like is_raining = True, has_umbrella = False and use them in a print statement
Write expressions that evaluate to True or False such as 5 > 3, 10 == 10, and 'hello' == 'Hello'
Create a program that uses boolean variables to determine if all conditions are met for an event to proceed (e.g., has_ticket and age >= 18)

sub_topics.name: Type Checking and Conversion
sub_topics.short_description: Using type() function to check data types and converting between types using int(), float(), str() functions.
example_tasks: Write a program that uses type() to display the data type of different values: 42, 3.14, 'hello', True
Create a program that converts string input '25' to an integer, performs arithmetic, then converts the result back to string for display
Handle user input by converting string numbers to appropriate types and demonstrate what happens with invalid conversions

sub_topics.name: Operators and Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Using arithmetic, comparison, and logical operators to build expressions and perform calculations and comparisons.

sub_topics.name: Arithmetic Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Using +, -, *, /, //, %, ** operators for mathematical calculations and understanding operator precedence.
example_tasks: Create a program that calculates the total cost including 8% sales tax using multiplication and addition operators
Write a program that uses the modulus operator (%) to determine if a number is even or odd
Build a compound interest calculator using the exponentiation operator (**) to calculate A = P(1 + r)^t

sub_topics.name: Comparison Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Using ==, !=, <, >, <=, >= operators to compare values and create boolean expressions.
example_tasks: Write a program that compares two numbers entered by the user and displays which is larger using comparison operators
Create boolean expressions to check eligibility: age >= 16 for driving, score >= 90 for an A grade
Compare string values to demonstrate how Python compares text alphabetically ('apple' < 'banana')

sub_topics.name: Logical Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Using and, or, not operators to combine boolean expressions and create complex conditions.
example_tasks: Write a program that checks if a student qualifies for honor roll: GPA >= 3.5 and attendance >= 95
Create a condition that checks if it's a weekend (day == 'Saturday' or day == 'Sunday') and it's not raining
Use the not operator to check if a user is NOT an admin or if a value is NOT in a valid range

sub_topics.name: Operator Precedence and Parentheses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the order of operations in expressions and using parentheses to control evaluation order.
example_tasks: Calculate the result of 2 + 3 * 4 and (2 + 3) * 4 to demonstrate how parentheses affect the outcome
Write a program that calculates the average of three numbers ensuring addition happens before division using parentheses
Debug expressions with incorrect operator precedence and fix them by adding appropriate parentheses

sub_topics.name: Input and Output Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Getting user input, formatting output, type conversion, and creating interactive programs that respond to user data.

sub_topics.name: Getting User Input
sub_topics.short_description: Using the input() function to receive data from users and understanding that input returns string values.
example_tasks: Create a program that asks for the user's name and age, then greets them with a personalized message
Write a program that prompts the user for two numbers, converts them from strings to integers, and displays their sum
Build an interactive quiz program that asks questions and stores user answers in variables

sub_topics.name: Formatted Output
sub_topics.short_description: Using f-strings, format() method, and string formatting to create well-structured output displays.
example_tasks: Create a receipt program that uses f-strings to display item names, prices, and total in aligned columns
Write a program that formats decimal numbers to 2 places for currency display using f'{price:.2f}'
Build a grade report that uses string formatting to create a professional-looking table with student information

sub_topics.name: Type Conversion for User Input
sub_topics.short_description: Converting string input to appropriate numeric types and handling input validation basics.
example_tasks: Create a calculator program that converts string inputs to floats before performing arithmetic operations
Write a program that asks for a birth year (string), converts it to integer, and calculates the person's age
Build a tip calculator that converts user input for bill amount and tip percentage into floats for calculation

sub_topics.name: Creating Interactive Programs
sub_topics.short_description: Combining input and output to create engaging programs that interact with users and provide feedback.
example_tasks: Create a personalized story generator that asks for user inputs (names, places, items) and weaves them into a narrative
Write a unit conversion program that asks for a value and converts between feet and meters with formatted output
Build a simple order system that takes item selections and quantities, calculates totals, and displays a summary

sub_topics.name: Conditional Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Making decisions in programs using if, elif, and else statements to execute different code based on conditions.

sub_topics.name: Basic If Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Using if statements to execute code only when a condition is true, understanding indentation and code blocks.
example_tasks: Write a program that checks if a user is old enough to vote (age >= 18) and displays an appropriate message
Create a program that determines if a test score is passing (>= 60) and congratulates the student if they passed
Build a temperature checker that displays a warning message if the temperature exceeds 100 degrees

sub_topics.name: If-Else Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Using else clause to provide alternative code execution when the if condition is false.
example_tasks: Create a program that checks if a number is positive or negative and displays the appropriate classification
Write a coin flip simulator that randomly generates 0 or 1 and displays 'Heads' or 'Tails' accordingly
Build a login validator that checks if a password matches and displays either 'Access Granted' or 'Access Denied'

sub_topics.name: Elif Statements for Multiple Conditions
sub_topics.short_description: Using elif to check multiple conditions sequentially, creating decision chains for complex logic.
example_tasks: Create a grade calculator that assigns letter grades A, B, C, D, F based on numeric score ranges using elif
Write a program that categorizes a person as child, teenager, adult, or senior based on age ranges
Build a shipping cost calculator that charges different rates based on package weight tiers

sub_topics.name: Nested Conditional Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Placing if statements inside other if statements to handle complex, multi-level decision-making.
example_tasks: Create a movie ticket pricing program that considers both age and day of the week for discount calculations
Write a program that checks if a year is a leap year using nested conditions (divisible by 4, except centuries unless divisible by 400)
Build a scholarship eligibility checker that requires GPA >= 3.5 AND (income < 50000 OR first-generation student)

sub_topics.name: Combining Conditions with Logical Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Using and, or, not within conditional statements to create sophisticated compound conditions.
example_tasks: Create a program that checks if a store is open: (day != 'Sunday') and (8 <= hour <= 20)
Write a weather advisory system that alerts if (temperature > 95 or temperature < 20) and conditions == 'extreme'
Build a password validator that checks: length >= 8 and has_number and has_uppercase

sub_topics.name: Loops and Iteration
sub_topics.short_description: Using for and while loops to repeat code execution, process sequences, and create iterative solutions to problems.

sub_topics.name: While Loops
sub_topics.short_description: Using while loops to repeat code as long as a condition remains true, understanding loop control and potential infinite loops.
example_tasks: Create a countdown program that starts at 10 and counts down to 1, displaying each number, then prints 'Blastoff!'
Write a number guessing game where the program repeatedly asks for guesses until the user guesses correctly
Build a password entry system that keeps asking for a password until the correct one is entered (max 3 attempts)

sub_topics.name: For Loops with Range
sub_topics.short_description: Using for loops with range() function to repeat code a specific number of times and generate number sequences.
example_tasks: Write a program that prints the multiplication table for a given number using a for loop with range(1, 11)
Create a program that calculates the sum of all numbers from 1 to 100 using a for loop
Build a pattern printer that displays a triangle of asterisks using nested for loops: *, **, ***, ****

sub_topics.name: Iterating Through Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Using for loops to iterate through strings, lists, and other sequences, accessing each element in turn.
example_tasks: Create a program that iterates through a string and counts how many vowels (a, e, i, o, u) it contains
Write a program that goes through a list of numbers and prints only the even numbers
Build a program that iterates through a list of names and prints each name with a greeting message

sub_topics.name: Loop Control Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Using break to exit loops early and continue to skip to the next iteration, controlling loop flow precisely.
example_tasks: Create a search program that uses break to stop searching once the target item is found in a list
Write a program that uses continue to skip negative numbers when calculating the sum of a number list
Build a menu system that loops until the user enters 'quit', using break to exit the loop

sub_topics.name: Nested Loops
sub_topics.short_description: Placing loops inside other loops to handle multi-dimensional problems and complex patterns.
example_tasks: Create a program that prints a multiplication table from 1 to 10 using nested for loops in a grid format
Write a program that generates all possible two-dice combinations (1,1), (1,2)...(6,6) using nested loops
Build a seating chart generator that uses nested loops to create a grid of seat numbers for rows and columns

sub_topics.name: Common Loop Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing common programming patterns using loops: counting, accumulating, finding max/min, and filtering.
example_tasks: Create a program that counts how many numbers in a list are greater than a threshold value
Write a program that accumulates the total of all prices in a shopping list using a running sum
Build a program that finds and displays the highest test score from a list of student scores using a loop

grade_9_10.name: Functions & Modular Programming
grade_9_10.short_description: Creating reusable code with functions, understanding parameters and return values, variable scope, and organizing programs into modular components.

sub_topics.name: Function Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Defining functions using def keyword, calling functions, and understanding the benefits of code reusability.

sub_topics.name: Defining and Calling Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating function definitions with def keyword and calling functions to execute their code blocks.
example_tasks: Define a function called greet() that prints 'Hello, World!' and call it three times in your program
Create a function named draw_line() that prints a line of 40 dashes, then use it to separate sections of output
Write a function called display_menu() that shows a list of options, and call it at the start of your program

sub_topics.name: Function Naming Conventions
sub_topics.short_description: Following Python naming conventions for functions using lowercase with underscores and descriptive names.
example_tasks: Refactor functions with poor names (func1, doStuff) to use descriptive names (calculate_average, validate_email)
Write three functions with proper naming: calculate_tip(), convert_temperature(), and check_password_strength()
Identify which function names follow Python conventions: PrintMessage, print_message, printMessage, print-message

sub_topics.name: Function Documentation with Docstrings
sub_topics.short_description: Writing docstrings to document function purpose, parameters, and return values using triple quotes.
example_tasks: Add a docstring to a function that explains its purpose: '''Calculates the area of a circle given its radius'''
Write a complete docstring for a grade conversion function that includes description, parameters, and return value information
Create three functions with proper docstrings that another programmer could understand and use without seeing the code

sub_topics.name: Benefits of Using Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how functions improve code organization, reusability, testing, and maintenance.
example_tasks: Refactor a program with repeated code blocks by extracting the repeated logic into a reusable function
Compare two versions of a program: one with repetitive code and one using functions to demonstrate improved readability
Write a program that calls the same function in multiple places, showing how changes to the function affect the entire program

sub_topics.name: Parameters and Arguments
sub_topics.short_description: Passing data to functions using parameters, understanding positional and keyword arguments, and default parameter values.

sub_topics.name: Functions with Single Parameters
sub_topics.short_description: Defining functions that accept one parameter and using that parameter within the function body.
example_tasks: Create a function greet_user(name) that takes a name parameter and prints a personalized greeting
Write a function calculate_square(number) that takes a number and prints its square
Build a function check_passing(score) that takes a test score and prints whether it's passing (>= 60) or failing

sub_topics.name: Functions with Multiple Parameters
sub_topics.short_description: Defining functions with multiple parameters and understanding parameter order and argument passing.
example_tasks: Create a function calculate_rectangle_area(length, width) that calculates and prints the area using both parameters
Write a function create_profile(name, age, city) that displays a formatted user profile with all three pieces of information
Build a function calculate_grade(homework, midterm, final) that weights each score and calculates the final grade

sub_topics.name: Default Parameter Values
sub_topics.short_description: Setting default values for parameters to make them optional when calling functions.
example_tasks: Create a function greet(name, greeting='Hello') where greeting has a default value but can be customized
Write a function calculate_price(base_price, tax_rate=0.08) that uses a default tax rate but allows overriding
Build a function send_notification(message, priority='normal') that has normal priority by default but accepts other levels

sub_topics.name: Keyword Arguments
sub_topics.short_description: Calling functions using keyword arguments to specify parameters by name, improving code clarity and allowing any order.
example_tasks: Call a function create_account(username, email, age) using keyword arguments in different orders
Write a function for formatting text that accepts multiple optional parameters using keyword arguments
Demonstrate the difference between positional and keyword arguments by calling the same function both ways

sub_topics.name: Return Values
sub_topics.short_description: Using return statements to send data back from functions and using returned values in expressions and assignments.

sub_topics.name: Basic Return Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Using return to send single values back from functions and storing returned values in variables.
example_tasks: Create a function calculate_square(n) that returns n squared, and store the result in a variable for later use
Write a function get_absolute_value(number) that returns the absolute value without printing it
Build a function is_even(number) that returns True or False, then use the result in a conditional statement

sub_topics.name: Returning Multiple Values
sub_topics.short_description: Returning multiple values from functions using tuples and unpacking return values into separate variables.
example_tasks: Create a function get_dimensions() that returns both length and width as a tuple: return length, width
Write a function calculate_circle(radius) that returns both area and circumference, unpacking into two variables
Build a function get_min_max(numbers) that returns the minimum and maximum values from a list

sub_topics.name: Return vs. Print
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between returning values and printing, knowing when to use each approach.
example_tasks: Compare two versions of a function: one that prints a result and one that returns it, demonstrating different use cases
Refactor a function that prints its result to instead return the value, showing how it enables further calculations
Write a program that chains function calls by using return values: final_result = function3(function2(function1(x)))

sub_topics.name: Early Return Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Using return to exit functions early based on conditions, implementing guard clauses and validation.
example_tasks: Create a function validate_age(age) that returns an error message immediately if age is negative
Write a function find_item(item_list, target) that returns the index as soon as the item is found
Build a function divide(a, b) that returns early with an error message if b equals zero before attempting division

sub_topics.name: Variable Scope
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding local and global scope, variable lifetime, and how scope affects variable accessibility in functions.

sub_topics.name: Local Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding variables created inside functions that only exist during function execution and within that function.
example_tasks: Create a function that defines a local variable inside it and demonstrate that it can't be accessed outside the function
Write two functions that each have a variable with the same name, showing they don't conflict due to local scope
Build a program that attempts to access a local variable outside its function and explain the resulting NameError

sub_topics.name: Global Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding variables defined outside functions that can be accessed throughout the program.
example_tasks: Create a global constant like PI = 3.14159 and use it in multiple functions to show shared access
Write a program with a global counter variable that tracks how many times functions are called
Demonstrate reading a global variable inside a function versus trying to modify it without the global keyword

sub_topics.name: Using the Global Keyword
sub_topics.short_description: Using the global keyword to modify global variables from within functions, understanding when this is appropriate.
example_tasks: Create a game score tracker that uses global keyword to modify a score variable from within increment_score() function
Write a function that uses global to update a settings variable, then demonstrate the changes persist outside the function
Compare two approaches: passing variables as parameters vs. using global, discussing the pros and cons of each

sub_topics.name: Scope Best Practices
sub_topics.short_description: Learning when to use local vs. global variables, preferring parameters and return values over global state.
example_tasks: Refactor a program that overuses global variables to instead pass data through parameters and return values
Create a function that receives parameters and returns results rather than modifying global variables directly
Write a program following the principle: input through parameters, output through return values, minimal global usage

sub_topics.name: Modular Program Design
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking programs into logical modules using functions, organizing code for maintainability and reusability.

sub_topics.name: Problem Decomposition with Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking complex problems into smaller sub-problems solved by individual functions that work together.
example_tasks: Design a restaurant ordering system with separate functions: display_menu(), take_order(), calculate_total(), print_receipt()
Create a grade management program with functions for: input_grades(), calculate_average(), determine_letter_grade(), display_report()
Build a number guessing game decomposed into: generate_number(), get_guess(), check_guess(), play_game() functions

sub_topics.name: Main Function Pattern
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing programs with a main() function that coordinates other functions, implementing standard program structure.
example_tasks: Refactor an existing program to use a main() function that calls other helper functions in logical order
Write a calculator program with a main() function that displays a menu, gets user choice, and calls appropriate calculation functions
Create a program with main() that orchestrates the flow: initialize(), process(), cleanup() pattern

sub_topics.name: Helper Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating small, focused helper functions that perform specific tasks and support main program logic.
example_tasks: Write helper functions for common validations: is_valid_email(), is_valid_phone(), is_positive_number()
Create utility functions that format output: format_currency(), format_date(), format_percentage()
Build a program with specialized helper functions for data conversion: celsius_to_fahrenheit(), pounds_to_kilograms()

sub_topics.name: Code Organization and Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing functions logically within a file, ordering from high-level to low-level, and grouping related functions.
example_tasks: Organize a messy program by grouping related functions together with comments separating different functional areas
Structure a program with main() at the bottom, high-level functions in the middle, and helper functions at the top
Create a well-organized program file with clear sections: constants, helper functions, main functions, main() call

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Recursion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding functions that call themselves, base cases, recursive cases, and simple recursive problems.

sub_topics.name: Recursion Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how functions can call themselves and how recursion breaks problems into smaller similar problems.
example_tasks: Trace the execution of a simple countdown function that calls itself: countdown(3) → countdown(2) → countdown(1) → stop
Draw a diagram showing how a recursive factorial function breaks down: factorial(5) = 5 * factorial(4) = 5 * 4 * factorial(3)...
Compare iterative and recursive solutions for the same problem to understand how recursion works differently from loops

sub_topics.name: Base Case and Recursive Case
sub_topics.short_description: Defining stopping conditions (base case) and recursive steps that move toward the base case.
example_tasks: Write a recursive countdown function with a base case (n == 0) that stops recursion and recursive case that continues
Create a recursive function to calculate factorial with base case factorial(0) = 1 and recursive case n * factorial(n-1)
Build a recursive sum function that has base case for empty list and recursive case for summing first element plus rest

sub_topics.name: Simple Recursive Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Solving basic problems using recursion including mathematical sequences and simple iterations.
example_tasks: Write a recursive function to calculate powers: power(base, exp) = base * power(base, exp-1) with base case exp == 0
Create a recursive function to sum all numbers from 1 to n: sum_to_n(n) = n + sum_to_n(n-1)
Build a recursive function to print a string in reverse by printing the last character then recursively printing the rest

grade_9_10.name: Data Structures Fundamentals
grade_9_10.short_description: Working with lists, tuples, strings, dictionaries, and sets. Learning to store, organize, access, and manipulate collections of data effectively.

sub_topics.name: Lists Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Creating lists, accessing elements by index, understanding list mutability, and basic list operations.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Accessing Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Initializing lists with values, accessing elements using positive and negative indices, understanding zero-based indexing.
example_tasks: Create a list of five favorite movies and access the first and last items using indices 0 and -1
Build a shopping list with 7 items and access the third item using positive index and the second-to-last using negative index
Create a list of test scores and demonstrate that accessing an out-of-range index causes an IndexError

sub_topics.name: Modifying Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Changing list elements by assignment, understanding that lists are mutable unlike strings or tuples.
example_tasks: Create a list of prices and change the third item to a new value using index assignment
Write a program that updates a to-do list by replacing completed tasks with 'DONE' using index access
Build a grade list and modify specific student scores based on extra credit assignments

sub_topics.name: Basic List Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using append(), insert(), remove(), pop(), and other methods to add and remove list elements.
example_tasks: Create an empty shopping list and use append() to add five items one at a time
Write a program that uses insert() to add an item at a specific position in a playlist
Build a task manager that uses remove() to delete completed tasks and pop() to remove the last item

sub_topics.name: List Operations and Concatenation
sub_topics.short_description: Using + for concatenation, * for repetition, len() for length, and in operator for membership testing.
example_tasks: Combine two lists using the + operator to create a master list of all items from both lists
Create a pattern list by repeating a base list using the * operator: pattern = [1, 2] * 5
Write a program that checks if an item is in a list using the 'in' operator before attempting to remove it

sub_topics.name: List Manipulation Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Slicing lists, sorting, reversing, and advanced techniques for processing and transforming list data.

sub_topics.name: List Slicing
sub_topics.short_description: Extracting sublists using slice notation with start, stop, and step parameters.
example_tasks: Create a list of numbers 1-10 and extract the first three elements using slice [0:3]
Write a program that gets every other element from a list using step parameter: numbers[::2]
Build a function that returns the last three items of any list using negative slicing: my_list[-3:]

sub_topics.name: Sorting and Reversing Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Using sort() method and sorted() function for arranging list elements, understanding reverse parameter.
example_tasks: Create a list of random numbers and sort it in ascending order using sort(), then in descending order with reverse=True
Write a program that sorts a list of names alphabetically using sorted() while keeping the original list unchanged
Build a leaderboard system that maintains scores in descending order using sort with reverse parameter

sub_topics.name: Introduction to List Comprehensions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating new lists using concise comprehension syntax, filtering and transforming data in one line.
example_tasks: Create a list of squares from 1 to 10 using list comprehension: squares = [x**2 for x in range(1, 11)]
Write a comprehension that filters a list to include only even numbers: evens = [n for n in numbers if n % 2 == 0]
Build a list of uppercase names from a list of mixed-case names using comprehension: [name.upper() for name in names]

sub_topics.name: Nested Lists and 2D Arrays
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and accessing multi-dimensional lists, understanding matrix-like structures and row-column access.
example_tasks: Create a 3x3 tic-tac-toe board as a nested list and access individual cells using double indices: board[row][col]
Write a program that stores a gradebook as a nested list with each student as a row containing multiple test scores
Build a simple seating chart using a 2D list and create a function to check if a specific seat is occupied

sub_topics.name: Advanced String Operations
sub_topics.short_description: String methods, formatting, splitting, joining, and text processing techniques for manipulating textual data.

sub_topics.name: String Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using built-in string methods for case conversion, searching, replacing, and validation.
example_tasks: Create a program that uses upper(), lower(), title(), and capitalize() methods to demonstrate different case conversions
Write a function that uses strip(), lstrip(), and rstrip() to remove whitespace from user input
Build a text processor that uses replace() to substitute words and find() to locate specific substrings

sub_topics.name: Splitting and Joining Strings
sub_topics.short_description: Using split() to break strings into lists and join() to combine lists into strings.
example_tasks: Write a program that splits a sentence into words using split() and counts the number of words
Create a function that takes a list of words and joins them with commas using ', '.join(words)
Build a CSV parser that splits comma-separated values and a CSV writer that joins values with commas

sub_topics.name: Advanced String Formatting
sub_topics.short_description: Using f-strings, format() method, and format specifications for precise control over string output.
example_tasks: Create a receipt formatter that uses f-strings with alignment: f'{item:<20} ${price:>8.2f}'
Write a program that formats percentages and currencies using format specifications: f'{value:.2%}' and f'${amount:,.2f}'
Build a table display using string formatting to align columns of numbers and text properly

sub_topics.name: String Validation Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using isdigit(), isalpha(), isalnum(), and other validation methods to check string properties.
example_tasks: Write a username validator that checks if input contains only alphanumeric characters using isalnum()
Create a function that validates if a string is numeric using isdigit() before converting to int
Build a password checker that verifies the presence of digits using any() with isdigit() for each character

sub_topics.name: Tuples
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding immutable sequences, creating tuples, tuple packing and unpacking, and when to use tuples vs. lists.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Using Tuples
sub_topics.short_description: Creating tuples with parentheses, accessing elements, understanding immutability and tuple advantages.
example_tasks: Create a tuple for storing fixed data like coordinates (x, y) or RGB colors (red, green, blue)
Write a program that attempts to modify a tuple element and explain the resulting TypeError
Build a function that returns multiple values as a tuple: return name, age, grade

sub_topics.name: Tuple Packing and Unpacking
sub_topics.short_description: Assigning multiple variables from tuple values in one statement, swapping values efficiently.
example_tasks: Use tuple unpacking to swap two variables without a temporary variable: a, b = b, a
Write a function that returns a tuple and unpack the values: width, height = get_dimensions()
Create a program that unpacks RGB color tuples into separate red, green, and blue variables

sub_topics.name: When to Use Tuples vs. Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the differences between tuples and lists, choosing appropriate data structure for the task.
example_tasks: Compare memory usage and performance between tuples and lists for fixed data that won't change
Create a program with tuples for fixed data (days of week) and lists for dynamic data (daily tasks)
Explain why tuples can be dictionary keys but lists cannot, demonstrating with examples

sub_topics.name: Dictionaries
sub_topics.short_description: Working with key-value pairs, creating dictionaries, accessing and modifying data, iterating through dictionaries.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Accessing Dictionaries
sub_topics.short_description: Creating dictionaries with key-value pairs, accessing values using keys, understanding dictionary syntax.
example_tasks: Create a student dictionary with keys for 'name', 'grade', 'age', 'gpa' and access each value using bracket notation
Build a phone book dictionary that maps names to phone numbers and retrieve numbers by looking up names
Write a program that creates a product catalog with item names as keys and prices as values

sub_topics.name: Modifying Dictionaries
sub_topics.short_description: Adding new key-value pairs, updating existing values, deleting entries using del and pop().
example_tasks: Create an empty dictionary and add new student records one at a time by assigning values to new keys
Write a program that updates inventory quantities in a dictionary as items are sold
Build a contact manager that can add, update, and remove contacts using dictionary operations

sub_topics.name: Dictionary Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using keys(), values(), items(), get(), and other dictionary methods for accessing and manipulating data.
example_tasks: Iterate through a dictionary using items() to access both keys and values: for key, value in dict.items()
Write a program that uses get() method with a default value to safely access dictionary entries
Create a function that uses keys() to get all dictionary keys and values() to get all values as lists

sub_topics.name: Nested Dictionaries
sub_topics.short_description: Creating complex data structures with dictionaries inside dictionaries, accessing nested values.
example_tasks: Create a students database where each student ID maps to a dictionary containing name, grades, and contact info
Write a program that stores a company directory with departments as keys and employee dictionaries as values
Build a game inventory system with nested dictionaries: items contain properties like name, type, value, and attributes

sub_topics.name: Sets
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding unordered collections of unique elements, set operations, and using sets for efficient membership testing.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Using Sets
sub_topics.short_description: Creating sets, understanding uniqueness property, adding and removing elements from sets.
example_tasks: Create a set from a list with duplicate values and observe that duplicates are automatically removed
Write a program that uses a set to track unique visitors to a website by adding user IDs
Build a program that uses add() to add elements and remove() or discard() to delete elements from a set

sub_topics.name: Set Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Using union, intersection, difference, and symmetric difference for mathematical set operations.
example_tasks: Create two sets of students (one from each class) and find students in both classes using intersection()
Write a program that uses union() to combine two groups of items without duplicates
Build a program that finds unique items in one list but not another using difference() operation

sub_topics.name: Set Methods and Use Cases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding when to use sets for removing duplicates, membership testing, and mathematical operations.
example_tasks: Convert a list with duplicates to a set and back to a list to remove all duplicate values efficiently
Write a program that uses sets for fast membership testing: if item in large_set (O(1) operation)
Create a spell checker that uses a set of valid words for quick lookup to identify misspellings

grade_9_10.name: Introduction to Web Development
grade_9_10.short_description: Learning HTML structure, semantic markup, creating web pages, understanding web standards, and building foundational skills for web design.

sub_topics.name: HTML Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding HTML syntax, document structure, tags, elements, and attributes for creating web content.

sub_topics.name: HTML Document Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the basic HTML document template with DOCTYPE, html, head, and body tags.
example_tasks: Create a basic HTML5 document with proper DOCTYPE declaration, head section with title, and body section with content
Build an HTML page structure that includes meta tags for character encoding and viewport settings
Write a complete HTML skeleton and explain the purpose of each major section: DOCTYPE, html, head, title, body

sub_topics.name: Text Formatting and Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Using heading tags, paragraphs, line breaks, and emphasis tags to format and structure text content.
example_tasks: Create a blog post page using h1 for the main title, h2 for section headings, and p tags for paragraph content
Build a recipe page that uses headings for recipe name and sections, paragraphs for instructions, and emphasis tags for important notes
Write an article with proper heading hierarchy (h1-h6) and demonstrate the difference between strong and em tags

sub_topics.name: HTML Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Creating ordered lists, unordered lists, and nested lists for organizing content hierarchically.
example_tasks: Create an unordered list of favorite movies using ul and li tags with proper nesting
Build a numbered step-by-step tutorial using ordered list (ol) tags with clear instructions
Write a navigation menu using nested lists to show main categories and subcategories

sub_topics.name: Links and Anchors
sub_topics.short_description: Creating hyperlinks to external pages, internal page sections, email addresses, and downloadable files.
example_tasks: Create a navigation bar with links to different sections of the same page using anchor tags with href='#section-id'
Build a resources page with external links that open in new tabs using target='_blank' attribute
Write links for email contact (mailto:) and phone numbers (tel:) with proper formatting

sub_topics.name: Images and Media
sub_topics.short_description: Embedding images using img tags, understanding src and alt attributes, managing image paths and accessibility.
example_tasks: Add images to a web page using img tags with proper src paths (relative and absolute) and descriptive alt text for accessibility
Create a photo gallery page with multiple images, captions, and appropriate width/height attributes
Build an image-heavy portfolio page with proper alt text descriptions for each image to support screen readers

sub_topics.name: Semantic HTML
sub_topics.short_description: Using semantic HTML5 elements like header, nav, main, article, section, and footer for meaningful page structure.

sub_topics.name: HTML5 Semantic Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and implementing header, nav, main, article, section, aside, and footer elements for clear document structure.
example_tasks: Create a blog page layout using semantic tags: header for logo/title, nav for menu, main for content, footer for copyright
Build a news website structure with article tags for each news story and section tags for different news categories
Write a portfolio website using aside for sidebar content and main for the primary content area

sub_topics.name: Importance of Semantic HTML
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how semantic HTML improves accessibility, SEO, and code maintainability compared to generic div elements.
example_tasks: Compare two versions of the same page: one using only div elements and one using semantic HTML tags, explaining the benefits
Create an accessible website structure that screen readers can easily navigate using proper semantic elements
Refactor a page built with div tags to use semantic HTML5 elements, improving both code clarity and SEO

sub_topics.name: Creating Document Outline
sub_topics.short_description: Using heading levels and semantic elements to create a logical, hierarchical document outline.
example_tasks: Create a multi-section document with a clear outline using proper heading hierarchy (h1 for page title, h2 for sections, h3 for subsections)
Build a long-form article with logical structure using article, section, and heading tags to create a navigable outline
Design a website where each major section has a clear heading structure that aids both users and search engines

sub_topics.name: HTML Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Creating interactive forms with various input types, labels, validation attributes, and form submission basics.

sub_topics.name: Basic Form Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Creating forms with form tags, understanding action and method attributes, organizing form elements.
example_tasks: Create a simple contact form with form tag, action attribute pointing to a submission handler, and method='post'
Build a search form with a text input field and submit button, understanding the difference between GET and POST methods
Write a newsletter signup form with proper form structure including fieldset and legend for grouping related inputs

sub_topics.name: Input Types and Controls
sub_topics.short_description: Using various input types including text, email, password, number, date, checkbox, radio, and select dropdowns.
example_tasks: Create a registration form using multiple input types: text for name, email for email address, password for password, number for age
Build a survey form with radio buttons for single-choice questions and checkboxes for multiple-choice questions
Write an event registration form with date picker (input type='date'), dropdown menu (select), and textarea for comments

sub_topics.name: Labels and Form Accessibility
sub_topics.short_description: Using label elements properly, associating labels with inputs using for attribute, improving form usability.
example_tasks: Create an accessible form where each input has a properly associated label using the for and id attributes
Build a form that demonstrates the clickable nature of labels - clicking the label focuses the input field
Write a complex form with fieldset and legend tags to group related inputs for better accessibility and organization

sub_topics.name: HTML5 Form Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Using built-in validation attributes like required, pattern, min, max, and understanding browser validation behavior.
example_tasks: Create a form with required attributes on essential fields to prevent submission of incomplete forms
Build a registration form using pattern attribute to validate email format and minlength for password strength
Write a booking form with min and max attributes on date and number inputs to restrict valid ranges

sub_topics.name: HTML Tables
sub_topics.short_description: Creating data tables with proper structure using table, tr, th, td tags, spanning columns and rows, and table accessibility.

sub_topics.name: Basic Table Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Creating tables with table, thead, tbody, tr, th, and td elements for organizing tabular data.
example_tasks: Create a grade table with headers (th) for subjects and columns (td) for different test scores
Build a class schedule table using proper table structure with thead for headers and tbody for class information
Write a comparison table showing features of different products with rows for features and columns for products

sub_topics.name: Column and Row Spanning
sub_topics.short_description: Using colspan and rowspan attributes to merge cells across columns and rows for complex table layouts.
example_tasks: Create a timetable where some cells span multiple columns (like lunch break) using colspan attribute
Build a report table with category headers that span multiple rows using rowspan to group related data
Write a complex data table that uses both colspan and rowspan for headers that apply to multiple cells

sub_topics.name: Table Accessibility and Semantics
sub_topics.short_description: Using caption, scope attribute, and proper header associations to make tables accessible to screen readers.
example_tasks: Add a caption element to a table to provide a title and context for the data presented
Create an accessible data table using scope='col' and scope='row' attributes to help screen readers understand table structure
Build a financial table with proper header associations so assistive technology can announce row and column headers correctly

sub_topics.name: HTML Best Practices
sub_topics.short_description: Writing clean, valid, accessible HTML code following web standards and best practices for maintainability.

sub_topics.name: HTML Code Formatting
sub_topics.short_description: Using proper indentation, spacing, and organization to create readable and maintainable HTML code.
example_tasks: Refactor a poorly formatted HTML document using consistent indentation (2 or 4 spaces) for nested elements
Create a complex page with proper code organization: logical grouping, comments for sections, consistent spacing
Write an HTML document following a style guide with lowercase tag names, quoted attributes, and proper closing tags

sub_topics.name: HTML Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Using W3C validation tools to check HTML code for errors, understanding common validation issues and fixes.
example_tasks: Validate an HTML document using the W3C Markup Validation Service and fix any errors or warnings
Identify and correct common HTML errors: unclosed tags, invalid nesting, missing required attributes
Create a checklist for HTML quality: proper DOCTYPE, valid tags, closed elements, quoted attributes

sub_topics.name: Web Accessibility Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding WCAG principles, using ARIA labels when needed, creating keyboard-navigable interfaces, and alt text for images.
example_tasks: Audit a website for basic accessibility: all images have alt text, forms have labels, headings follow hierarchy
Create an accessible navigation menu that can be used with keyboard alone (Tab and Enter keys)
Build a form with proper ARIA labels for custom controls and ensure all interactive elements are keyboard accessible

grade_9_10.name: JavaScript & Interactive Web Pages
grade_9_10.short_description: Introduction to JavaScript programming, DOM manipulation, event handling, and creating interactive, dynamic web experiences.

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Basics
sub_topics.short_description: JavaScript syntax, variables, data types, operators, and including JavaScript in HTML pages.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding JavaScript's role in web development, writing first JavaScript programs, and using console.log().
example_tasks: Create an HTML page with embedded JavaScript that displays 'Hello, World!' in the browser console using console.log()
Write JavaScript code in an external .js file and link it to an HTML page using the script tag with src attribute
Compare inline JavaScript (in HTML attributes), internal JavaScript (in script tags), and external JavaScript files

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Variables and Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Declaring variables using var, let, and const, understanding JavaScript data types and type coercion.
example_tasks: Create variables using let for values that change and const for constants, demonstrating the difference between them
Write JavaScript code showing different data types: string, number, boolean, undefined, null, and object
Demonstrate type coercion in JavaScript: '5' + 3 (concatenation) vs '5' - 3 (numeric operation)

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Using arithmetic, comparison, logical operators, and understanding operator precedence in JavaScript.
example_tasks: Create a simple calculator using JavaScript operators to perform basic arithmetic (+, -, *, /, %, **)
Write code using comparison operators (===, !==, <, >, <=, >=) and explain strict equality vs loose equality
Build expressions using logical operators (&&, ||, !) to combine multiple conditions for decision making

sub_topics.name: Control Flow in JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Using if/else statements, switch statements, and ternary operators for conditional logic.
example_tasks: Create a grade calculator using if/else if/else statements to assign letter grades based on numeric scores
Write a menu system using switch statement to handle different user choices
Use ternary operator for simple conditions: const message = age >= 18 ? 'Adult' : 'Minor'

sub_topics.name: DOM Manipulation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Document Object Model, selecting elements, modifying content and styles dynamically using JavaScript.

sub_topics.name: Selecting DOM Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Using getElementById, querySelector, querySelectorAll, and other methods to access HTML elements from JavaScript.
example_tasks: Select an element by ID using document.getElementById('my-element') and store it in a variable
Use querySelector to select elements by class, tag, or CSS selector: document.querySelector('.my-class')
Select multiple elements using querySelectorAll and iterate through them with a loop or forEach

sub_topics.name: Modifying Element Content
sub_topics.short_description: Changing text content, HTML content, and attributes of elements using textContent, innerHTML, and setAttribute.
example_tasks: Create a button that changes the text of a paragraph when clicked using element.textContent = 'New text'
Build a dynamic page that updates HTML content using innerHTML to add formatted text or new elements
Write JavaScript to modify image src attribute and alt text based on user interaction

sub_topics.name: Modifying Element Styles
sub_topics.short_description: Changing CSS properties using the style property and toggling classes with classList methods.
example_tasks: Create a theme switcher that changes background color and text color using element.style.backgroundColor
Build a toggle button that adds and removes CSS classes using classList.add(), classList.remove(), and classList.toggle()
Write JavaScript that animates an element by gradually changing its style properties in response to events

sub_topics.name: Creating and Removing Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Dynamically creating new elements with createElement, adding them with appendChild, and removing elements from the DOM.
example_tasks: Create a to-do list where new items are added dynamically using document.createElement('li') and appendChild()
Build a dynamic image gallery that creates new img elements and adds them to a container when loading photos
Write a function that removes elements from the DOM using removeChild() or element.remove() methods

sub_topics.name: Event Handling
sub_topics.short_description: Responding to user interactions through event listeners, understanding event types, and creating interactive web applications.

sub_topics.name: Adding Event Listeners
sub_topics.short_description: Using addEventListener to respond to user actions like clicks, mouse movements, and keyboard input.
example_tasks: Add a click event listener to a button that displays an alert or changes page content when clicked
Create a hover effect using mouseenter and mouseleave events to change element appearance
Build a keyboard-controlled interface using keydown or keypress events to respond to specific keys

sub_topics.name: Event Object and Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the event object, accessing event properties like target, type, and preventing default behavior.
example_tasks: Create a form that uses event.preventDefault() to stop submission and validate data with JavaScript instead
Build a click tracker that uses event.target to identify which specific element was clicked in a container
Write event handlers that use event object properties like event.key for keyboard events or event.clientX for mouse position

sub_topics.name: Form Events and Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Handling form submissions, input changes, and implementing client-side validation with JavaScript.
example_tasks: Create a registration form that validates email format on blur event and displays error messages
Build a real-time character counter for a textarea using input event to update count as user types
Write a form submission handler that validates all fields on submit event before allowing form to be sent

sub_topics.name: Event Delegation
sub_topics.short_description: Using event bubbling to handle events efficiently on parent elements rather than individual child elements.
example_tasks: Create a list where new items can be deleted using event delegation on the parent ul element
Build a dynamic menu where clicking any menu item is handled by a single event listener on the parent container
Write a todo list that uses event delegation to handle multiple buttons (complete, edit, delete) on dynamically added items

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating reusable functions, understanding parameters, return values, arrow functions, and function scope in JavaScript.

sub_topics.name: Function Declaration and Expression
sub_topics.short_description: Defining functions using function declarations and function expressions, understanding hoisting behavior.
example_tasks: Create a function declaration for calculating area of a rectangle: function calculateArea(length, width) { return length * width; }
Write a function expression assigned to a variable: const greet = function(name) { return 'Hello, ' + name; }
Compare function declarations and expressions by demonstrating hoisting - declarations can be called before they're defined

sub_topics.name: Arrow Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Using ES6 arrow function syntax for concise function definitions, understanding implicit returns and this binding.
example_tasks: Convert a traditional function to arrow function syntax: const square = (n) => n * n (implicit return)
Create an array method using arrow function: const doubled = numbers.map(n => n * 2)
Write arrow functions with and without curly braces to understand when return statement is needed

sub_topics.name: Callback Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Passing functions as arguments to other functions, understanding callbacks in array methods and event handlers.
example_tasks: Use forEach with a callback function to process each element in an array: numbers.forEach(num => console.log(num * 2))
Create a custom function that accepts a callback: function processArray(arr, callback) { arr.forEach(callback); }
Build an event handler using a callback function to respond to button clicks or other user interactions

sub_topics.name: Function Scope and Closures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding variable scope in functions, global vs local variables, and basic closure concepts.
example_tasks: Demonstrate function scope by creating variables inside and outside functions and attempting to access them from different scopes
Write a function that creates a closure by returning an inner function that accesses outer function variables
Create a counter using closure that maintains private state: const counter = () => { let count = 0; return () => ++count; }

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Arrays and Array Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Working with arrays in JavaScript, using built-in array methods for manipulation, iteration, and transformation.

sub_topics.name: Basic Array Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using push, pop, shift, unshift, slice, and splice methods to add, remove, and modify array elements.
example_tasks: Create a shopping cart array and use push() to add items and pop() to remove the last item
Build a queue system using shift() to remove from the beginning and push() to add to the end
Use splice() to insert, remove, or replace elements at specific positions in an array

sub_topics.name: Array Iteration Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using forEach, map, filter, find, and reduce methods for processing array data functionally.
example_tasks: Use map() to create a new array by transforming each element: const doubled = numbers.map(n => n * 2)
Filter an array to get only elements meeting a condition: const evens = numbers.filter(n => n % 2 === 0)
Use reduce() to calculate the sum of all numbers in an array: const sum = numbers.reduce((acc, n) => acc + n, 0)

sub_topics.name: Searching and Sorting Arrays
sub_topics.short_description: Using find, findIndex, includes, indexOf, and sort methods to search and organize array data.
example_tasks: Use find() to locate the first element matching a condition: const adult = people.find(p => p.age >= 18)
Check if an array contains a value using includes() method for primitive values
Sort an array of objects by a property: students.sort((a, b) => a.grade - b.grade)

sub_topics.name: Spread and Rest Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Using spread operator (...) to expand arrays and rest operator to collect multiple arguments into an array.
example_tasks: Combine multiple arrays using spread operator: const combined = [...array1, ...array2, ...array3]
Create a copy of an array using spread: const copy = [...original] to avoid mutation
Write a function using rest parameters to accept unlimited arguments: function sum(...numbers) { return numbers.reduce((a, b) => a + b); }

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and manipulating objects, object properties and methods, destructuring, and working with JSON data.

sub_topics.name: Object Literals and Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Creating objects using object literal syntax, accessing and modifying properties using dot and bracket notation.
example_tasks: Create a student object with properties for name, age, grade, and courses using object literal syntax
Access object properties using both dot notation (student.name) and bracket notation (student['name'])
Add new properties to existing objects and delete properties using the delete operator

sub_topics.name: Object Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Adding methods to objects, understanding 'this' keyword, and using Object.keys(), Object.values(), Object.entries().
example_tasks: Create an object with methods that use 'this' to access the object's own properties
Use Object.keys() to get all property names, Object.values() to get all values, and Object.entries() for key-value pairs
Build a calculator object with methods for add, subtract, multiply, and divide operations

sub_topics.name: Object and Array Destructuring
sub_topics.short_description: Using destructuring syntax to extract values from objects and arrays into separate variables efficiently.
example_tasks: Destructure an object to extract specific properties: const { name, age } = person
Use array destructuring to swap values or extract specific array elements: const [first, second] = array
Destructure function parameters to extract object properties directly: function greet({ name, age }) { }

sub_topics.name: Working with JSON
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding JSON format, parsing JSON strings to objects, and converting objects to JSON strings.
example_tasks: Parse a JSON string to a JavaScript object using JSON.parse(): const obj = JSON.parse(jsonString)
Convert a JavaScript object to JSON string using JSON.stringify() for data storage or transmission
Create a simple data storage system that saves and loads data using JSON in localStorage

grade_9_10.name: Computer Systems & Hardware
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding computer architecture, hardware components, operating systems, binary number systems, and how computers process and store information.

sub_topics.name: Computer Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Von Neumann architecture, CPU components, memory hierarchy, and how instructions are processed.

sub_topics.name: CPU Components and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Control Unit, Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU), registers, and the fetch-decode-execute cycle.
example_tasks: Create a diagram showing the major components of a CPU (Control Unit, ALU, registers, cache) and explain each component's role
Trace the fetch-decode-execute cycle for a simple instruction like adding two numbers
Compare CPU specifications (clock speed, cores, cache) from different processors and explain how they affect performance

sub_topics.name: Memory Hierarchy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the hierarchy of memory from registers to cache to RAM to storage, and the speed-capacity tradeoffs.
example_tasks: Create a diagram of the memory hierarchy showing registers, L1/L2/L3 cache, RAM, and storage with approximate speeds and capacities
Explain why a computer needs multiple levels of memory rather than just using fast memory for everything
Calculate the effective access time for a memory system given cache hit rates and access times for different levels

sub_topics.name: Instruction Processing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how machine instructions are stored, fetched, decoded, and executed by the CPU.
example_tasks: Describe the steps of the instruction cycle for a simple operation like loading data from memory into a register
Explain the role of the program counter and instruction register in managing program execution
Compare CISC and RISC architectures and explain why modern processors use features of both approaches

sub_topics.name: Hardware Components
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the function of major hardware components including processors, memory, storage devices, input/output devices, and motherboards.

sub_topics.name: Processors and Specifications
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding CPU specifications including clock speed, cores, threads, cache, and how they affect computer performance.
example_tasks: Compare specifications of three different processors and recommend which would be best for gaming, video editing, and office work
Explain the difference between clock speed (GHz) and number of cores in determining CPU performance
Research current processors from Intel and AMD and create a comparison chart showing key specifications

sub_topics.name: Memory Types and Specifications
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding RAM types (DDR3, DDR4, DDR5), capacity, speed, and the difference between volatile and non-volatile memory.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between RAM and ROM, giving examples of what data is stored in each type
Compare different RAM specifications (8GB DDR4 2400MHz vs 16GB DDR4 3200MHz) and explain which provides better performance
Calculate how much RAM is needed for different use cases: basic computing, gaming, video editing, software development

sub_topics.name: Storage Devices
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding HDDs, SSDs, NVMe drives, optical media, and USB storage, comparing capacity, speed, and durability.
example_tasks: Compare HDDs and SSDs in terms of speed, capacity, price per GB, durability, and power consumption
Explain the advantages of NVMe SSDs over SATA SSDs and when the extra performance is worth the cost
Create a storage recommendation for a computer based on different use cases: budget laptop, gaming PC, workstation

sub_topics.name: Input and Output Devices
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding peripheral devices, interfaces (USB, HDMI, DisplayPort), and how data flows between devices and the computer.
example_tasks: Categorize 10 different devices as input devices, output devices, or both (keyboard, monitor, touchscreen, printer, etc.)
Compare different interface standards (USB 2.0, 3.0, 3.1, USB-C, Thunderbolt) in terms of speed and capabilities
Explain how a device driver enables communication between an operating system and hardware device

sub_topics.name: Motherboard and System Bus
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding motherboard components, expansion slots, chipsets, and how the system bus connects all components.
example_tasks: Identify major components on a motherboard: CPU socket, RAM slots, PCIe slots, SATA connectors, power connectors
Explain the role of the chipset in coordinating communication between the CPU, memory, and peripherals
Research motherboard form factors (ATX, micro-ATX, mini-ITX) and explain how they affect system building

sub_topics.name: Binary and Number Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding binary, hexadecimal, and decimal number systems, converting between bases, and how computers represent data.

sub_topics.name: Binary Number System
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding binary (base-2) representation, place values, and why computers use binary.
example_tasks: Convert decimal numbers to binary: 25, 100, 255, showing the division method or place value method
Convert binary numbers to decimal: 1101, 10110, 11111111, using place value multiplication
Explain why computers use binary (two states: on/off, high/low voltage) rather than decimal

sub_topics.name: Hexadecimal Number System
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding hexadecimal (base-16) representation, converting between binary, decimal, and hex.
example_tasks: Convert hexadecimal to decimal: 1A, FF, 3C, and explain how hex digits 0-9 and A-F represent values 0-15
Convert binary to hexadecimal by grouping bits in sets of 4: 11010110 = D6 in hex
Explain why hexadecimal is commonly used in computing (memory addresses, color codes) as a shorthand for binary

sub_topics.name: Binary Arithmetic
sub_topics.short_description: Performing addition, subtraction, and understanding logical operations (AND, OR, NOT, XOR) in binary.
example_tasks: Perform binary addition: 1011 + 1101, showing carry operations and converting result to decimal to verify
Demonstrate binary subtraction using the borrowing method or two's complement method
