Apply logical operations: 1010 AND 1100, 1010 OR 1100, NOT 1010, 1010 XOR 1100, explaining each result

sub_topics.name: Data Representation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how computers represent different types of data: integers, characters (ASCII, Unicode), colors, and images.
example_tasks: Convert text to ASCII binary representation: Convert 'HI' to binary using ASCII table (H=72=01001000, I=73=01001001)
Explain how RGB color codes work: #FF0000 is red (255 red, 0 green, 0 blue) in hexadecimal
Calculate storage requirements: How many bytes needed to store a 1920x1080 uncompressed RGB image (3 bytes per pixel)?

sub_topics.name: Operating Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding operating system functions, types, user interfaces, file management, and process management basics.

sub_topics.name: Operating System Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the key roles of an OS: resource management, process scheduling, memory management, and providing user interface.
example_tasks: List and explain five main functions of an operating system: process management, memory management, file system, device management, security
Describe how an OS acts as an intermediary between hardware and application software with specific examples
Explain how the OS manages multiple programs running simultaneously through process scheduling and time-sharing

sub_topics.name: Types of Operating Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing different operating systems: Windows, macOS, Linux, mobile OS, and understanding their use cases.
example_tasks: Create a comparison chart of Windows, macOS, and Linux showing pros, cons, typical use cases, and market share
Research mobile operating systems (iOS, Android) and explain how they differ from desktop operating systems
Explain the concept of open-source operating systems using Linux as an example and discuss advantages/disadvantages

sub_topics.name: File Systems and Management
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding file organization, directories, paths, file permissions, and different file system types (NTFS, FAT32, ext4).
example_tasks: Explain the hierarchical file system structure using a tree diagram showing root, folders, and files
Write absolute and relative file paths for various files: C:\Users\Student\Documents\essay.docx or /home/user/documents/essay.txt
Compare file systems (NTFS, FAT32, exFAT, ext4) in terms of compatibility, file size limits, and features

sub_topics.name: User Interfaces
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding GUI vs CLI, navigating operating systems, and basic command line operations.
example_tasks: Compare GUI (Graphical User Interface) and CLI (Command Line Interface), listing advantages and disadvantages of each
Perform basic file operations using command line: navigate directories (cd), list files (ls/dir), create folders (mkdir)
Complete common tasks using both GUI and CLI to understand when each interface type is more efficient

sub_topics.name: Process and Task Management
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding processes, multitasking, using task manager to monitor system resources and manage running applications.
example_tasks: Use Task Manager (Windows) or Activity Monitor (macOS) to identify which processes are using the most CPU and memory
Explain the difference between a program and a process, and how one program can create multiple processes
Describe how the operating system schedules processes and allocates CPU time to create the illusion of simultaneous execution

sub_topics.name: System Software and Utilities
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding system utilities, device drivers, firmware, BIOS/UEFI, and software for system maintenance and optimization.

sub_topics.name: Device Drivers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the role of device drivers in enabling hardware-software communication and keeping drivers updated.
example_tasks: Explain what a device driver is and why it's needed for hardware like printers, graphics cards, and network adapters to work
Research how to check for and update device drivers on Windows or macOS systems
Troubleshoot a hypothetical hardware problem by identifying that an outdated or missing driver could be the cause

sub_topics.name: BIOS and UEFI
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding firmware, the role of BIOS/UEFI in system startup, and accessing and configuring basic BIOS settings.
example_tasks: Explain the boot sequence from power-on to OS loading, including POST (Power-On Self-Test) and bootloader
Describe common BIOS/UEFI settings: boot order, date/time, hardware enable/disable, secure boot
Compare legacy BIOS and UEFI, explaining advantages of UEFI (faster boot, larger disk support, secure boot)

sub_topics.name: System Utilities
sub_topics.short_description: Using disk cleanup, defragmentation, backup tools, antivirus software, and other utilities for system maintenance.
example_tasks: Perform disk cleanup to remove temporary files and free up storage space, explaining which file types are safe to delete
Explain when disk defragmentation is useful for HDDs and why it's not needed for SSDs
Create a backup strategy including what data to back up, how often, and using built-in OS backup tools

grade_9_10.name: Networks & Internet Fundamentals
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding computer networks, internet architecture, protocols, IP addressing, network security basics, and how data travels across networks.

sub_topics.name: Network Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what networks are, types of networks (LAN, WAN, MAN), network topologies, and basic networking concepts.

sub_topics.name: Types of Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding LAN (Local Area Network), WAN (Wide Area Network), MAN (Metropolitan Area Network), and PAN (Personal Area Network).
example_tasks: Compare LAN and WAN networks, providing examples: school network (LAN) vs internet (WAN), explaining scope and ownership differences
Identify which type of network is used in different scenarios: home Wi-Fi (LAN), Bluetooth devices (PAN), citywide network (MAN)
Create a diagram showing a LAN in a school with multiple rooms connected to a central switch, then extending to a WAN via router

sub_topics.name: Network Topologies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding bus, star, ring, mesh, and hybrid topologies, comparing advantages and disadvantages of each.
example_tasks: Draw diagrams of star, bus, and ring topologies and explain how data travels in each configuration
Compare topologies: star is easy to troubleshoot but requires central hub; mesh provides redundancy but is expensive
Identify which topology would be best for different scenarios: small office, data center, home network

sub_topics.name: Network Devices
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding routers, switches, hubs, access points, modems, and their roles in network communication.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between a hub (broadcasts to all devices) and a switch (sends to specific device) with examples
Describe the role of a router in connecting different networks and directing traffic between them
Create a home network diagram showing modem (ISP connection), router (creates LAN), switch (connects wired devices), and access point (Wi-Fi)

sub_topics.name: Bandwidth and Latency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding network speed measurements, factors affecting performance, and the difference between bandwidth and latency.
example_tasks: Explain bandwidth (data transfer rate measured in Mbps or Gbps) vs latency (delay measured in milliseconds)
Calculate download time for a 2GB file with different bandwidth: 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, 1 Gbps connections
Identify factors that affect network performance: number of users, distance, interference, network congestion

sub_topics.name: Internet Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the internet works, client-server model, DNS, and the infrastructure connecting billions of devices globally.

sub_topics.name: Client-Server Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the relationship between clients requesting services and servers providing resources or services.
example_tasks: Explain the client-server model using a web browser (client) requesting a webpage from a web server, tracing the request-response cycle
Identify clients and servers in different scenarios: email, online gaming, streaming video, cloud storage
Compare client-server architecture to peer-to-peer architecture, explaining advantages and use cases for each

sub_topics.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how DNS translates human-readable domain names to IP addresses and the hierarchical DNS structure.
example_tasks: Trace the DNS lookup process: browser cache → OS cache → local DNS server → root servers → TLD servers → authoritative server
Explain why DNS is necessary by comparing typing 'google.com' vs '142.250.185.46' to access a website
Identify parts of a domain name: subdomain, domain, top-level domain in 'www.school.edu' or 'mail.google.com'

sub_topics.name: Internet Infrastructure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ISPs, backbone networks, internet exchange points, and the physical infrastructure of the internet.
example_tasks: Explain the role of Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in connecting users to the internet and providing different service tiers
Describe how data travels from your computer through local ISP, regional networks, backbone networks, to destination server
Research and explain what internet exchange points (IXPs) are and why they're important for efficient data routing

sub_topics.name: Web Browsers and URLs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding web browser functions, URL structure, and how browsers request and render web pages.
example_tasks: Break down a URL into its components: protocol (https://), domain (www.example.com), path (/products), query string (?id=123)
Explain what happens when you type a URL in a browser: DNS lookup, TCP connection, HTTP request, server response, page rendering
Compare different URL protocols: http vs https (security), ftp (file transfer), mailto (email)

sub_topics.name: Network Protocols
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding communication protocols including TCP/IP, HTTP/HTTPS, FTP, and how protocols enable standardized communication.

sub_topics.name: TCP/IP Protocol Suite
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the TCP/IP model layers, how data is packaged and transmitted, and the role of TCP and IP protocols.
example_tasks: Explain the four layers of TCP/IP model: Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access, with examples of protocols in each layer
Describe how TCP ensures reliable data transmission through acknowledgments, retransmission, and error checking
Compare TCP (reliable, connection-oriented) vs UDP (faster, connectionless), giving use cases for each: web browsing vs video streaming

sub_topics.name: HTTP and HTTPS Protocols
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how web communication works, HTTP methods (GET, POST), status codes, and HTTPS encryption.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between HTTP and HTTPS, describing how HTTPS uses SSL/TLS encryption to secure data transmission
Identify HTTP methods and their purposes: GET (retrieve data), POST (submit data), PUT (update), DELETE (remove)
Interpret common HTTP status codes: 200 (OK), 404 (Not Found), 403 (Forbidden), 500 (Server Error), 301 (Redirect)

sub_topics.name: Other Internet Protocols
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding FTP, SMTP, POP3, IMAP, and other protocols used for different internet services.
example_tasks: Explain how email protocols work together: SMTP for sending, POP3 or IMAP for receiving messages
Describe FTP (File Transfer Protocol) and its use for uploading/downloading files to/from servers
Compare POP3 (downloads emails to device) vs IMAP (keeps emails on server), explaining advantages of each approach

sub_topics.name: Why Protocols Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how protocols enable different devices and systems to communicate through standardized rules.
example_tasks: Explain why protocols are necessary using an analogy: like language rules that allow people to communicate
Describe what would happen without standardized protocols: incompatibility between different manufacturers' devices
Give examples of how protocols enable interoperability: Windows PC can communicate with Mac, iPhone with Android via standard protocols

sub_topics.name: IP Addressing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, subnet masks, public vs private IPs, and how devices are identified on networks.

sub_topics.name: IPv4 Addressing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding IPv4 address structure, classes, octets, and the limitations leading to IPv6 development.
example_tasks: Explain IPv4 address format: four octets separated by dots (192.168.1.1), with each octet ranging from 0-255
Identify valid vs invalid IPv4 addresses: 192.168.1.1 (valid), 192.168.1.256 (invalid - octet > 255)
Calculate how many unique IPv4 addresses exist: 2^32 = approximately 4.3 billion addresses, explaining why this is insufficient

sub_topics.name: Public vs Private IP Addresses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between public IPs (internet-routable) and private IPs (local network only), and NAT.
example_tasks: Identify private IP ranges: 192.168.x.x, 10.x.x.x, 172.16.x.x through 172.31.x.x, explaining these aren't routed on the internet
Explain Network Address Translation (NAT): how a router allows multiple private IPs to share one public IP
Use ipconfig (Windows) or ifconfig (Mac/Linux) to find your device's private IP address and default gateway

sub_topics.name: Introduction to IPv6
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why IPv6 was needed, IPv6 address format, and advantages over IPv4.
example_tasks: Compare IPv6 address format (2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334) to IPv4, noting hexadecimal and length differences
Calculate IPv6 address space: 2^128 addresses, explaining this provides enough addresses for every device for the foreseeable future
Explain IPv6 advantages: more addresses, simplified header, better security, no need for NAT

sub_topics.name: Subnetting Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding subnet masks, network and host portions of IP addresses, and basic subnetting concepts.
example_tasks: Explain what a subnet mask is (255.255.255.0) and how it divides an IP address into network and host portions
Identify the network address and host address given an IP (192.168.1.100) and subnet mask (255.255.255.0)
Describe why subnetting is useful: organizing networks, improving security, reducing broadcast traffic

sub_topics.name: Network Security Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding common network security threats, firewalls, encryption, VPNs, and basic security measures to protect networks.

sub_topics.name: Common Network Security Threats
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding malware, phishing, man-in-the-middle attacks, DDoS, and other network security threats.
example_tasks: Identify and explain five common network threats: malware, phishing, DDoS attacks, man-in-the-middle attacks, SQL injection
Describe how a DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attack works: overwhelming a server with traffic from multiple sources
Explain man-in-the-middle attacks where attackers intercept communication between two parties, especially on public Wi-Fi

sub_topics.name: Firewalls
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how firewalls protect networks by filtering incoming and outgoing traffic based on security rules.
example_tasks: Explain what a firewall does: acts as barrier between trusted internal network and untrusted external networks
Describe the difference between hardware firewalls (router-based) and software firewalls (OS-based)
Create a basic firewall rule example: allow HTTP/HTTPS traffic (ports 80/443), block all other incoming traffic

sub_topics.name: Encryption and Secure Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding encryption concepts, symmetric vs asymmetric encryption, and SSL/TLS for secure web browsing.
example_tasks: Explain how encryption protects data by converting plaintext to ciphertext using encryption keys
Compare symmetric encryption (same key for encryption/decryption) vs asymmetric encryption (public/private key pairs)
Describe how HTTPS uses SSL/TLS certificates to encrypt web traffic, explaining why you should look for the padlock icon

sub_topics.name: Virtual Private Networks (VPN)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how VPNs create secure tunnels over public networks and protect privacy by masking IP addresses.
example_tasks: Explain what a VPN does: creates encrypted tunnel between your device and VPN server, hiding your IP and encrypting data
Describe scenarios where VPNs are useful: remote work accessing company network, protecting privacy on public Wi-Fi
Compare using internet with and without VPN: direct connection vs routed through VPN server appearing to be from different location

sub_topics.name: Wi-Fi Security
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding WPA2/WPA3 encryption, securing wireless networks, and risks of open/public Wi-Fi networks.
example_tasks: Compare Wi-Fi security protocols: WEP (outdated, insecure), WPA, WPA2, WPA3 (current standard), explaining evolution of security
List steps to secure a home Wi-Fi network: change default password, use WPA3/WPA2, hide SSID (optional), MAC filtering
Explain risks of using public Wi-Fi: unencrypted connections, potential eavesdropping, man-in-the-middle attacks, and how to stay safe

sub_topics.name: Cloud and Internet Services
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cloud computing basics, cloud storage, web services, and how modern internet applications are delivered.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Cloud Computing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what cloud computing is, service models (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS), and benefits of cloud services.
example_tasks: Explain cloud computing: delivering computing services (servers, storage, software) over the internet rather than local devices
Compare cloud service models: IaaS (infrastructure), PaaS (platform), SaaS (software) with examples: AWS EC2, Google App Engine, Gmail
List advantages of cloud computing: scalability, accessibility from anywhere, reduced IT costs, automatic updates

sub_topics.name: Cloud Storage Services
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cloud storage platforms like Google Drive, Dropbox, OneDrive, and how data synchronization works.
example_tasks: Compare three cloud storage services (Google Drive, Dropbox, OneDrive) in terms of free storage, features, and integration
Explain how file synchronization works: local changes automatically uploaded to cloud and synced across all devices
Describe scenarios where cloud storage is beneficial: accessing files from multiple devices, collaboration, backup/disaster recovery

sub_topics.name: Web Applications and Services
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how modern web apps work, APIs, web services, and the shift from desktop to web-based applications.
example_tasks: Compare desktop applications vs web applications: installation requirements, updates, accessibility, offline capability
Explain what an API (Application Programming Interface) is and how web services use APIs to communicate
Give examples of web applications that replaced desktop software: Google Docs vs Microsoft Word, Figma vs Photoshop

grade_9_10.name: Digital Literacy & Citizenship
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding responsible technology use, digital footprint, online safety, privacy, cybersecurity awareness, media literacy, and ethical considerations in the digital age.

sub_topics.name: Digital Footprint and Online Presence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how online actions create a permanent digital footprint and managing your online reputation responsibly.

sub_topics.name: Active vs Passive Digital Footprint
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between data you intentionally share (active) and data collected about you (passive).
example_tasks: Categorize 10 online actions as active footprint (posting on social media, sending email) or passive (cookies tracking, IP logs)
Audit your own digital footprint by searching your name on Google and reviewing what information is publicly available
Explain how passive data collection occurs: websites tracking behavior, apps collecting location, cookies storing preferences

sub_topics.name: Managing Online Reputation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how digital actions affect future opportunities and strategies for maintaining a positive online presence.
example_tasks: Create a plan for building a positive digital footprint: professional social media presence, portfolio website, positive contributions
Analyze case studies where individuals' old social media posts affected college admissions or job opportunities
Research and explain the 'right to be forgotten' concept and how GDPR gives Europeans some control over their digital footprint

sub_topics.name: Privacy Settings and Controls
sub_topics.short_description: Configuring privacy settings on social media, apps, and devices to control what information is shared and with whom.
example_tasks: Review and adjust privacy settings on one social media platform: who can see posts, tag you, find you via search
Audit smartphone app permissions and disable unnecessary access (camera, microphone, location, contacts) for apps that don't need them
Create a privacy checklist for new social media accounts: set profile to private, review default sharing settings, limit data collection

sub_topics.name: Online Safety and Security
sub_topics.short_description: Protecting yourself from online threats, recognizing scams, creating strong passwords, and practicing safe browsing habits.

sub_topics.name: Password Security
sub_topics.short_description: Creating strong, unique passwords, understanding password managers, and implementing two-factor authentication.
example_tasks: Evaluate password strength: 'password123' (weak) vs 'T7$mK9@pL2&qR5' (strong), explaining what makes passwords secure
Set up two-factor authentication on at least one important account (email, banking) and explain how it provides extra security
Research and explain how password managers work and why using unique passwords for each account is important

sub_topics.name: Recognizing Phishing and Scams
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying phishing emails, fake websites, social engineering tactics, and protecting yourself from online fraud.
example_tasks: Analyze five emails to identify which are phishing attempts: check sender, grammar, urgent requests, suspicious links
List red flags in phishing attempts: spelling errors, generic greetings, threats/urgency, requests for passwords, suspicious URLs
Practice hovering over links to see actual destination before clicking, and explain why this is important for security

sub_topics.name: Safe Browsing Practices
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing secure websites, avoiding malicious downloads, understanding browser security indicators, and safe file sharing.
example_tasks: Identify secure websites: look for HTTPS, padlock icon, verify domain spelling, check for security certificates
Explain risks of downloading from untrusted sources and how to verify software is legitimate before installing
Create a safe browsing checklist: update browser regularly, use ad-blockers, avoid public Wi-Fi for sensitive transactions, clear cookies

sub_topics.name: Social Media Safety
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing risks on social media platforms, protecting personal information, dealing with cyberbullying, and reporting inappropriate content.
example_tasks: Identify information that should NOT be shared publicly on social media: home address, phone number, location in real-time, vacation plans
Create a response plan for dealing with cyberbullying: don't respond, block user, save evidence, report to platform, tell trusted adult
Practice reporting inappropriate content on a social media platform and explain the platform's community guidelines

sub_topics.name: Privacy and Data Protection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding data collection, tracking, user rights, regulations like GDPR, and protecting personal information online.

sub_topics.name: How Data is Collected and Used
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how companies collect user data through websites, apps, and services, and how that data is monetized.
example_tasks: Explain common data collection methods: cookies, account profiles, location tracking, purchase history, search queries
Analyze a website's privacy policy to identify what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with
Describe the business model 'if it's free, you're the product' - explaining how free services monetize user data through advertising

sub_topics.name: Cookies and Online Tracking
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding first-party and third-party cookies, tracking pixels, browser fingerprinting, and how to limit tracking.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between first-party cookies (set by site you visit) and third-party cookies (set by advertisers for tracking)
Configure browser settings to block third-party cookies and clear browsing data regularly
Research and install browser privacy extensions (like Privacy Badger, uBlock Origin) and explain how they protect privacy

sub_topics.name: User Rights and Data Protection Laws
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding GDPR, COPPA, CCPA, and user rights to access, delete, and control personal data.
example_tasks: Explain key rights under GDPR: right to access your data, right to be forgotten, right to data portability, right to opt out
Compare data protection laws: GDPR (EU), CCPA (California), COPPA (protecting children under 13)
Practice exercising data rights: request a copy of your data from a company, request deletion of your account

sub_topics.name: Protecting Personal Identifiable Information
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what PII is, why it's valuable, and strategies for minimizing sharing of sensitive personal information.
example_tasks: Identify examples of PII: Social Security number, full name with birthdate, credit card numbers, medical records
Evaluate forms and websites for necessity of PII requests: does this site really need my phone number or birthdate?
Create guidelines for protecting PII: use minimal information, verify legitimacy before sharing, monitor for identity theft

sub_topics.name: Media Literacy and Information Evaluation
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluating online information credibility, recognizing misinformation and bias, fact-checking, and understanding how algorithms shape what we see.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Source Credibility
sub_topics.short_description: Using the CRAAP test (Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, Purpose) to evaluate information quality.
example_tasks: Apply the CRAAP test to three websites on the same topic, determining which source is most credible and why
Identify red flags in sources: lack of author information, no date, extreme bias, poor writing quality, ads disguised as content
Compare information from a peer-reviewed source, news outlet, blog, and social media post on the same topic

sub_topics.name: Recognizing Misinformation and Disinformation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between misinformation (false info shared unknowingly) and disinformation (false info spread intentionally).
example_tasks: Analyze examples of misinformation: outdated info, misinterpreted data, satire taken seriously, manipulated images
Identify characteristics of disinformation: sensational headlines, emotional manipulation, lack of credible sources, political motivation
Explain how misinformation spreads: social media sharing, confirmation bias, echo chambers, algorithmic amplification

sub_topics.name: Fact-Checking Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Using fact-checking websites, reverse image search, and lateral reading to verify information before sharing.
example_tasks: Fact-check a viral social media claim using sites like Snopes, FactCheck.org, or PolitiFact
Use reverse image search (Google Images, TinEye) to trace the origin of a photo and verify if it's been manipulated or misrepresented
Practice lateral reading: open new tabs to research the source's credibility rather than just reading the article itself

sub_topics.name: Filter Bubbles and Echo Chambers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how algorithms personalize content, creating filter bubbles that reinforce existing beliefs and limit exposure to diverse viewpoints.
example_tasks: Explain how social media algorithms create filter bubbles by showing content similar to what you've engaged with before
Compare news feeds or search results on different accounts to see personalization in action
Develop strategies to escape filter bubbles: follow diverse sources, search incognito, actively seek opposing viewpoints

sub_topics.name: Digital Ethics and Responsibility
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ethical technology use, copyright, plagiarism, fair use, intellectual property, and respectful online communication.

sub_topics.name: Copyright and Fair Use
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding copyright laws, Creative Commons licenses, fair use doctrine, and properly attributing sources.
example_tasks: Explain copyright basics: automatic protection for original works, rights of creators, duration of copyright protection
Identify which uses qualify as fair use: education, criticism, news reporting, transformative works vs commercial copying
Compare Creative Commons licenses: CC0 (public domain), CC BY (attribution required), CC BY-NC (non-commercial), CC BY-SA (share-alike)

sub_topics.name: Plagiarism and Proper Citation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what constitutes plagiarism, paraphrasing properly, and citing sources correctly in different formats.
example_tasks: Identify examples of plagiarism: copying without quotes, improper paraphrasing, missing citations, self-plagiarism
Practice paraphrasing: rewrite information in your own words while maintaining the original meaning and citing the source
Create proper citations for different sources: websites, books, articles using MLA or APA format

sub_topics.name: Netiquette and Online Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Practicing respectful online communication, understanding tone in text, dealing with disagreements constructively.
example_tasks: List 10 rules of netiquette: respect others' time, use proper grammar, avoid all caps (shouting), stay on topic, be forgiving of mistakes
Rewrite rude or inappropriate messages using respectful language and constructive tone
Practice disagreeing respectfully online: focus on ideas not personal attacks, acknowledge valid points, provide evidence

sub_topics.name: Digital Divide and Access Equity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding disparities in technology access based on socioeconomic status, geography, and how this affects opportunity and education.
example_tasks: Research statistics on internet access by income level, rural vs urban areas, and different countries
Explain how lack of technology access creates educational and economic disadvantages in the digital age
Identify solutions to bridge the digital divide: public Wi-Fi, library access, affordable internet programs, device lending

sub_topics.name: Cybersecurity Awareness
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding common cyber threats, malware types, social engineering, and protective measures for personal cybersecurity.

sub_topics.name: Types of Malware
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware, spyware, adware, and how each type threatens computer security.
example_tasks: Define and compare malware types: virus (attaches to files), worm (self-replicating), trojan (disguised), ransomware (encrypts files)
Explain how ransomware attacks work: encrypts user files, demands payment for decryption key, threatens deletion
Identify signs of malware infection: slow performance, unexpected pop-ups, programs starting automatically, strange network activity

sub_topics.name: Social Engineering Attacks
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing manipulation tactics used to trick people into revealing information or taking harmful actions.
example_tasks: Explain common social engineering techniques: phishing (fake emails), pretexting (fabricated scenarios), baiting (malicious downloads)
Analyze social engineering scenarios and identify the manipulation tactics being used
Create awareness posters warning about social engineering with specific examples and how to resist these attacks

sub_topics.name: Antivirus and Protection Software
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how antivirus software works, importance of updates, and layered security approach.
example_tasks: Explain how antivirus software detects threats: signature-based detection, heuristic analysis, behavior monitoring
Research and compare three antivirus solutions: features, effectiveness, cost, system impact
Create a security checklist: antivirus installed, automatic updates enabled, regular scans scheduled, firewall active

sub_topics.name: Software Updates and Patch Management
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why software updates are critical for security and how to keep systems and apps updated.
example_tasks: Explain why software updates are important for security: patching vulnerabilities, fixing bugs, adding security features
Enable automatic updates on operating system and applications, checking update status regularly
Research a major security breach caused by unpatched vulnerabilities (e.g., WannaCry ransomware exploiting unpatched Windows)

grade_9_10.name: Introduction to Databases
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding database concepts, relational database structure, creating simple databases, basic SQL queries, and organizing data effectively.

sub_topics.name: Database Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what databases are, why they're used, comparing databases to spreadsheets, and database terminology.

sub_topics.name: What Are Databases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding databases as organized collections of data, different types of databases, and real-world database applications.
example_tasks: Explain what a database is and why it's better than storing data in text files for large amounts of related information
Identify database use cases in daily life: online shopping (product catalog), social media (user profiles), banking (transactions)
Compare flat-file databases (one table) vs relational databases (multiple related tables) with examples

sub_topics.name: Database Terminology
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding key terms: database, table, record, field, primary key, foreign key, and relationships.
example_tasks: Define database terms using a school database example: table (Students), record (one student), field (Name, Grade), primary key (StudentID)
Create a simple database diagram showing tables, fields, and relationships in a library system: Books, Authors, Borrowers
Identify primary keys in different tables and explain why each record needs a unique identifier

sub_topics.name: Databases vs Spreadsheets
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding when to use databases vs spreadsheets, advantages of databases for complex data and multiple users.
example_tasks: Compare storing student information in Excel vs a database: data redundancy, query capabilities, multi-user access
List scenarios where spreadsheets are sufficient vs when databases are needed based on data volume and complexity
Explain database advantages: reduced redundancy, data integrity, complex queries, concurrent access, security controls

sub_topics.name: Relational Database Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tables, rows, columns, data types, primary keys, foreign keys, and relationships between tables.

sub_topics.name: Tables, Rows, and Columns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how data is organized in tables with rows representing records and columns representing fields.
example_tasks: Design a Students table with appropriate columns: StudentID, FirstName, LastName, GradeLevel, Email, EnrollmentDate
Create sample data for 5 records in a Products table with columns: ProductID, Name, Category, Price, StockQuantity
Explain the relationship between rows (horizontal records) and columns (vertical attributes) using a library books example

sub_topics.name: Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different data types: INTEGER, VARCHAR, DATE, BOOLEAN, DECIMAL, and choosing appropriate types for fields.
example_tasks: Assign appropriate data types for student table fields: StudentID (INTEGER), Name (VARCHAR), Birthdate (DATE), GPA (DECIMAL)
Explain why choosing correct data types matters: storage efficiency, data validation, enabling appropriate operations
Compare numeric types (INTEGER for whole numbers vs DECIMAL for money) and text types (CHAR vs VARCHAR)

sub_topics.name: Primary Keys
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding primary keys as unique identifiers for records, characteristics of good primary keys, and auto-increment fields.
example_tasks: Identify which fields make good primary keys: StudentID (good) vs Name (bad - not unique) vs Email (okay but can change)
Create tables with appropriate primary keys: OrderID for Orders table, ISBN for Books table, EmployeeID for Employees
Explain why primary keys must be unique and not null, using examples of database errors when these rules are violated

sub_topics.name: Table Relationships and Foreign Keys
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding one-to-many relationships, foreign keys that link tables, and maintaining referential integrity.
example_tasks: Design a relationship between Students and Enrollments tables using StudentID as foreign key in Enrollments
Create an entity relationship diagram for a school database: Students, Courses, Enrollments (junction table)
Explain one-to-many relationships: one customer can have many orders, but each order belongs to one customer

sub_topics.name: Basic SQL Queries
sub_topics.short_description: Writing SELECT statements, filtering with WHERE, sorting with ORDER BY, and retrieving specific data from databases.

sub_topics.name: SELECT Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Using SELECT to retrieve data, selecting specific columns, using * for all columns, and basic query syntax.
example_tasks: Write a query to select all columns from Students table: SELECT * FROM Students;
Write a query to select only Name and Grade columns: SELECT Name, Grade FROM Students;
Create queries selecting different column combinations from a Products table to answer specific questions

sub_topics.name: Filtering with WHERE Clause
sub_topics.short_description: Using WHERE to filter records based on conditions, comparison operators, and logical operators (AND, OR).
example_tasks: Write a query to find students with GPA above 3.5: SELECT * FROM Students WHERE GPA > 3.5;
Create a query using multiple conditions: SELECT * FROM Products WHERE Price < 50 AND Category = 'Electronics';
Write queries using different comparison operators: =, !=, <, >, <=, >=, BETWEEN, IN, LIKE

sub_topics.name: Sorting with ORDER BY
sub_topics.short_description: Using ORDER BY to sort results in ascending or descending order, sorting by multiple columns.
example_tasks: Write a query to list students alphabetically by last name: SELECT * FROM Students ORDER BY LastName ASC;
Sort products by price descending: SELECT Name, Price FROM Products ORDER BY Price DESC;
Create a query sorting by multiple columns: ORDER BY Department ASC, Salary DESC to group by department then salary

sub_topics.name: Limiting Results
sub_topics.short_description: Using LIMIT to retrieve a specific number of results, useful for top N queries and pagination.
example_tasks: Write a query to find the top 5 highest-priced products: SELECT * FROM Products ORDER BY Price DESC LIMIT 5;
Create a query to show the 10 most recent orders: SELECT * FROM Orders ORDER BY OrderDate DESC LIMIT 10;
Explain how LIMIT is useful for pagination: displaying results 10 at a time on multiple pages

sub_topics.name: Data Manipulation
sub_topics.short_description: Using INSERT to add records, UPDATE to modify existing data, DELETE to remove records, and understanding data integrity.

sub_topics.name: Inserting Data
sub_topics.short_description: Using INSERT INTO to add new records to tables, specifying columns and values.
example_tasks: Write an INSERT statement to add a new student: INSERT INTO Students (StudentID, Name, Grade, Email) VALUES (101, 'John Doe', 11, 'john@school.edu');
Insert multiple records at once using multiple VALUES sets or multiple INSERT statements
Explain what happens when you try to insert data that violates constraints: duplicate primary key, missing required field

sub_topics.name: Updating Data
sub_topics.short_description: Using UPDATE to modify existing records, using WHERE to specify which records to update.
example_tasks: Write an UPDATE statement to change a student's grade: UPDATE Students SET Grade = 12 WHERE StudentID = 101;
Update multiple fields at once: UPDATE Products SET Price = 29.99, StockQuantity = 100 WHERE ProductID = 5;
Explain the danger of UPDATE without WHERE clause: all records would be updated to the same values

sub_topics.name: Deleting Data
sub_topics.short_description: Using DELETE to remove records from tables, understanding the permanent nature of deletions.
example_tasks: Write a DELETE statement to remove a specific student: DELETE FROM Students WHERE StudentID = 101;
Delete records based on conditions: DELETE FROM Orders WHERE OrderDate < '2023-01-01';
Explain why DELETE without WHERE is dangerous: it removes ALL records from the table permanently

sub_topics.name: Data Integrity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding constraints (NOT NULL, UNIQUE, CHECK) that maintain data quality and consistency.
example_tasks: Explain NOT NULL constraint: ensures field must have a value, preventing incomplete records
Describe UNIQUE constraint: ensures no duplicate values in a column, like Email in Users table
Create a table with CHECK constraint: CHECK (Age >= 0 AND Age <= 120) to ensure valid age values

sub_topics.name: Basic Database Design
sub_topics.short_description: Planning database structure, identifying entities and attributes, avoiding data redundancy, and basic normalization concepts.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Entities and Attributes
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing requirements to identify what tables (entities) are needed and what fields (attributes) each table should have.
example_tasks: For a library system, identify entities: Books, Authors, Borrowers, Loans and list attributes for each
Design a simple e-commerce database: identify Customer, Product, Order, OrderItem entities and their attributes
Create an entity-relationship diagram showing entities, attributes, and relationships for a school system

sub_topics.name: Avoiding Data Redundancy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding problems caused by storing the same data in multiple places and how normalization reduces redundancy.
example_tasks: Identify redundancy problems in a poorly designed table where customer info is repeated for every order
Redesign a redundant table by splitting it into multiple related tables: Customers and Orders tables linked by CustomerID
Explain anomalies caused by redundancy: update anomalies, deletion anomalies, insertion anomalies with examples

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Normalization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding basic normalization concepts: organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity.
example_tasks: Explain First Normal Form (1NF): each field contains atomic values (no lists), each record is unique
Convert unnormalized data (one table with repeating groups) into 1NF by creating separate records
Describe benefits of normalization: reduced redundancy, easier updates, improved data integrity

grade_9_10.name: Software Development Practices
grade_9_10.short_description: Learning debugging techniques, testing strategies, code documentation, version control basics with Git, and collaborative development workflows.

sub_topics.name: Debugging Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Systematic approaches to finding and fixing bugs, using print statements, debuggers, and logical problem-solving.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Error Messages
sub_topics.short_description: Reading error messages carefully, identifying error types (syntax, runtime, logical), and using stack traces.
example_tasks: Analyze different Python error messages: SyntaxError, NameError, TypeError, IndexError, and identify what each indicates
Use a stack trace to locate where an error occurred, reading from bottom to top to trace execution flow
Practice fixing common errors based on error messages: undefined variable, index out of range, type mismatch

sub_topics.name: Debugging Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Using systematic approaches: divide and conquer, rubber duck debugging, and simplifying code to isolate problems.
example_tasks: Practice rubber duck debugging: explain code line-by-line to find logical errors through careful explanation
Use divide and conquer by commenting out code sections to isolate where a bug occurs
Create a debugging checklist: read error carefully, reproduce bug, isolate problem area, form hypothesis, test fix

sub_topics.name: Using Print Statements for Debugging
sub_topics.short_description: Strategically placing print statements to track variable values, execution flow, and identify where code behaves unexpectedly.
example_tasks: Add print statements to trace variable values through a function to see where calculations go wrong
Use print statements to verify which branches of conditionals are being executed
Debug a loop by printing iteration counter and values being processed at each step

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Debugger Tools
sub_topics.short_description: Using IDE debuggers to set breakpoints, step through code, inspect variables, and watch expressions.
example_tasks: Set breakpoints in code and run the debugger to pause execution and examine variable states
Use step over, step into, and step out controls to navigate through code execution line by line
Watch specific variables during debugging to see how their values change as the program runs

sub_topics.name: Testing Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the importance of testing, writing test cases, manual testing, and introduction to automated testing concepts.

sub_topics.name: Why Testing Matters
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how testing prevents bugs, ensures requirements are met, and builds confidence in code quality.
example_tasks: Explain why testing is important: catches bugs early, verifies functionality, prevents regressions, documents expected behavior
Describe the cost of bugs found at different stages: development (cheap) vs production (expensive)
Give examples of real-world software failures caused by inadequate testing: calculation errors, data loss, security breaches

sub_topics.name: Writing Test Cases
sub_topics.short_description: Creating test cases with inputs and expected outputs, covering normal cases, edge cases, and error cases.
example_tasks: Write test cases for a function that calculates letter grades from numeric scores, including boundary values (59, 60, 89, 90)
Create test cases for input validation: valid input, empty input, invalid data type, negative numbers, extremely large values
Design a test case table with columns: test ID, input, expected output, actual output, pass/fail

sub_topics.name: Manual Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Systematically testing code by hand, documenting results, and creating bug reports.
example_tasks: Manually test a calculator program with a variety of inputs, documenting which tests pass and fail
Create a testing checklist for a form: required fields, valid/invalid email, password strength, submission behavior
Write a bug report including: description, steps to reproduce, expected vs actual behavior, severity, screenshots

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Automated Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the concept of automated tests that run code and verify results programmatically.
example_tasks: Write a simple assert statement to check if a function returns expected value: assert add(2, 3) == 5
Create multiple assertions to test different cases of the same function automatically
Explain benefits of automated tests: run quickly, repeatable, catch regressions, document expected behavior

sub_topics.name: Code Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Writing clear comments, docstrings, README files, and creating documentation that helps others understand code.

sub_topics.name: Writing Effective Comments
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding when to comment, writing clear explanations of why code does something rather than what it does.
example_tasks: Refactor code with too many obvious comments ('increment i') to use comments only where code intent isn't clear
Write comments explaining complex algorithms or business logic that isn't immediately obvious from the code
Compare bad comments (what code does) vs good comments (why code is needed, edge cases, assumptions)

sub_topics.name: Docstrings and Function Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Writing comprehensive docstrings that document function purpose, parameters, return values, and usage examples.
example_tasks: Write a docstring for a function including description, Args section, Returns section, and example usage
Document edge cases and error conditions in docstrings: what happens with invalid input, when function returns None
Generate documentation from docstrings using tools like pydoc or built-in help() function

sub_topics.name: README Files
sub_topics.short_description: Creating README files that explain what a project does, how to install it, how to use it, and how to contribute.
example_tasks: Write a README for a program including: project description, installation instructions, usage examples, requirements
Create a README template with sections: Title, Description, Features, Installation, Usage, Contributing, License
Explain why good README files are important: help users get started quickly, reduce support questions, attract contributors

sub_topics.name: Code Organization and Readability
sub_topics.short_description: Using meaningful names, consistent formatting, logical structure to make code self-documenting.
example_tasks: Refactor code with cryptic variable names (x, y, temp) to use descriptive names (studentName, totalScore, maxAttempts)
Organize code logically: constants at top, imports grouped, related functions together, main execution at bottom
Apply consistent formatting: indentation, spacing, line length to improve readability

sub_topics.name: Version Control with Git
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding version control concepts, basic Git commands, repositories, commits, and tracking changes over time.

sub_topics.name: Version Control Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why version control is needed, tracking changes, reverting to previous versions, collaboration benefits.
example_tasks: Explain problems version control solves: tracking changes over time, recovering old versions, collaborating without conflicts
Compare manual version control (saving files as v1, v2, v3) vs automated version control systems
Describe how version control enables collaboration: multiple developers work simultaneously without overwriting changes

sub_topics.name: Git Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Git repository, working directory, staging area, and commits as snapshots of project state.
example_tasks: Initialize a Git repository using 'git init' and explain what .git folder contains
Explain Git workflow: modify files in working directory → add to staging area → commit to repository
Describe what a commit is: a snapshot of project at specific time with message explaining changes

sub_topics.name: Basic Git Commands
sub_topics.short_description: Using git init, git add, git commit, git status, git log to manage version control locally.
example_tasks: Create a repository, make changes to files, add them to staging (git add), and commit with message (git commit -m 'message')
Use git status to see which files are modified, staged, or untracked
View commit history with git log to see timeline of changes with authors, dates, and messages

sub_topics.name: GitHub and Remote Repositories
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding remote repositories, pushing code to GitHub, cloning repositories, and basic collaboration.
example_tasks: Create a GitHub account, create a new repository, and push local code to GitHub using git remote and git push
Clone an existing repository from GitHub using git clone to get a local copy
Explain difference between local repository (on your computer) and remote repository (on GitHub server)

sub_topics.name: Collaborative Development
sub_topics.short_description: Working on projects in teams, code review basics, using issues and project boards, pair programming concepts.

sub_topics.name: Code Review Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the purpose of code review, giving and receiving constructive feedback, improving code quality.
example_tasks: Review a classmate's code looking for: correctness, readability, efficiency, edge cases, and provide constructive feedback
Practice receiving code review feedback graciously and making improvements based on suggestions
Create a code review checklist: does it work, is it readable, are there tests, is it documented, any security issues

sub_topics.name: Pair Programming
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding driver-navigator model, benefits of pair programming, effective communication while coding together.
example_tasks: Practice pair programming: one person types (driver), other reviews and guides (navigator), switching roles regularly
Explain benefits of pair programming: catches mistakes immediately, shares knowledge, produces better code
Develop communication skills for pair programming: articulating thoughts, asking questions, explaining approach

sub_topics.name: Project Planning and Task Management
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking projects into tasks, using issue trackers, estimating time, and managing deadlines.
example_tasks: Break a project into smaller tasks and organize them on a project board: To Do, In Progress, Done columns
Create GitHub issues for features and bugs, assigning them to team members and setting priorities
Estimate time for tasks and create a project timeline, learning to account for unexpected challenges

grade_9_10.name: Object-Oriented Programming Basics
grade_9_10.short_description: Introduction to object-oriented programming concepts including classes, objects, methods, attributes, and understanding encapsulation and basic OOP design.

sub_topics.name: Classes and Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between classes (blueprints) and objects (instances), creating classes and instantiating objects.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Classes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding classes as templates for creating objects, defining class structure with attributes and methods.
example_tasks: Create a simple Student class with attributes for name, grade, and GPA, understanding class as a blueprint
Define a Car class with attributes like make, model, year, and color to represent real-world objects
Explain the concept of a class using analogies: cookie cutter (class) creates cookies (objects), blueprint (class) creates houses (objects)

sub_topics.name: Creating and Using Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Instantiating objects from classes, accessing object attributes, and understanding that each object has its own data.
example_tasks: Create multiple Student objects from the Student class, each with different names and grades: student1 = Student('Alice', 10, 3.8)
Instantiate several Car objects with different attributes and access their properties using dot notation
Demonstrate that objects are independent: changing one object's attributes doesn't affect other objects of the same class

sub_topics.name: Constructor Method (__init__)
sub_topics.short_description: Using the __init__ method to initialize object attributes when objects are created, understanding self parameter.
example_tasks: Write a __init__ method for a Book class that accepts title, author, and pages parameters and assigns them to attributes
Explain the self parameter: refers to the specific instance being created, allowing access to instance attributes
Create a BankAccount class with __init__ that initializes account_number, owner_name, and balance attributes

sub_topics.name: Instance Attributes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding instance variables that belong to specific objects, accessing and modifying attributes.
example_tasks: Create a Person class with instance attributes for name, age, and email, accessing them using object.attribute syntax
Modify object attributes after creation: person1.age = 31, demonstrating objects are mutable
Compare multiple objects showing each has its own copy of attributes with different values

sub_topics.name: Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Defining and calling methods that operate on object data, understanding instance methods and the self parameter.

sub_topics.name: Instance Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Creating methods that operate on object data, using self to access instance attributes within methods.
example_tasks: Add a display_info() method to Student class that prints the student's name, grade, and GPA using self.attribute
Create a Rectangle class with methods calculate_area() and calculate_perimeter() that use self.length and self.width
Write a BankAccount class with deposit() and withdraw() methods that modify self.balance

sub_topics.name: Methods with Parameters
sub_topics.short_description: Writing methods that accept additional parameters beyond self, combining object data with method arguments.
example_tasks: Create an update_grade(new_grade) method in Student class that changes the student's grade attribute
Write a drive(distance) method in Car class that updates the odometer reading by adding the distance parameter
Build a transfer(amount, recipient) method in BankAccount that moves money from one account to another

sub_topics.name: Methods that Return Values
sub_topics.short_description: Writing methods that perform calculations and return results rather than just modifying attributes or printing.
example_tasks: Create a get_full_name() method in Person class that returns first_name + last_name as a single string
Write an is_honor_roll() method in Student class that returns True if GPA >= 3.5, False otherwise
Build a calculate_monthly_payment() method in Loan class that returns the computed payment amount

sub_topics.name: String Representation (__str__)
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing __str__ method to control how objects are displayed when printed, providing user-friendly output.
example_tasks: Add __str__ method to Student class that returns formatted string: 'Student: Alice, Grade: 10, GPA: 3.8'
Implement __str__ in Book class to display: 'Title by Author (Year)' when book object is printed
Create __str__ method for Product class showing name, price, and stock in a readable format

sub_topics.name: Encapsulation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding data hiding, private attributes, getter and setter methods, and protecting object data.

sub_topics.name: Public vs Private Attributes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding naming conventions: public attributes (no underscore) vs private attributes (single or double underscore prefix).
example_tasks: Create a BankAccount class with public attribute account_number and private attribute __balance (double underscore)
Demonstrate that private attributes with double underscore can't be easily accessed from outside the class
Explain Python's name mangling for private attributes: __balance becomes _ClassName__balance

sub_topics.name: Getter Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Creating getter methods to provide controlled access to private attributes without direct access.
example_tasks: Write a get_balance() method in BankAccount that returns the private __balance attribute
Create getter methods for a Person class with private attributes: get_age(), get_email(), get_ssn()
Explain why getters are useful: can add validation, logging, or computed values when accessing data

sub_topics.name: Setter Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Creating setter methods to provide controlled modification of private attributes with validation.
example_tasks: Write a set_age(new_age) method that validates age is positive before updating private __age attribute
Create a set_balance(amount) method in BankAccount that ensures balance can't be set to negative value
Implement a set_email(email) method that validates email format before updating private __email attribute

sub_topics.name: Benefits of Encapsulation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how encapsulation protects data integrity, allows validation, and controls how data is accessed and modified.
example_tasks: Compare two versions of BankAccount: one with public balance (can be set to negative) vs private with setter validation
Demonstrate how encapsulation prevents invalid states: age can't be negative, email must be valid format
Explain real-world benefits: changing internal implementation doesn't break external code using the class

sub_topics.name: Class Design
sub_topics.short_description: Designing classes to model real-world entities, identifying appropriate attributes and methods, and creating well-structured classes.

sub_topics.name: Modeling Real-World Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing real-world objects to identify what attributes and behaviors should be included in a class.
example_tasks: Design a Library class by identifying attributes (name, location, books) and methods (add_book, remove_book, search)
Create a Recipe class modeling real recipes with ingredients, steps, prep_time, cook_time attributes and appropriate methods
Build a VideoGame class with attributes like title, genre, rating, price and methods like play(), get_description()

sub_topics.name: Relationships Between Classes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how classes can contain instances of other classes, creating has-a relationships.
example_tasks: Create a Library class that contains a list of Book objects, demonstrating Library has-a Book relationship
Design a School class with a list of Student objects and a list of Teacher objects
Build a ShoppingCart class that contains Product objects and calculates total from all products

sub_topics.name: Single Responsibility Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that classes should have one clear purpose, avoiding classes that try to do too many things.
example_tasks: Evaluate a bloated class that handles database, email, and calculations, then split it into focused classes
Create separate classes for Student, Grade, and Transcript rather than putting all functionality in one class
Explain why single responsibility makes code easier to maintain, test, and reuse

sub_topics.name: Documenting Classes
sub_topics.short_description: Writing clear class docstrings that explain class purpose, attributes, and methods.
example_tasks: Write comprehensive docstring for a class including: purpose, attributes, example usage
Document each method within a class: what it does, parameters, return value, side effects
Create a complete documented class that another programmer could use without seeing the implementation

sub_topics.name: Working with Collections of Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Managing lists of objects, iterating through object collections, and performing operations on multiple objects.

sub_topics.name: Lists of Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and managing lists containing object instances, accessing objects in lists.
example_tasks: Create a list of Student objects and iterate through it to display each student's information
Build a list of Product objects and calculate total inventory value by summing price * quantity for each
Manage a roster of Player objects, adding new players, removing players, and displaying the team

sub_topics.name: Searching and Filtering Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Finding specific objects in lists based on attribute values, filtering objects that meet criteria.
example_tasks: Search a list of students to find all students with GPA above 3.5 using a loop or list comprehension
Filter a product list to show only items in a specific category or price range
Find the student with highest GPA from a list of Student objects by comparing gpa attributes

sub_topics.name: Sorting Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Sorting lists of objects by attribute values, using key parameter in sort methods.
example_tasks: Sort a list of Student objects alphabetically by name using: students.sort(key=lambda s: s.name)
Sort products by price descending: products.sort(key=lambda p: p.price, reverse=True)
Create custom sort orders: sort students by grade level, then by GPA within each grade

sub_topics.name: Aggregate Operations on Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Performing calculations across multiple objects: counting, summing, averaging attributes.
example_tasks: Calculate average GPA across all students: sum(s.gpa for s in students) / len(students)
Count how many products are out of stock by checking stock_quantity attribute for each product
Find total sales by summing the price of all items in a list of Purchase objects

grade_9_10.name: Problem Solving with Algorithms
grade_9_10.short_description: Learning fundamental algorithms for searching and sorting, analyzing algorithm efficiency, and developing problem-solving strategies through algorithmic thinking.

sub_topics.name: Searching Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing and comparing linear search and binary search algorithms, understanding when each is appropriate.

sub_topics.name: Linear Search
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing linear search that checks each element sequentially until target is found or list ends.
example_tasks: Write a linear search function that searches through a list and returns the index of target value, or -1 if not found
Implement linear search to find a student by ID in an unsorted list of students
Count how many comparisons linear search makes when searching for an element at the beginning, middle, and end of list

sub_topics.name: Binary Search
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing binary search on sorted lists, understanding divide-and-conquer approach and efficiency advantages.
example_tasks: Write a binary search function that repeatedly divides a sorted list in half to find a target value
Trace binary search execution finding value 67 in sorted list [12, 25, 34, 45, 67, 78, 89, 92], showing which elements are checked
Compare number of comparisons needed for linear search vs binary search on a list of 1000 sorted items

sub_topics.name: Comparing Search Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tradeoffs between linear and binary search: speed vs requirement for sorted data.
example_tasks: Create a table comparing linear and binary search: time complexity, sorted requirement, ease of implementation
Explain when to use each algorithm: binary search for large sorted datasets, linear search for small or unsorted data
Implement both searches and measure execution time on lists of different sizes: 100, 1000, 10000 elements

sub_topics.name: Sorting Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and implementing basic sorting algorithms including bubble sort, selection sort, and insertion sort.

sub_topics.name: Bubble Sort
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing bubble sort that repeatedly steps through list, comparing adjacent elements and swapping if needed.
example_tasks: Write a bubble sort function that sorts a list by repeatedly comparing and swapping adjacent elements
Trace bubble sort execution on [64, 34, 25, 12, 22, 11, 90], showing array state after each pass
Count the number of comparisons and swaps bubble sort makes on different sized lists

sub_topics.name: Selection Sort
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing selection sort that repeatedly finds the minimum element and places it at the beginning.
example_tasks: Write a selection sort function that finds the smallest element in unsorted portion and swaps it to the front
Visualize selection sort on [29, 10, 14, 37, 13], highlighting which elements are compared and swapped each iteration
Compare selection sort to bubble sort in terms of number of swaps needed

sub_topics.name: Insertion Sort
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing insertion sort that builds sorted array one element at a time by inserting elements in correct position.
example_tasks: Write an insertion sort function that takes each element and inserts it into its correct position in the sorted portion
Trace insertion sort on [12, 11, 13, 5, 6], showing how sorted portion grows one element at a time
Explain why insertion sort is efficient for nearly-sorted data compared to other simple sorting algorithms

sub_topics.name: Comparing Sorting Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tradeoffs between different sorting algorithms in terms of efficiency, complexity, and use cases.
example_tasks: Create a comparison chart for bubble, selection, and insertion sort showing average comparisons, swaps, and best use cases
Test all three sorting algorithms on the same data and compare execution times
Explain scenarios where each algorithm might be preferred: insertion sort for nearly-sorted, selection for minimal swaps

sub_topics.name: Algorithm Efficiency
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to analyzing algorithm efficiency, understanding Big O notation basics, and comparing algorithm performance.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Time Complexity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how to measure algorithm efficiency by counting operations relative to input size.
example_tasks: Compare two algorithms that solve the same problem: one with fixed number of operations vs one that loops through all data
Count operations in simple algorithms and express as function of input size n: print all elements is n operations
Explain why algorithm efficiency matters more as data size increases: 1ms vs 10ms difference on 10 items becomes 1s vs 10s on 10000 items

sub_topics.name: Big O Notation Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding common Big O complexities: O(1), O(n), O(n²), and what they mean for algorithm performance.
example_tasks: Identify the Big O complexity of simple algorithms: accessing array element (O(1)), linear search (O(n)), nested loops (O(n²))
Compare algorithms graphically: show how O(1), O(n), and O(n²) grow as n increases from 10 to 1000
Classify algorithms by complexity: constant time (checking if list is empty), linear time (finding max), quadratic time (bubble sort)

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Algorithm Efficiency
sub_topics.short_description: Determining time complexity by analyzing loops, nested loops, and recursive calls in algorithms.
example_tasks: Analyze a function with a single loop and determine it's O(n) - operations proportional to list length
Identify O(n²) complexity in nested loops that compare each element to every other element
Compare binary search O(log n) to linear search O(n) by calculating operations for list of 1000 elements

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Space Complexity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding memory usage of algorithms, in-place vs additional space, and tradeoffs between time and space.
example_tasks: Compare in-place sorting (modifies original list) vs creating new sorted list (uses extra memory)
Identify algorithms that use O(1) space (only a few variables) vs O(n) space (creates copy of data)
Explain tradeoff scenarios: sometimes using more memory can make algorithm faster, sometimes we must minimize memory usage

sub_topics.name: Problem-Solving Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Developing systematic approaches to solving programming problems using pseudocode, breaking problems down, and testing solutions.

sub_topics.name: Understanding the Problem
sub_topics.short_description: Reading problem statements carefully, identifying inputs and outputs, understanding constraints and requirements.
example_tasks: Read a problem statement and identify: what are the inputs, what should the output be, what are the constraints
Restate the problem in your own words to ensure understanding before starting to code
Create example test cases with input and expected output to clarify requirements

sub_topics.name: Breaking Down Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Decomposing complex problems into smaller sub-problems that are easier to solve individually.
example_tasks: Break down 'create a grade calculator' into sub-problems: input grades, validate input, calculate average, determine letter grade, display result
Use top-down design to decompose a game into major components: setup, game loop, player turn, check win, display result
Practice identifying which sub-problems can be solved independently and which depend on others

sub_topics.name: Planning Solution with Pseudocode
sub_topics.short_description: Writing pseudocode to plan algorithm logic before coding, thinking through edge cases and flow.
example_tasks: Write detailed pseudocode for a solution before writing actual code, including variable names and logic flow
Create flowchart showing decision points and loops in an algorithm to visualize logic
Review pseudocode to identify potential issues before implementing: missing edge cases, infinite loops, logic errors

sub_topics.name: Iterative Refinement
sub_topics.short_description: Starting with simple solution, testing it, then adding features and optimizations incrementally.
example_tasks: Implement a basic version of a solution that handles simple cases, test it, then add handling for edge cases
Create working prototype with minimal features, then incrementally add additional functionality
Refactor working code to improve efficiency or readability: start with simple nested loops, optimize to single loop

sub_topics.name: Testing and Validating Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating comprehensive test cases, testing edge cases, and verifying solutions work correctly for all scenarios.
example_tasks: Create test cases covering: normal cases, edge cases (empty input, maximum values), error cases (invalid input)
Test solution with different input sizes to ensure it works for small and large datasets
Validate solution against original problem requirements: does it produce correct output for all specified inputs?

sub_topics.name: Common Algorithm Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Learning frequently-used algorithm patterns: finding max/min, counting, accumulating, filtering, and two-pointer techniques.

sub_topics.name: Finding Maximum and Minimum
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing algorithms to find largest or smallest element in a collection.
example_tasks: Write an algorithm to find the maximum value in a list by iterating once and tracking the largest seen so far
Find both minimum and maximum in a single pass through the data to avoid iterating twice
Extend to find the index of maximum/minimum element, not just the value itself

sub_topics.name: Counting and Accumulating
sub_topics.short_description: Patterns for counting occurrences or accumulating values while iterating through data.
example_tasks: Count how many elements in a list meet a specific condition: count_even = sum(1 for n in numbers if n % 2 == 0)
Accumulate running total while iterating: calculate cumulative sum, running average, or product
Use dictionary to count frequency of items: count each word's occurrences in text

sub_topics.name: Filtering and Mapping
sub_topics.short_description: Creating new collections by filtering elements that meet criteria or transforming each element.
example_tasks: Filter a list to include only elements meeting criteria: evens = [n for n in numbers if n % 2 == 0]
Map/transform each element: squares = [n**2 for n in numbers], converting list of numbers to list of squares
Combine filtering and mapping: get squares of even numbers only

sub_topics.name: Two-Pointer Technique
sub_topics.short_description: Using two pointers moving through data to solve problems efficiently, often in sorted arrays.
example_tasks: Find pair of numbers in sorted array that sum to target using two pointers from start and end
Reverse a string in-place using two pointers: one at start, one at end, swap and move toward center
Check if a string is a palindrome using two pointers comparing characters from both ends

grade_9_10.name: Creative Computing Projects
grade_9_10.short_description: Applying learned skills to create meaningful projects combining programming, web development, and problem-solving. Building a portfolio of work demonstrating competency.

sub_topics.name: Project Planning and Design
sub_topics.short_description: Planning projects from idea to implementation, creating specifications, designing user interfaces, and breaking work into phases.

sub_topics.name: Defining Project Requirements
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying what a project should do, listing features, defining success criteria and constraints.
example_tasks: Create a requirements document for a project: purpose, target users, features list, technical requirements, timeline
Prioritize features as must-have, should-have, and nice-to-have to manage scope and focus on essential functionality
Define acceptance criteria: specific, measurable conditions that determine when project is complete

sub_topics.name: User Interface Design
sub_topics.short_description: Sketching interfaces, creating wireframes, planning user flow through an application.
example_tasks: Sketch wireframes for a web application showing layout of pages and navigation between them
Design user flow diagram showing how users move through the application to complete key tasks
Create mockups or prototypes of main screens before beginning implementation

sub_topics.name: Breaking Projects into Phases
sub_topics.short_description: Dividing large projects into manageable milestones, creating realistic timelines.
example_tasks: Break a semester project into phases: planning (week 1), core features (weeks 2-4), testing (week 5), refinement (week 6)
Create a task list with dependencies: must complete user authentication before building user profile features
Develop minimum viable product (MVP) first: basic working version, then add enhancements incrementally

sub_topics.name: Web Development Projects
