sub_topics.short_description: Building complete websites combining HTML, CSS, and JavaScript to create interactive, functional web applications.

sub_topics.name: Personal Portfolio Website
sub_topics.short_description: Creating a multi-page portfolio showcasing projects, skills, and contact information with responsive design.
example_tasks: Build a portfolio with pages: Home (about), Projects (showcase work), Skills (technical abilities), Contact (form or links)
Implement responsive navigation menu that works on desktop and mobile devices
Create project cards with images, descriptions, and links to live demos or GitHub repositories

sub_topics.name: Interactive Web Tools
sub_topics.short_description: Building useful web tools and calculators that solve real problems using JavaScript.
example_tasks: Create a grade calculator that accepts assignment scores and weights, calculating final grade with letter grade display
Build a to-do list application with add, complete, and delete functionality using local storage for persistence
Develop a unit converter tool (temperature, distance, weight) with live conversion as user types

sub_topics.name: Content-Focused Websites
sub_topics.short_description: Creating informational websites on topics of interest with well-organized content and engaging design.
example_tasks: Build an educational website about a topic you're passionate about: history, science, hobby, with multiple pages of content
Create a recipe website with searchable/filterable recipes, ingredient lists, instructions, and photos
Develop a fan site for a book, movie, or game series with character bios, timelines, and interactive elements

sub_topics.name: Python Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Creating standalone Python programs that solve problems or provide entertainment using programming concepts learned.

sub_topics.name: Text-Based Games
sub_topics.short_description: Building interactive games using Python with game loops, player choices, and score tracking.
example_tasks: Create an adventure game where player navigates rooms, collects items, and solves puzzles using dictionaries and functions
Build a quiz game that asks questions, tracks score, provides feedback, and displays final results
Develop a number guessing game with difficulty levels, hints, and limited attempts

sub_topics.name: Data Analysis Tools
sub_topics.short_description: Creating programs that read, process, and analyze data from files or user input.
example_tasks: Build a grade analyzer that reads student data from CSV file, calculates statistics, and generates reports
Create a text analyzer that reads a file and reports: word count, most common words, average word length, reading level
Develop a survey analyzer that processes responses and displays results with percentages and visualizations

sub_topics.name: Utility Programs
sub_topics.short_description: Creating useful tools that automate tasks or solve practical problems.
example_tasks: Build a password generator that creates random secure passwords based on user specifications (length, character types)
Create a file organizer that sorts files into folders based on file type or other criteria
Develop a budget tracker that records expenses, categorizes them, and shows spending summaries

sub_topics.name: Database Projects
sub_topics.short_description: Creating applications that use databases to store and manage data persistently.

sub_topics.name: Contact Management System
sub_topics.short_description: Building a system to store, search, and manage contact information using a database.
example_tasks: Create a contact database with name, phone, email, address fields and operations to add, search, update, delete contacts
Implement search functionality: find contacts by name, filter by category or tag
Add features: export contacts to CSV, import from file, birthday reminders

sub_topics.name: Inventory Management System
sub_topics.short_description: Building a system to track products, quantities, prices using relational database design.
example_tasks: Design and implement database for products: ProductID, Name, Category, Price, Quantity, Supplier
Create operations: add product, update quantity, search inventory, generate low-stock alerts
Build reports: inventory value, products by category, sales tracking

sub_topics.name: Student Records System
sub_topics.short_description: Creating a system to manage student information, courses, and grades.
example_tasks: Design database with Students, Courses, and Enrollments tables with proper relationships
Implement functionality: register students for courses, record grades, calculate GPAs
Generate reports: student transcripts, class rosters, honor roll lists

sub_topics.name: Portfolio Development
sub_topics.short_description: Curating and presenting work professionally, documenting projects, and reflecting on learning.

sub_topics.name: Documenting Projects
sub_topics.short_description: Writing clear documentation for each project including purpose, features, technologies used, and challenges overcome.
example_tasks: Create README files for each project with: description, screenshots, features list, installation instructions, usage guide
Write reflections on projects: what you learned, challenges faced, how you solved problems, what you'd do differently
Document code with clear comments and docstrings so others can understand and use your work

sub_topics.name: GitHub Portfolio
sub_topics.short_description: Using GitHub to showcase projects, organizing repositories, writing professional profiles.
example_tasks: Organize GitHub profile with: pinned repositories showcasing best work, complete README with skills and interests
Ensure each repository has: descriptive name, detailed README, appropriate license, organized code structure
Include live demo links or screenshots/GIFs showing projects in action

sub_topics.name: Presenting Work
sub_topics.short_description: Creating presentations or demonstrations of projects, explaining technical decisions and learning outcomes.
example_tasks: Prepare project presentation: problem solved, approach taken, demonstration of features, lessons learned
Create video walkthrough or live demonstration of project showing key functionality
Practice explaining technical concepts to different audiences: technical peers vs non-technical users

sub_topics.name: Continuous Learning and Improvement
sub_topics.short_description: Reflecting on progress, setting learning goals, and planning future projects to develop new skills.
example_tasks: Review portfolio quarterly: identify gaps in skills, plan projects to address weak areas
Set SMART goals for next project: specific technical skill to learn, measurable outcome, realistic timeline
Seek feedback on projects from peers, teachers, or online communities and use it to improve

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Python Programming
grade_11_12.short_description: Mastering advanced Python concepts including complex data structures, file I/O, exception handling, modules and packages, and working with external libraries.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Data Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Working with advanced collections including stacks, queues, deques, defaultdict, Counter, and understanding when to use each structure.

sub_topics.name: Stacks and Queues
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing and using stack (LIFO) and queue (FIFO) data structures for appropriate problem-solving scenarios.
example_tasks: Implement a stack using Python list with push, pop, peek, and is_empty operations, then use it to check balanced parentheses in expressions
Create a queue using collections.deque for efficient enqueue and dequeue operations, simulating a print job queue
Build an undo/redo system using two stacks: one for undo history, one for redo operations

sub_topics.name: Collections Module
sub_topics.short_description: Using specialized container types from collections module: deque, Counter, defaultdict, OrderedDict, and namedtuple.
example_tasks: Use Counter to analyze text and find most common words: from collections import Counter; word_counts = Counter(words)
Implement defaultdict to group items by category without checking if key exists: from collections import defaultdict; groups = defaultdict(list)
Create namedtuple for readable record structures: from collections import namedtuple; Student = namedtuple('Student', ['name', 'grade', 'gpa'])

sub_topics.name: Advanced Comprehensions
sub_topics.short_description: Using nested comprehensions, dictionary comprehensions, set comprehensions, and generator expressions for complex data transformations.
example_tasks: Create dictionary comprehension to invert a dictionary: inverted = {v: k for k, v in original.items()}
Use nested list comprehension to flatten 2D list: flat = [item for sublist in nested for item in sublist]
Build set comprehension to get unique values: unique_lengths = {len(word) for word in words}

sub_topics.name: Itertools Module
sub_topics.short_description: Using itertools for efficient iteration: permutations, combinations, product, chain, and other iterator tools.
example_tasks: Generate all permutations of a list using itertools.permutations: all_arrangements = list(permutations([1,2,3]))
Create all combinations using itertools.combinations: pairs = list(combinations(students, 2))
Use itertools.product to generate cartesian product: all_combos = list(product([1,2], ['a','b']))

sub_topics.name: File Input/Output
sub_topics.short_description: Reading from and writing to files, working with different file formats (text, CSV, JSON), and handling file operations safely.

sub_topics.name: Text File Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Reading and writing text files, using context managers, processing files line by line efficiently.
example_tasks: Read entire file using with statement: with open('data.txt', 'r') as f: content = f.read(), explaining why context managers are important
Process large files efficiently by reading line by line: for line in file: process(line) without loading entire file into memory
Write to file with proper formatting and newlines: with open('output.txt', 'w') as f: f.write(line + '\n')

sub_topics.name: Working with CSV Files
sub_topics.short_description: Reading and writing CSV files using csv module, handling headers, different delimiters, and data types.
example_tasks: Read CSV file into list of dictionaries using csv.DictReader: with open('data.csv') as f: reader = csv.DictReader(f); data = list(reader)
Write data to CSV file with headers using csv.DictWriter, properly formatting different data types
Parse CSV with custom delimiter or quote character, handling edge cases like commas within quoted fields

sub_topics.name: Working with JSON Files
sub_topics.short_description: Reading and writing JSON files, converting between Python objects and JSON, handling nested structures.
example_tasks: Read JSON file and convert to Python dictionary: with open('data.json') as f: data = json.load(f)
Write Python data structure to JSON file with formatting: json.dump(data, f, indent=4) for readable output
Work with nested JSON structures: extract specific values from deeply nested dictionaries and lists

sub_topics.name: File System Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Using os and pathlib modules for file system navigation, path manipulation, and file metadata.
example_tasks: List all files in directory: import os; files = os.listdir('path') or use pathlib.Path('path').glob('*')
Build cross-platform file paths using pathlib: path = Path('folder') / 'subfolder' / 'file.txt'
Check if file exists, get file size, modification time: path.exists(), path.stat().st_size, path.stat().st_mtime

sub_topics.name: Exception Handling
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding exceptions, using try-except blocks, handling specific exception types, raising exceptions, and creating robust error-resistant code.

sub_topics.name: Try-Except Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Using try-except blocks to catch and handle exceptions, preventing program crashes from runtime errors.
example_tasks: Wrap risky operations in try-except: try: value = int(input()) except ValueError: print('Invalid input'), handling type conversion errors
Handle file operations safely: try: with open(file) as f: data = f.read() except FileNotFoundError: print('File not found')
Prevent division by zero: try: result = a / b except ZeroDivisionError: result = None or appropriate handling

sub_topics.name: Handling Specific Exceptions
sub_topics.short_description: Catching specific exception types, using multiple except blocks, and handling different errors appropriately.
example_tasks: Handle multiple exception types with separate except blocks providing specific error messages for each type
Use exception hierarchy: catch specific exceptions first (ValueError, TypeError) then broader ones (Exception) last
Implement proper error recovery: retry logic for network errors, default values for conversion errors, user-friendly messages

sub_topics.name: Else and Finally Clauses
sub_topics.short_description: Using else clause for code that runs if no exception occurs, finally for cleanup code that always runs.
example_tasks: Use else clause for success logic: try: file = open() except: handle_error() else: process_file(file) finally: cleanup()
Implement finally for resource cleanup: ensure files are closed, database connections released, even if exceptions occur
Create complete exception handling with try-except-else-finally showing appropriate use of each clause

sub_topics.name: Raising Exceptions
sub_topics.short_description: Using raise to throw exceptions when invalid conditions are detected, creating informative error messages.
example_tasks: Validate function inputs and raise ValueError with descriptive message: if age < 0: raise ValueError('Age cannot be negative')
Re-raise exceptions after logging: except Exception as e: log_error(e); raise to preserve stack trace
Create custom validation: check business rules and raise appropriate exceptions when violated

sub_topics.name: Custom Exception Classes
sub_topics.short_description: Creating custom exception classes for domain-specific errors, making code more maintainable and errors more meaningful.
example_tasks: Define custom exception: class InvalidGradeError(Exception): pass for domain-specific error handling
Create exception hierarchy: class ValidationError(Exception); class EmailValidationError(ValidationError) for organized error types
Use custom exceptions in application: raise InsufficientFundsError(f'Balance: {balance}, Required: {amount}')

sub_topics.name: Modules and Packages
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing code into modules and packages, importing effectively, understanding module scope, and creating reusable code libraries.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Using Modules
sub_topics.short_description: Creating Python modules, importing functions and classes, understanding module namespace and __name__ variable.
example_tasks: Create a module file math_utils.py with functions, import in another file: import math_utils or from math_utils import calculate
Use if __name__ == '__main__': to include test code that runs when module executed directly but not when imported
Understand module namespace: accessing module attributes, avoiding naming conflicts between modules

sub_topics.name: Import Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Different ways to import: import module, from module import, import as, and choosing appropriate import style.
example_tasks: Compare import styles: import math (use math.sqrt), from math import sqrt (use sqrt directly), import math as m (alias)
Understand wildcard imports: from module import * and why they're generally discouraged (namespace pollution)
Use selective imports for clarity and efficiency: from collections import Counter, defaultdict instead of importing entire module

sub_topics.name: Creating Packages
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing related modules into packages using directories and __init__.py files, creating hierarchical code organization.
example_tasks: Create package structure: mypackage/__init__.py, mypackage/module1.py, mypackage/module2.py
Import from packages: from mypackage import module1 or from mypackage.module1 import function
Use __init__.py to control package interface: specify what gets imported with from package import *

sub_topics.name: Python Standard Library
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring useful standard library modules: datetime, random, math, re (regex), os, sys, and when to use them.
example_tasks: Use datetime module for date/time operations: calculate age, format dates, parse date strings, handle timezones
Apply random module for simulations: random.choice, random.randint, random.shuffle for various random operations
Use re module for pattern matching: validate emails, extract phone numbers, parse structured text with regular expressions

sub_topics.name: Working with External Libraries
sub_topics.short_description: Installing and using external packages with pip, understanding virtual environments, and integrating third-party libraries.

sub_topics.name: Package Management with pip
sub_topics.short_description: Using pip to install, upgrade, and manage external Python packages from PyPI.
example_tasks: Install packages using pip: pip install requests, pip install pandas, understanding package versioning
Manage installed packages: pip list to see installed packages, pip show package_name for details, pip uninstall to remove
Create requirements.txt file: pip freeze > requirements.txt to document dependencies, pip install -r requirements.txt to install

sub_topics.name: Virtual Environments
sub_topics.short_description: Creating isolated Python environments for projects, managing dependencies separately for different projects.
example_tasks: Create virtual environment: python -m venv myenv, activate it (source myenv/bin/activate or myenv\Scripts\activate on Windows)
Understand why virtual environments matter: different projects need different package versions, avoid conflicts
Set up project workflow: create venv, activate, install packages, freeze requirements, deactivate when done

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Popular Libraries
sub_topics.short_description: Overview of commonly used libraries: requests (HTTP), BeautifulSoup (web scraping), pandas (data analysis), matplotlib (visualization).
example_tasks: Use requests library to fetch data from web APIs: response = requests.get(url); data = response.json()
Parse HTML with BeautifulSoup: soup = BeautifulSoup(html, 'html.parser'); elements = soup.find_all('div', class_='item')
Perform basic data analysis with pandas: read CSV, filter data, calculate statistics, group and aggregate

sub_topics.name: Reading Library Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to read and understand library documentation, finding examples, and troubleshooting library usage.
example_tasks: Navigate library documentation to find function parameters, return values, and usage examples
Use help() function and docstrings to get information about library functions: help(requests.get)
Search documentation and Stack Overflow effectively when encountering errors or unclear library behavior

sub_topics.name: Functional Programming Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding functional programming paradigm, using lambda functions, map, filter, reduce, and functional approaches to problem-solving.

sub_topics.name: Lambda Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating anonymous functions using lambda syntax for simple, one-line function definitions.
example_tasks: Use lambda for simple operations: square = lambda x: x**2; result = square(5)
Apply lambda with sorting: students.sort(key=lambda s: s.gpa, reverse=True) to sort by attribute
Pass lambda to functions expecting callable: filtered = filter(lambda x: x > 0, numbers)

sub_topics.name: Map, Filter, and Reduce
sub_topics.short_description: Using functional tools to transform, filter, and aggregate data without explicit loops.
example_tasks: Use map to transform data: squared = list(map(lambda x: x**2, numbers)) to apply function to each element
Filter data with filter: evens = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, numbers)) to keep elements meeting condition
Aggregate with reduce: from functools import reduce; total = reduce(lambda a, b: a + b, numbers)

sub_topics.name: Higher-Order Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating functions that take functions as arguments or return functions, enabling powerful abstractions.
example_tasks: Create decorator-like function that wraps another function: def timer(func): def wrapper(*args): measure_time; return func(*args); return wrapper
Build function factory that returns customized functions: def make_multiplier(n): return lambda x: x * n
Use functions as data: store functions in dictionaries for command pattern or strategy pattern implementations

sub_topics.name: Functional vs Imperative Style
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding differences between functional (what to do) and imperative (how to do) programming approaches.
example_tasks: Compare imperative loop: result = []; for x in nums: if x > 0: result.append(x*2) vs functional: result = list(map(lambda x: x*2, filter(lambda x: x > 0, nums)))
Refactor imperative code using functional approach: replace explicit loops with map/filter/reduce
Understand tradeoffs: functional style can be more concise but sometimes less readable for complex operations

grade_11_12.name: Object-Oriented Design & Programming
grade_11_12.short_description: Advanced OOP concepts including inheritance, polymorphism, encapsulation, composition, design patterns, and creating robust object-oriented systems.

sub_topics.name: Inheritance
sub_topics.short_description: Creating class hierarchies, inheriting attributes and methods, overriding methods, and understanding is-a relationships.

sub_topics.name: Basic Inheritance
sub_topics.short_description: Creating child classes that inherit from parent classes, understanding inheritance syntax and super() function.
example_tasks: Create Student class inheriting from Person: class Student(Person): adds student_id, gpa while inheriting name, age from Person
Use super().__init__() to call parent constructor: super().__init__(name, age) before adding child-specific attributes
Demonstrate inheritance: child class automatically has all parent methods and attributes without redefining them

sub_topics.name: Method Overriding
sub_topics.short_description: Overriding parent methods in child classes to provide specialized behavior while maintaining same interface.
example_tasks: Override __str__ method in child class to provide more specific string representation than parent class
Override calculate_pay() method differently in SalariedEmployee vs HourlyEmployee classes both inheriting from Employee
Use super() to extend parent method: call parent implementation then add child-specific behavior

sub_topics.name: Multilevel Inheritance
sub_topics.short_description: Creating inheritance chains where classes inherit from classes that inherit from other classes.
example_tasks: Create inheritance chain: Animal → Mammal → Dog, where each level adds more specific attributes and behaviors
Implement hierarchy: Vehicle → Car → ElectricCar, showing how each level specializes the previous one
Understand method resolution order (MRO): which method gets called when multiple levels define same method

sub_topics.name: Multiple Inheritance
sub_topics.short_description: Inheriting from multiple parent classes, understanding diamond problem and method resolution order.
example_tasks: Create class inheriting from multiple parents: class TeachingAssistant(Student, Employee): combining attributes from both
Resolve diamond problem: when same method exists in multiple parents, understand which version is called
Use super() correctly with multiple inheritance to ensure all parent initializers are called

sub_topics.name: Polymorphism
sub_topics.short_description: Using polymorphism to write flexible code that works with objects of different types through common interfaces.

sub_topics.name: Method Polymorphism
sub_topics.short_description: Calling same method on different object types, with each type providing its own implementation.
example_tasks: Create different Shape classes (Circle, Rectangle, Triangle) each with area() method implemented differently
Write function that accepts any Shape and calls area(): works with all shapes despite different implementations
Demonstrate duck typing: if object has required method, it can be used, regardless of its type or inheritance

sub_topics.name: Operator Overloading
sub_topics.short_description: Defining special methods to customize how operators work with custom classes.
example_tasks: Implement __add__ method to enable using + operator: result = vector1 + vector2
Define comparison operators: __lt__, __gt__, __eq__ to enable sorting and comparing custom objects
Overload __len__, __getitem__, __setitem__ to make custom class work like built-in sequence types

sub_topics.name: Abstract Base Classes
sub_topics.short_description: Creating abstract classes that define interface but don't provide implementation, ensuring child classes implement required methods.
example_tasks: Use ABC module: from abc import ABC, abstractmethod; class Shape(ABC): @abstractmethod def area(self): pass
Create abstract class Payment with process() method that must be implemented by CreditCard, PayPal, Bitcoin classes
Understand that abstract classes can't be instantiated directly, only concrete child classes can be created

sub_topics.name: Advanced Encapsulation
sub_topics.short_description: Using properties, private attributes, and access control to protect and validate object state.

sub_topics.name: Property Decorators
sub_topics.short_description: Using @property decorator to create getters and setters that look like attributes but run validation code.
example_tasks: Create property with getter: @property def age(self): return self._age, accessed as obj.age without parentheses
Add setter: @age.setter def age(self, value): validate then set self._age, enabling obj.age = 25 with validation
Implement read-only property: define getter with @property but no setter to prevent modification

sub_topics.name: Data Validation in Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Using property setters to validate data before storing, maintaining object invariants.
example_tasks: Validate age is positive: @age.setter def age(self, value): if value < 0: raise ValueError('Age must be positive')
Validate email format in setter using regular expressions before accepting the value
Ensure percentage is between 0-100: @property setter that raises exception if value out of range

sub_topics.name: Computed Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Creating properties that calculate values on-the-fly rather than storing them, keeping data consistent.
example_tasks: Create computed property: @property def full_name(self): return f'{self.first_name} {self.last_name}' without storing full_name
Calculate age from birthdate: @property def age(self): return (datetime.now() - self.birthdate).years
Compute BMI from height and weight: @property def bmi(self): return self.weight / (self.height ** 2)

sub_topics.name: Composition and Aggregation
sub_topics.short_description: Using composition (has-a relationships) as alternative to inheritance, creating objects that contain other objects.

sub_topics.name: Composition Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Creating classes that contain instances of other classes, understanding has-a vs is-a relationships.
example_tasks: Create Car class containing Engine object: car has-a engine rather than car is-a engine (inheritance)
Build Computer class with CPU, RAM, Storage components as attributes, each being instances of their own classes
Compare inheritance vs composition: Student is-a Person (inheritance), Student has-a Address (composition)

sub_topics.name: Delegating Behavior
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing behavior by delegating to contained objects rather than inheriting.
example_tasks: Create Car class that delegates start() to Engine object: def start(self): self.engine.start()
Build Playlist class containing Song objects, delegating play operations to individual songs
Implement wrapper class that adds functionality by delegating most operations to wrapped object

sub_topics.name: When to Use Composition vs Inheritance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tradeoffs and deciding whether to use inheritance or composition based on problem requirements.
example_tasks: Refactor inheritance hierarchy that's too rigid into composition-based design for more flexibility
Identify scenarios where composition is better: when you need multiple behaviors from different classes
Apply 'favor composition over inheritance' principle: composition provides more flexibility and looser coupling

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Design Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Learning common design patterns: Singleton, Factory, Strategy, Observer, and understanding when to apply them.

sub_topics.name: Singleton Pattern
sub_topics.short_description: Ensuring class has only one instance and providing global point of access to it.
example_tasks: Implement Singleton for Database connection: ensure only one connection exists throughout application
Create Logger singleton that all parts of program can use without creating multiple logger instances
Understand when Singleton is appropriate: shared resources, configuration, caching

sub_topics.name: Factory Pattern
sub_topics.short_description: Creating objects through factory methods rather than direct instantiation, encapsulating object creation logic.
example_tasks: Create ShapeFactory that returns appropriate shape object based on type: factory.create_shape('circle') returns Circle object
Implement factory method for creating different payment processors based on payment type
Use factory pattern to hide complex object creation: factory handles initialization complexity

sub_topics.name: Strategy Pattern
sub_topics.short_description: Defining family of algorithms, encapsulating each one, and making them interchangeable.
example_tasks: Create different sorting strategies (BubbleSort, QuickSort, MergeSort) that can be swapped in sorting algorithm
Implement payment strategies: CreditCardPayment, PayPalPayment, CryptoPayment with common interface
Build discount calculation with different strategies: RegularDiscount, SeasonalDiscount, LoyaltyDiscount

sub_topics.name: Observer Pattern
sub_topics.short_description: Defining one-to-many dependency where when one object changes state, dependents are notified automatically.
example_tasks: Implement news publisher-subscriber system: when news is published, all subscribers are notified
Create stock price observer: when price changes, all watching portfolios update automatically
Build event system: GUI components observe data model and update when model changes

sub_topics.name: SOLID Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding SOLID principles for writing maintainable, flexible object-oriented code.

sub_topics.name: Single Responsibility Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Each class should have one reason to change, one specific responsibility.
example_tasks: Refactor class that does too much (User class that handles authentication, database, and email) into separate classes
Identify responsibilities in existing code and split into focused classes: UserRepository, AuthenticationService, EmailService
Evaluate classes for SRP: does this class have multiple reasons to change?

sub_topics.name: Open/Closed Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Classes should be open for extension but closed for modification, use inheritance or composition to add functionality.
example_tasks: Design shape system that can add new shapes without modifying existing code using polymorphism
Create plugin architecture where new features can be added without changing core system
Use strategy pattern to make system extensible: new strategies can be added without modifying client code

sub_topics.name: Liskov Substitution Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Objects of a superclass should be replaceable with objects of subclass without breaking the application.
example_tasks: Identify LSP violation: Square inheriting from Rectangle where setting width also sets height breaks rectangle behavior
Design class hierarchy that respects LSP: child classes can be used anywhere parent is expected
Refactor inheritance hierarchy that violates LSP into composition or different hierarchy

sub_topics.name: Interface Segregation Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Clients shouldn't be forced to depend on interfaces they don't use, prefer small, focused interfaces.
example_tasks: Split large interface into smaller ones: Printer interface becomes Printable, Scannable, Faxable
Create role-based interfaces rather than one large interface: ReadableRepository, WritableRepository
Refactor fat interface that forces implementations to have methods they don't need

sub_topics.name: Dependency Inversion Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Depend on abstractions, not concretions; high-level modules shouldn't depend on low-level modules.
example_tasks: Use dependency injection: pass database interface to service rather than hardcoding specific database
Create abstract interface that both high-level and low-level modules depend on
Refactor code that directly instantiates dependencies to receive them as parameters (dependency injection)

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Web Development
grade_11_12.short_description: Backend development with server-side programming, RESTful APIs, asynchronous JavaScript, AJAX, and building full-stack web applications with databases.

sub_topics.name: Backend Development Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding server-side programming, HTTP request/response cycle, routing, and server architecture basics.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Server-Side Programming
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding role of backend in web applications, server-side vs client-side code, and choosing backend technologies.
example_tasks: Explain the client-server model for web applications: browser sends HTTP request, server processes and returns response
Compare server-side languages (Python/Flask, Node.js/Express, PHP) and understand when to use each
Identify which tasks belong on server (database access, authentication, business logic) vs client (UI, validation, interactivity)

sub_topics.name: HTTP Methods and RESTful Design
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) and designing RESTful APIs that follow conventions.
example_tasks: Design RESTful routes for blog: GET /posts (list), POST /posts (create), GET /posts/123 (read), PUT /posts/123 (update), DELETE /posts/123
Understand idempotency: GET and PUT are idempotent (same result when repeated), POST is not
Implement CRUD operations using appropriate HTTP methods following REST conventions

sub_topics.name: Routing and URL Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Creating routes that map URLs to handler functions, extracting parameters from URLs, and organizing routes.
example_tasks: Create routes in Flask: @app.route('/users/<int:user_id>') def get_user(user_id): to handle dynamic URLs
Implement route with query parameters: /search?q=python&category=programming and access via request.args
Organize routes logically: group related routes (all user routes together), use blueprints for modularity

sub_topics.name: Building Web Apps with Flask
sub_topics.short_description: Using Flask framework to create web applications with templates, forms, sessions, and database integration.

sub_topics.name: Flask Application Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Setting up Flask applications, creating routes, handling requests, and returning responses.
example_tasks: Create basic Flask app: from flask import Flask; app = Flask(__name__); @app.route('/') def home(): return 'Hello World'
Handle different request methods: @app.route('/submit', methods=['GET', 'POST']) checking if request.method == 'POST'
Return different response types: HTML, JSON, redirects, setting status codes

sub_topics.name: Templates with Jinja2
sub_topics.short_description: Using Jinja2 templating to generate dynamic HTML, template inheritance, and passing data to templates.
example_tasks: Create template with variables: {{ user.name }}, loops: {% for item in items %}, conditionals: {% if condition %}
Implement template inheritance: base.html with {% block content %}, child templates extend and override blocks
Pass data to templates: return render_template('page.html', users=users, title='User List')

sub_topics.name: Forms and Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Handling form submissions, validating input server-side, displaying validation errors, and protecting against CSRF.
example_tasks: Handle form submission: access data with request.form['fieldname'], validate inputs, redirect after successful POST
Implement server-side validation: check required fields, validate email format, ensure age is positive number
Use Flask-WTF for forms: create form classes, render forms in templates, validate with validators, handle CSRF protection

sub_topics.name: Sessions and Cookies
sub_topics.short_description: Managing user sessions, storing data across requests, using cookies safely, and implementing authentication.
example_tasks: Use Flask sessions: from flask import session; session['user_id'] = user.id to store user state across requests
Implement login system: check credentials, store user_id in session, check session on protected routes
Set cookies: response.set_cookie('preference', value), read cookies: request.cookies.get('preference')

sub_topics.name: Building RESTful APIs
sub_topics.short_description: Creating APIs that return JSON, handling API requests, authentication, error handling, and API documentation.

sub_topics.name: Creating JSON APIs
sub_topics.short_description: Returning JSON data from API endpoints, serializing Python objects to JSON, and handling JSON requests.
example_tasks: Create API endpoint returning JSON: from flask import jsonify; @app.route('/api/users') def get_users(): return jsonify(users)
Parse JSON from request body: data = request.get_json(); process data from POST/PUT requests
Design API response format: consistent structure with data, status, message fields

sub_topics.name: API Authentication
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing API authentication using tokens, API keys, or JWT for securing API endpoints.
example_tasks: Implement token-based authentication: generate token on login, require token in Authorization header for protected endpoints
Create API key system: generate keys, validate keys in requests, associate keys with users/applications
Use JWT (JSON Web Tokens): create token with user claims, validate token on each request, handle token expiration

sub_topics.name: API Error Handling
sub_topics.short_description: Returning appropriate HTTP status codes, formatting error responses consistently, handling exceptions gracefully.
example_tasks: Return appropriate status codes: 200 (success), 201 (created), 400 (bad request), 401 (unauthorized), 404 (not found), 500 (server error)
Format error responses: return jsonify({'error': 'Resource not found', 'status': 404}), status=404
Handle exceptions globally: use @app.errorhandler to catch exceptions and return formatted error responses

sub_topics.name: API Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Documenting API endpoints, parameters, responses, and authentication requirements for API consumers.
example_tasks: Document each endpoint: URL, HTTP method, parameters, request body format, response format, status codes
Create API documentation: use tools like Swagger/OpenAPI or write manual documentation with examples
Provide example requests/responses: show curl commands, example JSON payloads, expected responses for documentation

sub_topics.name: Asynchronous JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding asynchronous programming, callbacks, promises, async/await, and handling asynchronous operations effectively.

sub_topics.name: Callbacks and Asynchronous Code
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why asynchronous code is needed, using callbacks to handle async operations, and callback hell.
example_tasks: Use setTimeout to demonstrate async: setTimeout(() => console.log('delayed'), 1000) executes after delay
Handle async file reading: fs.readFile('file.txt', (err, data) => { if(err) handle_error; else process(data) })
Identify callback hell: deeply nested callbacks that are hard to read and maintain

sub_topics.name: Promises
sub_topics.short_description: Using promises to handle asynchronous operations, chaining with .then(), catching errors with .catch().
example_tasks: Create and use promise: fetch(url).then(response => response.json()).then(data => console.log(data)).catch(error => console.error(error))
Chain promises: multiple async operations in sequence, passing data from one then() to next
Handle promise errors: use .catch() to handle errors anywhere in promise chain

sub_topics.name: Async/Await
sub_topics.short_description: Using async/await syntax for cleaner asynchronous code, error handling with try/catch.
example_tasks: Convert promise chain to async/await: async function fetchData() { const response = await fetch(url); const data = await response.json(); return data; }
Handle errors with try/catch: try { const data = await fetchData(); } catch(error) { handle_error }
Understand when to use await: only inside async functions, pauses execution until promise resolves

sub_topics.name: Parallel Asynchronous Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Running multiple async operations concurrently using Promise.all(), Promise.race(), and understanding parallelism benefits.
example_tasks: Use Promise.all to wait for multiple promises: const [data1, data2, data3] = await Promise.all([fetch1(), fetch2(), fetch3()])
Understand Promise.race: returns first promise to settle, useful for timeout implementations
Compare sequential vs parallel execution time when multiple independent async operations needed

sub_topics.name: AJAX and Fetch API
sub_topics.short_description: Making HTTP requests from JavaScript without page reload, updating page content dynamically, and working with APIs.

sub_topics.name: Fetch API Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Using fetch() to make HTTP requests, handling responses, and working with JSON data.
example_tasks: Make GET request: fetch('https://api.example.com/data').then(res => res.json()).then(data => display(data))
Make POST request with JSON: fetch(url, { method: 'POST', headers: {'Content-Type': 'application/json'}, body: JSON.stringify(data) })
Handle fetch errors: check response.ok, handle network errors with catch

sub_topics.name: Dynamic Page Updates
sub_topics.short_description: Updating DOM based on API responses, creating interactive features without page refresh.
example_tasks: Load data on button click: fetch data from API, parse JSON, update DOM to display results without page reload
Implement infinite scroll: detect scroll position, fetch more data, append to page dynamically
Create auto-complete search: send requests as user types, display suggestions, handle rapid keystrokes with debouncing

sub_topics.name: Loading States and Error Handling
sub_topics.short_description: Showing loading indicators during async operations, handling timeouts, and displaying errors to users.
example_tasks: Display loading spinner: show spinner before fetch, hide after data loads or error occurs
Implement timeout: use Promise.race with fetch and timeout promise to cancel slow requests
Handle API errors gracefully: display user-friendly error messages, provide retry option, log errors for debugging

sub_topics.name: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding CORS restrictions, working with APIs that require CORS, and handling CORS errors.
example_tasks: Understand CORS errors: why browsers block cross-origin requests, what same-origin policy means
Work with CORS-enabled APIs: use APIs that send Access-Control-Allow-Origin headers
Handle CORS in development: use proxy or CORS browser extensions for testing, understand production solutions

sub_topics.name: Database Integration
sub_topics.short_description: Connecting web applications to databases, using ORMs, performing CRUD operations, and managing database migrations.

sub_topics.name: Flask with SQLAlchemy ORM
sub_topics.short_description: Using SQLAlchemy ORM to interact with databases from Flask applications, defining models and relationships.
example_tasks: Set up Flask-SQLAlchemy: configure database URI, initialize db, create models as Python classes
Define model: class User(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True); name = db.Column(db.String)
Create relationships: define one-to-many (User has many Posts), many-to-many (Students and Courses) using db.relationship

sub_topics.name: CRUD Operations with ORM
sub_topics.short_description: Performing Create, Read, Update, Delete operations using ORM rather than raw SQL.
example_tasks: Create record: user = User(name='Alice'); db.session.add(user); db.session.commit()
Query records: User.query.all(), User.query.filter_by(name='Alice').first(), User.query.get(id)
Update record: user = User.query.get(id); user.name = 'Bob'; db.session.commit()
Delete record: db.session.delete(user); db.session.commit()

sub_topics.name: Query Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Writing efficient database queries, understanding N+1 problem, using eager loading and indexes.
example_tasks: Identify N+1 query problem: loading posts then making separate query for each post's author
Use eager loading: User.query.options(db.joinedload(User.posts)).all() to load related data efficiently
Add database indexes: create indexes on frequently queried columns to improve query performance

sub_topics.name: Database Migrations
sub_topics.short_description: Managing database schema changes over time using migration tools like Flask-Migrate/Alembic.
example_tasks: Initialize migrations: flask db init to set up migration repository
Create migration: flask db migrate -m 'Add email to User' after modifying models
Apply migration: flask db upgrade to update database schema to match models

grade_11_12.name: Database Design & Management
grade_11_12.short_description: Advanced database design including normalization, complex queries with joins and subqueries, transactions, indexes, and database administration concepts.

sub_topics.name: Database Normalization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding normal forms (1NF, 2NF, 3NF), eliminating redundancy and anomalies through proper database design.

sub_topics.name: First Normal Form (1NF)
sub_topics.short_description: Ensuring atomic values, eliminating repeating groups, and establishing primary keys.
example_tasks: Convert unnormalized table with comma-separated phone numbers into 1NF by creating separate rows for each phone number
Identify violations of 1NF: columns containing lists, arrays, or multiple values that should be split into separate rows
Create 1NF table structure: each field contains single value, no repeating columns (phone1, phone2, phone3)

sub_topics.name: Second Normal Form (2NF)
sub_topics.short_description: Removing partial dependencies, ensuring non-key attributes depend on entire primary key.
example_tasks: Identify partial dependency: in OrderDetails(OrderID, ProductID, ProductName, Price), ProductName depends only on ProductID not full composite key
Normalize to 2NF: split table to eliminate partial dependencies, create separate Products table
Verify 2NF: check that all non-key attributes fully depend on primary key, no attributes depend on only part of composite key

sub_topics.name: Third Normal Form (3NF)
sub_topics.short_description: Removing transitive dependencies, ensuring non-key attributes depend only on primary key, not on other non-key attributes.
example_tasks: Identify transitive dependency: in Students(StudentID, AdvisorID, AdvisorName, AdvisorOffice), AdvisorName depends on AdvisorID not StudentID
Normalize to 3NF: create separate Advisors table to eliminate transitive dependency
Design database in 3NF from requirements: identify entities, attributes, and relationships ensuring proper normalization

sub_topics.name: When to Denormalize
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tradeoffs of normalization, when denormalization improves performance, balancing normalization and efficiency.
example_tasks: Identify scenarios where denormalization helps: read-heavy systems, reporting databases, avoiding complex joins
Implement controlled denormalization: add calculated fields, cache aggregates while maintaining source data normalized
Compare performance: measure query speed on normalized vs denormalized schemas for specific use cases

sub_topics.name: Complex SQL Queries
sub_topics.short_description: Writing advanced queries using joins, subqueries, aggregations, and set operations to extract complex information.

sub_topics.name: SQL Joins
sub_topics.short_description: Using INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, FULL JOIN to combine data from multiple tables.
example_tasks: Write INNER JOIN: SELECT * FROM Students s INNER JOIN Enrollments e ON s.StudentID = e.StudentID to get students with enrollments
Use LEFT JOIN to include all students even without enrollments: LEFT JOIN shows nulls for students not enrolled
Create complex multi-table join: join Students, Enrollments, and Courses to show student names with course titles

sub_topics.name: Subqueries
sub_topics.short_description: Using nested queries in WHERE, SELECT, and FROM clauses to perform complex filtering and calculations.
example_tasks: Use subquery in WHERE: SELECT * FROM Products WHERE Price > (SELECT AVG(Price) FROM Products) to find above-average prices
Create correlated subquery: SELECT s.Name, (SELECT AVG(Grade) FROM Enrollments WHERE StudentID = s.StudentID) FROM Students s
Use subquery in FROM: SELECT * FROM (SELECT Name, Price FROM Products WHERE Category='Electronics') AS Electronics

sub_topics.name: Aggregate Functions and GROUP BY
sub_topics.short_description: Using COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX with GROUP BY and HAVING to analyze data.
example_tasks: Calculate aggregates: SELECT Department, COUNT(*), AVG(Salary) FROM Employees GROUP BY Department
Use HAVING to filter groups: SELECT Category, COUNT(*) FROM Products GROUP BY Category HAVING COUNT(*) > 5
Create complex aggregation: find departments with average salary above company average using subquery and GROUP BY

sub_topics.name: Set Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Using UNION, INTERSECT, EXCEPT to combine results from multiple queries.
example_tasks: Use UNION to combine results: SELECT Name FROM Students2023 UNION SELECT Name FROM Students2024
Find common elements with INTERSECT: students enrolled in both math and science courses
Use EXCEPT to find differences: students in database but not in current enrollment

sub_topics.name: Window Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Using RANK, ROW_NUMBER, PARTITION BY for advanced analytics without grouping rows.
example_tasks: Rank students: SELECT Name, Grade, RANK() OVER (ORDER BY Grade DESC) as Rank FROM Students
Use PARTITION BY: SELECT Name, Department, Salary, RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY Department ORDER BY Salary DESC) FROM Employees
Calculate running totals: SELECT Date, Amount, SUM(Amount) OVER (ORDER BY Date) as RunningTotal FROM Sales

sub_topics.name: Advanced SQL Features
sub_topics.short_description: Using views, stored procedures, triggers, and transactions for complex database operations and automation.

sub_topics.name: Database Views
sub_topics.short_description: Creating virtual tables with views to simplify complex queries and control data access.
example_tasks: Create view for complex query: CREATE VIEW StudentGrades AS SELECT s.Name, c.Title, e.Grade FROM Students s JOIN Enrollments e JOIN Courses c
Use view to hide sensitive data: create view showing only non-sensitive columns for specific users
Update data through views: understand when views are updatable and restrictions on updating joined views

sub_topics.name: Stored Procedures
sub_topics.short_description: Creating reusable SQL procedures that accept parameters and encapsulate business logic in database.
example_tasks: Create stored procedure: CREATE PROCEDURE GetStudentsByGrade(grade INT) AS SELECT * FROM Students WHERE Grade = grade
Use parameters and logic: create procedure that accepts input, performs validation, executes queries, returns results
Understand benefits: code reuse, security, performance (compiled), centralized business logic

sub_topics.name: Database Triggers
sub_topics.short_description: Creating triggers that automatically execute code in response to database events like INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE.
example_tasks: Create audit trigger: automatically log changes to audit table when records are updated or deleted
Implement validation trigger: prevent invalid data insertion, enforce complex business rules
Create cascading trigger: automatically update related records when main record changes

sub_topics.name: Transactions and ACID Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Using transactions to ensure data integrity, understanding ACID properties, and handling transaction rollback.
example_tasks: Implement transaction: BEGIN TRANSACTION; UPDATE Accounts SET Balance -= 100 WHERE ID = 1; UPDATE Accounts SET Balance += 100 WHERE ID = 2; COMMIT;
Handle errors with rollback: use TRY-CATCH to rollback transaction if any operation fails
Explain ACID: Atomicity (all or nothing), Consistency (valid state), Isolation (concurrent transactions), Durability (permanent)

sub_topics.name: Database Performance Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding indexes, query optimization, execution plans, and improving database performance.

sub_topics.name: Database Indexes
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and using indexes to speed up queries, understanding index types and tradeoffs.
example_tasks: Create index on frequently queried column: CREATE INDEX idx_lastname ON Students(LastName) to speed up name searches
Use composite index: CREATE INDEX idx_name ON Students(LastName, FirstName) for queries filtering on both columns
Understand index tradeoffs: faster reads but slower writes, storage overhead, choose which columns to index based on query patterns

sub_topics.name: Query Optimization Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Writing efficient queries, avoiding common performance pitfalls, using EXPLAIN to analyze queries.
example_tasks: Use EXPLAIN to analyze query execution plan: EXPLAIN SELECT * FROM Students WHERE Grade = 11 to see if index is used
Optimize slow queries: add indexes, rewrite with better joins, avoid SELECT *, limit result sets
Identify performance problems: N+1 queries, unnecessary joins, missing indexes, inefficient WHERE clauses

sub_topics.name: Database Tuning
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding database configuration, cache settings, connection pooling, and system-level optimization.
example_tasks: Configure connection pooling: limit concurrent connections, reuse connections instead of creating new ones
Optimize cache settings: configure buffer pool size, query cache to improve frequently-accessed data retrieval
Monitor database performance: track slow queries, connection counts, cache hit rates, identify bottlenecks

sub_topics.name: Advanced Data Modeling
sub_topics.short_description: Creating entity-relationship diagrams, modeling complex relationships, and designing databases for real-world applications.

sub_topics.name: Entity-Relationship Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Creating ER diagrams with entities, attributes, relationships, cardinality, and converting to database schema.
example_tasks: Create ER diagram for library system: entities (Book, Member, Loan), relationships (Member borrows Book), cardinality (one-to-many)
Model many-to-many relationship: Students and Courses with junction table Enrollments containing additional attributes
Convert ER diagram to database schema: translate entities to tables, relationships to foreign keys, handle cardinality

sub_topics.name: Modeling Relationship Types
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many relationships in database design.
example_tasks: Implement one-to-one: Person and Passport where each person has exactly one passport, use foreign key with UNIQUE constraint
Model one-to-many: Customer and Orders where one customer has many orders, foreign key CustomerID in Orders table
Create many-to-many: Students and Courses using junction table StudentCourses(StudentID, CourseID, Grade, Semester)

sub_topics.name: Database Design Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding common patterns like single table inheritance, polymorphic associations, and temporal data.
example_tasks: Implement inheritance: design for Employee → Manager, Employee → Developer using single table with type column or separate tables
Model hierarchical data: organizational chart, category trees using parent_id self-referencing or nested sets
Handle temporal data: track historical changes, maintain audit trail with effective_date and end_date columns

sub_topics.name: Designing from Requirements
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing business requirements, identifying entities and relationships, creating complete database design.
example_tasks: Design e-commerce database from requirements: identify entities (Customer, Product, Order, Payment), define relationships and constraints
Create school management system: students, teachers, courses, grades, attendance with appropriate tables and relationships
Model social media platform: users, posts, comments, likes, follows with efficient schema supporting common queries

sub_topics.name: Database Security
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding SQL injection, parameterized queries, user permissions, encryption, and securing database applications.

sub_topics.name: SQL Injection Prevention
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding SQL injection attacks and preventing them using parameterized queries and input validation.
example_tasks: Identify SQL injection vulnerability: query = f"SELECT * FROM Users WHERE username='{user_input}'" allows malicious input
Use parameterized queries: cursor.execute('SELECT * FROM Users WHERE username = ?', (user_input,)) to prevent injection
Validate and sanitize input: check input format, escape special characters, use whitelist validation

sub_topics.name: User Permissions and Access Control
sub_topics.short_description: Creating database users, granting and revoking permissions, implementing principle of least privilege.
example_tasks: Create database user with limited permissions: GRANT SELECT ON Students TO read_only_user; no INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE
Implement role-based access: create roles (admin, teacher, student) with different permission levels
Use views for security: create views showing subset of columns, grant access to views instead of base tables

sub_topics.name: Data Encryption
sub_topics.short_description: Encrypting sensitive data at rest and in transit, hashing passwords, protecting confidential information.
example_tasks: Hash passwords before storing: use bcrypt or similar to hash passwords, never store plain text passwords
Encrypt sensitive fields: encrypt Social Security numbers, credit card numbers using appropriate encryption algorithms
Understand encryption levels: database-level encryption, column-level encryption, connection encryption (SSL/TLS)

sub_topics.name: Backup and Recovery
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing backup strategies, point-in-time recovery, disaster recovery planning.
example_tasks: Create backup strategy: full backups weekly, incremental backups daily, transaction log backups hourly
Test recovery procedures: restore from backup to verify backups are working, practice recovery process
Implement point-in-time recovery: use transaction logs to restore database to specific moment before data corruption

grade_11_12.name: Data Structures & Algorithms
grade_11_12.short_description: Advanced data structures including trees, graphs, hash tables, heaps, and advanced algorithms including recursion, dynamic programming, and graph algorithms.

sub_topics.name: Tree Data Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tree structures, binary trees, binary search trees, tree traversal algorithms, and tree applications.

sub_topics.name: Binary Trees
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding binary tree structure where each node has at most two children, implementing nodes and basic operations.
example_tasks: Implement binary tree node class: class Node: def __init__(self, data): self.data = data; self.left = None; self.right = None
Create binary tree by manually linking nodes: root = Node(1); root.left = Node(2); root.right = Node(3)
Calculate tree properties: height, number of nodes, check if balanced using recursive algorithms

sub_topics.name: Tree Traversal
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing in-order, pre-order, post-order, and level-order traversal algorithms for visiting all tree nodes.
example_tasks: Implement in-order traversal recursively: visit left subtree, process node, visit right subtree (gives sorted order for BST)
Write pre-order traversal: process node, visit left, visit right (useful for copying tree structure)
Implement level-order traversal using queue: visit nodes level by level from left to right

sub_topics.name: Binary Search Trees (BST)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding BST property (left < parent < right), implementing insert, search, delete operations efficiently.
example_tasks: Implement BST insert: compare value with node, recursively insert in left or right subtree maintaining BST property
Write BST search algorithm: compare target with node, search left if smaller, right if larger, O(log n) average case
Implement delete operation: handle three cases: no children (remove), one child (replace with child), two children (replace with inorder successor)

sub_topics.name: Tree Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Using trees for file systems, expression parsing, decision trees, and understanding when trees are the right data structure.
example_tasks: Model file system as tree: directories are nodes, files are leaves, implement operations like find, list, navigate
Parse arithmetic expressions into expression tree: evaluate by traversing tree, handle operator precedence
Implement autocomplete using trie (prefix tree): efficiently store and search words by prefix

sub_topics.name: Graph Data Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding graphs, representing graphs with adjacency matrices and lists, graph traversal, and basic graph algorithms.

sub_topics.name: Graph Representation
sub_topics.short_description: Representing graphs using adjacency matrix, adjacency list, understanding directed vs undirected, weighted vs unweighted.
example_tasks: Implement graph with adjacency list: graph = {node: [neighbors]} where neighbors is list of connected nodes
Create adjacency matrix: 2D array where matrix[i][j] = 1 if edge exists between node i and j, 0 otherwise
Compare representations: adjacency list better for sparse graphs, matrix better for dense graphs and edge lookup

sub_topics.name: Graph Traversal
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing depth-first search (DFS) and breadth-first search (BFS) to visit all nodes in a graph.
example_tasks: Implement DFS recursively: visit node, mark as visited, recursively visit unvisited neighbors, useful for cycle detection
Implement BFS with queue: enqueue start node, dequeue, enqueue unvisited neighbors, useful for shortest path in unweighted graph
Compare DFS vs BFS: DFS uses stack/recursion (explores deep), BFS uses queue (explores level by level)

sub_topics.name: Shortest Path Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Finding shortest paths in graphs using Dijkstra's algorithm and understanding path-finding applications.
example_tasks: Implement Dijkstra's algorithm: find shortest path from source to all nodes in weighted graph using priority queue
Trace Dijkstra's execution on small graph showing how distances are updated and final shortest paths
Apply to real problems: GPS navigation, network routing, finding cheapest flight connections

sub_topics.name: Graph Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Using graphs to model real-world problems: social networks, maps, dependencies, recommendations.
example_tasks: Model social network: users as nodes, friendships as edges, find mutual friends, suggest connections, detect communities
Represent course prerequisites as directed graph: detect cycles (impossible prerequisites), find valid course orderings (topological sort)
Implement recommendation system: users/items as graph, edges represent similarities, recommend based on connected nodes

sub_topics.name: Hash Tables and Hashing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding hash functions, collision resolution, implementing hash tables, and analyzing hash table performance.

sub_topics.name: Hash Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding properties of good hash functions, creating hash functions for different data types.
example_tasks: Implement simple hash function for strings: sum ASCII values modulo table size, understand distribution issues
Create better hash: use polynomial rolling hash to reduce collisions and distribute keys evenly
Understand hash function properties: deterministic, uniform distribution, efficient to compute

sub_topics.name: Collision Resolution
sub_topics.short_description: Handling collisions using chaining (linked lists) and open addressing (linear probing, quadratic probing).
example_tasks: Implement chaining: each bucket contains linked list of all keys that hash to that location
Implement linear probing: if bucket occupied, check next bucket, continue until empty slot found
Compare collision strategies: chaining never fills up but uses extra memory, open addressing is cache-friendly but can cluster

sub_topics.name: Hash Table Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing insert, search, delete operations in hash tables, analyzing average and worst-case performance.
example_tasks: Implement hash table with chaining: insert(key, value), get(key), delete(key) with O(1) average case
Handle load factor: resize table when load factor exceeds threshold, rehash all keys to new table
Analyze performance: average O(1) for operations, worst case O(n) if all keys collide

sub_topics.name: Hash Table Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Using hash tables for caching, deduplication, counting frequencies, implementing sets and dictionaries.
example_tasks: Implement cache with hash table: store expensive computation results, check cache before recalculating
Count word frequencies: use hash table to map words to counts, efficient O(1) increment
Detect duplicates: insert elements into hash set, O(1) lookup to check if element already seen

sub_topics.name: Heaps and Priority Queues
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heap data structure, implementing min-heap and max-heap, using heaps for priority queues and heap sort.

sub_topics.name: Heap Structure and Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heap property (parent smaller/larger than children), representing heap as array, complete binary tree.
example_tasks: Understand min-heap property: parent is smaller than both children, root is minimum element
Represent heap as array: for node at index i, left child at 2i+1, right child at 2i+2, parent at (i-1)//2
Verify heap property: check that all nodes satisfy heap property, identify violations

sub_topics.name: Heap Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing insert, extract-min, heapify operations, maintaining heap property.
example_tasks: Implement heap insert: add element at end, bubble up by swapping with parent until heap property restored
Implement extract-min: remove root, move last element to root, bubble down to restore heap property
Build heap from array: use heapify to convert unsorted array into heap in O(n) time

sub_topics.name: Priority Queue with Heap
sub_topics.short_description: Using heaps to implement efficient priority queues supporting insert and extract-min in O(log n).
example_tasks: Implement priority queue using heap: enqueue adds element, dequeue removes and returns minimum element
Use priority queue for task scheduling: tasks have priorities, always process highest priority task next
Solve problems with priority queue: merge k sorted lists, find k largest elements in array

sub_topics.name: Heap Sort
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing heap sort algorithm using heap operations, understanding time and space complexity.
example_tasks: Implement heap sort: build max-heap, repeatedly extract maximum and place at end of array
Analyze complexity: O(n log n) time for all cases, O(1) extra space (in-place sorting)
Compare to other sorts: slower than quicksort on average but guaranteed O(n log n), in-place unlike merge sort

sub_topics.name: Advanced Recursion
sub_topics.short_description: Mastering recursion for complex problems, backtracking, divide and conquer, and understanding recursion tree analysis.

sub_topics.name: Divide and Conquer
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking problems into smaller subproblems, solving recursively, combining results (merge sort, quick sort).
example_tasks: Implement merge sort: divide array in half, recursively sort halves, merge sorted halves in O(n log n) time
Implement quick sort: choose pivot, partition around pivot, recursively sort partitions
Analyze using recursion tree: visualize recursive calls, calculate time complexity from tree structure

sub_topics.name: Backtracking
sub_topics.short_description: Using backtracking to explore all possibilities, pruning invalid branches, solving constraint satisfaction problems.
example_tasks: Solve N-Queens problem: place N queens on chess board so none attack each other, backtrack when conflict detected
Generate all permutations of array using backtracking: try each element in each position, backtrack and try next
Solve sudoku puzzle: try values 1-9 in each cell, backtrack if constraints violated, find valid solution

sub_topics.name: Memoization and Dynamic Programming Intro
sub_topics.short_description: Optimizing recursive solutions by caching results, avoiding redundant computation in overlapping subproblems.
example_tasks: Optimize Fibonacci with memoization: cache = {}; if n in cache: return cache[n]; result = fib(n-1) + fib(n-2); cache[n] = result
Solve staircase problem: ways to climb n stairs taking 1 or 2 steps at a time, use memoization to avoid recalculating
Compare naive recursion vs memoization: exponential time vs polynomial time for problems with overlapping subproblems

sub_topics.name: Algorithm Complexity Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing time and space complexity rigorously, understanding Big O, Big Theta, Big Omega, and comparing algorithms.

sub_topics.name: Big O, Theta, and Omega
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding asymptotic notation: Big O (upper bound), Big Theta (tight bound), Big Omega (lower bound).
example_tasks: Analyze algorithm complexity: determine Big O by identifying dominant term as n grows large
Distinguish notations: O(n²) means at most quadratic, Θ(n²) means exactly quadratic, Ω(n²) means at least quadratic
Prove complexity: show algorithm is O(n log n) by analyzing operations in terms of input size

sub_topics.name: Common Complexity Classes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding O(1), O(log n), O(n), O(n log n), O(n²), O(2ⁿ) and their practical implications.
example_tasks: Identify complexity class of algorithms: array access (O(1)), binary search (O(log n)), linear search (O(n)), merge sort (O(n log n))
Understand growth rates: graph how runtime grows with input size for different complexity classes
Determine practical limits: O(n²) acceptable for n < 1000, O(2ⁿ) only for very small n < 20

sub_topics.name: Space Complexity
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing memory usage of algorithms, understanding space-time tradeoffs, in-place vs auxiliary space.
example_tasks: Calculate space complexity: recursive calls use O(depth) stack space, auxiliary arrays use O(n) space
Compare in-place algorithms (O(1) space) vs algorithms using auxiliary space (O(n) space)
Analyze space-time tradeoff: memoization uses O(n) space to reduce time from O(2ⁿ) to O(n)

sub_topics.name: Best, Average, and Worst Case
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different cases of algorithm performance, when each case occurs, analyzing realistic expectations.
example_tasks: Analyze quicksort: best/average O(n log n) with good pivot, worst O(n²) with bad pivot (sorted input)
Understand linear search: best case O(1) finding first element, worst case O(n) element not present, average O(n/2)
Compare algorithms by worst case: merge sort guarantees O(n log n), quicksort O(n²) worst but O(n log n) average

grade_11_12.name: Software Engineering & Project Management
grade_11_12.short_description: Software development lifecycle, agile methodologies, collaborative development with Git and GitHub, code quality, testing strategies, and managing software projects.

sub_topics.name: Software Development Life Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding phases of software development: planning, analysis, design, implementation, testing, deployment, maintenance.

sub_topics.name: SDLC Phases
sub_topics.short_description: Learning each phase of software development and its importance in delivering quality software.
example_tasks: Describe each SDLC phase: requirements gathering, design, implementation, testing, deployment, maintenance with specific activities
Apply SDLC to project: document requirements, create design diagrams, implement features, test, deploy, plan maintenance
Understand phase dependencies: can't test before implementation, can't implement without design, can't design without requirements

sub_topics.name: Waterfall Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sequential SDLC approach where each phase completed before next begins.
example_tasks: Compare waterfall characteristics: sequential phases, detailed documentation, difficult to change requirements late
Identify when waterfall appropriate: well-defined requirements, regulatory compliance, hardware-software integration
Understand limitations: inflexible to change, late testing discovers problems, long time to deliver working software

sub_topics.name: Iterative and Incremental Development
sub_topics.short_description: Developing software in cycles, delivering working increments, incorporating feedback continuously.
example_tasks: Plan iterative development: break project into iterations, each delivering working software increment
Implement increment: add features in priority order, get feedback after each iteration, adjust based on feedback
Understand benefits: early user feedback, risk reduction, flexibility to change requirements

sub_topics.name: Agile Methodologies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding agile principles, Scrum framework, sprints, user stories, and agile practices for flexible software development.

sub_topics.name: Agile Principles and Values
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Agile Manifesto values and principles that prioritize individuals, working software, collaboration, and responding to change.
example_tasks: Explain agile values: individuals over processes, working software over documentation, collaboration over contracts, responding to change over plans
Apply agile principles: deliver working software frequently, welcome changing requirements, collaborate daily, reflect and adjust
Compare agile vs waterfall: flexibility vs planning, incremental vs all-at-once delivery, collaboration vs documentation

sub_topics.name: Scrum Framework
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Scrum roles (product owner, scrum master, team), events (sprints, standups, reviews, retrospectives), and artifacts.
example_tasks: Explain Scrum roles: product owner (priorities), scrum master (facilitator), development team (implementation)
Participate in Scrum events: sprint planning (select work), daily standup (coordinate), review (demo), retrospective (improve)
Manage Scrum artifacts: product backlog (all work), sprint backlog (sprint work), increment (working software)

sub_topics.name: User Stories and Acceptance Criteria
sub_topics.short_description: Writing user stories from user perspective, defining acceptance criteria, estimating story points.
example_tasks: Write user story: 'As a [role], I want [feature] so that [benefit]' - e.g., 'As a student, I want to view my grades so that I can track my progress'
Define acceptance criteria: specific, testable conditions that must be met for story to be complete
Estimate stories: use story points or t-shirt sizes to estimate relative effort, use planning poker for team estimation

sub_topics.name: Sprints and Sprint Planning
sub_topics.short_description: Planning and executing time-boxed iterations, selecting work for sprint, delivering working increment.
example_tasks: Plan sprint: select user stories from backlog that can be completed in sprint (typically 2 weeks)
Execute sprint: daily standup coordination, track progress on sprint board, adjust as needed
Deliver increment: demo working features at sprint review, deploy to production or staging environment

sub_topics.name: Advanced Git and Collaboration
sub_topics.short_description: Using Git for team collaboration, branching strategies, pull requests, code review, and managing merge conflicts.

sub_topics.name: Git Branching Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Using branches for features, understanding Git Flow, creating and merging branches effectively.
example_tasks: Create feature branch: git checkout -b feature/user-login, develop in isolation from main branch
Understand Git Flow: main (production), develop (integration), feature branches, release branches, hotfix branches
Merge strategies: use merge commits for features, rebase for clean history, squash commits before merging

sub_topics.name: Pull Requests and Code Review
sub_topics.short_description: Creating pull requests on GitHub, conducting code reviews, providing constructive feedback.
example_tasks: Create pull request: push branch to GitHub, create PR with description, link to related issues
Review code: check for correctness, readability, tests, documentation, suggest improvements constructively
Respond to review: make requested changes, explain decisions, discuss alternative approaches, update PR

sub_topics.name: Handling Merge Conflicts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why conflicts occur, resolving conflicts manually, using merge tools, preventing conflicts.
example_tasks: Resolve merge conflict: identify conflict markers, choose which changes to keep, test resolution, commit
Use merge tool: configure and use visual merge tool to resolve conflicts more easily
Prevent conflicts: pull frequently, communicate with team, work on different files, keep branches short-lived

sub_topics.name: Team Git Workflows
sub_topics.short_description: Establishing team conventions for commits, branches, and collaboration using Git effectively.
