example_tasks: Write good commit messages: short summary line, detailed description if needed, reference issue numbers
Follow commit conventions: atomic commits (one logical change), meaningful messages, commit frequently
Coordinate with team: communicate before major changes, agree on branching strategy, document workflow

sub_topics.name: Testing Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding testing pyramid, unit tests, integration tests, writing testable code, test-driven development.

sub_topics.name: Testing Pyramid
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different test levels: unit tests (many), integration tests (some), end-to-end tests (few).
example_tasks: Explain testing pyramid: many fast unit tests at base, fewer integration tests in middle, few slow E2E tests at top
Balance test types: unit tests for logic, integration tests for component interaction, E2E tests for critical user paths
Understand tradeoffs: unit tests fast but don't catch integration issues, E2E tests thorough but slow and brittle

sub_topics.name: Unit Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Writing unit tests for functions and classes, using testing frameworks like unittest or pytest, testing in isolation.
example_tasks: Write unit test with pytest: def test_add(): assert add(2, 3) == 5, test one function in isolation
Use test fixtures: set up test data before test, clean up after, share setup across multiple tests
Test edge cases: empty input, null values, boundary conditions, invalid input, not just happy path

sub_topics.name: Integration Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Testing how components work together, testing database integration, API integration, module interaction.
example_tasks: Test database integration: verify data correctly saved and retrieved, test query logic, use test database
Test API integration: verify correct HTTP requests sent, responses parsed correctly, errors handled
Test module interaction: verify modules communicate correctly, data passed properly between components

sub_topics.name: Test-Driven Development (TDD)
sub_topics.short_description: Writing tests before code following red-green-refactor cycle, using TDD to drive design.
example_tasks: Follow TDD cycle: write failing test (red), write minimal code to pass (green), improve code quality (refactor)
Practice TDD: write test for feature that doesn't exist yet, implement feature to make test pass, refactor
Understand TDD benefits: ensures testable design, provides documentation, catches bugs early, builds confidence

sub_topics.name: Code Quality and Best Practices
sub_topics.short_description: Writing clean, maintainable code following best practices, code smells, refactoring, and code standards.

sub_topics.name: Clean Code Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Writing readable, self-documenting code with meaningful names, small functions, and clear intent.
example_tasks: Apply naming principles: use descriptive names, avoid abbreviations, names should reveal intent (getUserByEmail vs getUBE)
Keep functions small: each function does one thing, extract complex logic into well-named helper functions
Write self-documenting code: code so clear that comments unnecessary, use comments only for why not what

sub_topics.name: Identifying Code Smells
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing signs of poor code quality: long methods, duplicated code, large classes, and addressing them.
example_tasks: Identify common code smells: duplicated code, long methods (> 20 lines), large classes (> 500 lines), too many parameters
Recognize design smells: tight coupling, low cohesion, violation of SOLID principles
Prioritize refactoring: not all smells critical, focus on code that changes frequently or causes bugs

sub_topics.name: Refactoring Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Improving code structure without changing behavior, common refactoring patterns, refactoring safely with tests.
example_tasks: Extract method: take complex code block and move to well-named method to improve readability
Extract variable: replace complex expression with variable with descriptive name: is_valid_age = 0 <= age <= 120
Refactor safely: ensure tests pass before refactoring, make small changes, test after each change

sub_topics.name: Coding Standards and Style Guides
sub_topics.short_description: Following language-specific style guides (PEP 8 for Python), using linters, maintaining consistency.
example_tasks: Follow PEP 8: 4-space indentation, snake_case for variables/functions, line length < 79 characters, proper spacing
Use linter: configure pylint or flake8 to check code style automatically, fix warnings
Establish team standards: agree on style guide, automate checking with CI, use code formatters like Black

sub_topics.name: Project Management Tools
sub_topics.short_description: Using tools for tracking issues, managing tasks, documentation, and coordinating team work.

sub_topics.name: Issue Tracking
sub_topics.short_description: Using GitHub Issues or similar tools to track bugs, features, and tasks.
example_tasks: Create informative issues: clear title, detailed description, steps to reproduce (bugs), acceptance criteria (features)
Use labels and milestones: categorize issues (bug, feature, documentation), group into releases/sprints
Link issues to code: reference issue numbers in commits and PRs, close issues automatically with keywords

sub_topics.name: Project Boards and Kanban
sub_topics.short_description: Visualizing work with Kanban boards, tracking progress, managing workflow.
example_tasks: Create project board: columns for To Do, In Progress, In Review, Done
Track work: move issues/cards across board as work progresses, visualize bottlenecks
Use board metrics: track cycle time, work in progress limits, identify process improvements

sub_topics.name: Project Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and maintaining project documentation: README, architecture docs, API docs, user guides.
example_tasks: Write comprehensive README: project description, installation, usage, contributing guidelines, license
Document architecture: high-level design, component diagrams, technology decisions, deployment architecture
Maintain wiki: development setup, troubleshooting, coding standards, meeting notes

grade_11_12.name: Cybersecurity & Network Security
grade_11_12.short_description: Advanced security concepts including encryption, authentication, network security protocols, ethical hacking basics, security best practices, and understanding common vulnerabilities.

sub_topics.name: Cryptography Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding encryption and decryption, symmetric and asymmetric cryptography, hashing, and cryptographic applications.

sub_topics.name: Symmetric Encryption
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding symmetric key cryptography where same key used for encryption and decryption (AES, DES).
example_tasks: Explain symmetric encryption: same key encrypts and decrypts, fast but requires secure key distribution
Implement simple Caesar cipher: shift each letter by n positions as basic encryption example
Understand AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): modern symmetric algorithm, 128/192/256-bit keys, used for bulk data encryption

sub_topics.name: Asymmetric Encryption
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding public-key cryptography with key pairs, RSA algorithm, and how asymmetric encryption enables secure communication.
example_tasks: Explain public/private key pairs: public key encrypts, only corresponding private key can decrypt
Understand RSA application: encrypt with recipient's public key, recipient decrypts with their private key
Compare symmetric vs asymmetric: symmetric is faster, asymmetric solves key distribution problem but slower

sub_topics.name: Cryptographic Hashing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding hash functions (SHA-256, MD5), properties of good hash functions, and using hashing for integrity and passwords.
example_tasks: Explain hash function properties: deterministic, fixed output size, one-way (can't reverse), avalanche effect (small change = different hash)
Hash passwords: use bcrypt or similar with salt to prevent rainbow table attacks, never store plain text passwords
Verify file integrity: compute hash before and after transfer, compare hashes to detect tampering or corruption

sub_topics.name: Digital Signatures and Certificates
sub_topics.short_description: Using cryptography to verify authenticity and integrity, understanding digital certificates and PKI.
example_tasks: Explain digital signatures: hash message, encrypt hash with private key, recipient verifies with public key
Understand SSL/TLS certificates: server proves identity, enables encrypted HTTPS connections, certificate authorities provide trust
Verify digital signature: compute hash of message, decrypt signature with sender's public key, compare hashes

sub_topics.name: Authentication and Authorization
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing secure authentication systems, multi-factor authentication, session management, role-based access control.

sub_topics.name: Secure Password Storage
sub_topics.short_description: Hashing and salting passwords, understanding password strength requirements, preventing common password attacks.
example_tasks: Implement password hashing: use bcrypt with salt, never store plain text: hashed_pw = bcrypt.hashpw(password.encode(), bcrypt.gensalt())
Enforce password policies: minimum length, complexity requirements (uppercase, numbers, symbols), prevent common passwords
Understand attack vectors: brute force, dictionary attacks, rainbow tables, credential stuffing

sub_topics.name: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing authentication with multiple factors: something you know, have, and are.
example_tasks: Explain authentication factors: knowledge (password), possession (phone/token), inherence (biometrics)
Implement 2FA: send code to user's phone/email after password, verify code before granting access
Understand MFA benefits: even if password compromised, attacker needs second factor to gain access

sub_topics.name: Session Management
sub_topics.short_description: Managing user sessions securely, using secure session tokens, preventing session hijacking and fixation.
example_tasks: Generate secure session tokens: use cryptographically random tokens, sufficient length to prevent guessing
Implement session security: use HTTPS, set secure/httpOnly cookie flags, regenerate session ID after login
Handle session expiration: timeout after inactivity, expire after absolute time, clear session on logout

sub_topics.name: Role-Based Access Control
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing authorization systems where users have roles with specific permissions.
example_tasks: Design RBAC system: define roles (admin, teacher, student), assign permissions to roles (create, read, update, delete)
Implement permission checks: verify user has required role/permission before allowing action
Use principle of least privilege: grant minimum permissions needed, deny by default, explicit allow

sub_topics.name: Web Application Security
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding common web vulnerabilities: XSS, CSRF, SQL injection, and implementing protections.

sub_topics.name: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Prevention
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding XSS attacks where malicious scripts injected into web pages, implementing input validation and output encoding.
example_tasks: Identify XSS vulnerability: user input displayed on page without sanitization, attacker injects <script>malicious_code</script>
Prevent XSS: escape HTML special characters before displaying user input, use templating engines that auto-escape
Implement Content Security Policy (CSP): HTTP header that restricts which scripts can execute on page

sub_topics.name: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Prevention
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding CSRF attacks that trick authenticated users into unwanted actions, using CSRF tokens for protection.
example_tasks: Explain CSRF attack: malicious site causes authenticated user's browser to make unwanted request to legitimate site
Implement CSRF tokens: generate unique token for each session, include in forms, validate on server before processing
Use SameSite cookies: set SameSite=Strict or Lax to prevent cookies sent with cross-site requests

sub_topics.name: Injection Attack Prevention
sub_topics.short_description: Preventing SQL injection, command injection, and other injection attacks using parameterized queries and input validation.
example_tasks: Prevent SQL injection: use parameterized queries/prepared statements, never concatenate user input into SQL
Validate input: whitelist validation (allow only expected format), reject suspicious input, sanitize before use
Prevent command injection: avoid executing system commands with user input, use libraries instead of shell commands

sub_topics.name: Security Headers
sub_topics.short_description: Configuring HTTP security headers to protect against common attacks: HSTS, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options.
example_tasks: Set security headers: Strict-Transport-Security (enforce HTTPS), X-Frame-Options (prevent clickjacking), X-Content-Type-Options (prevent MIME sniffing)
Configure CSP header: Content-Security-Policy to control which resources can load from which origins
Test headers: use security scanning tools to verify all recommended headers present and properly configured

sub_topics.name: Advanced Network Security
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding network attacks, firewalls, intrusion detection, VPNs, and securing network communications.

sub_topics.name: Common Network Attacks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding man-in-the-middle, packet sniffing, DDoS, ARP spoofing, and how these attacks work.
example_tasks: Explain MITM attack: attacker intercepts communication between two parties, reads or modifies messages without detection
Understand DDoS attack: overwhelm target with traffic from many sources (botnet), making service unavailable
Describe packet sniffing: capturing network traffic to extract sensitive information sent unencrypted

sub_topics.name: Firewall Configuration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding firewall rules, configuring firewalls to allow/block traffic, creating security zones.
example_tasks: Create firewall rules: allow incoming HTTP/HTTPS (ports 80/443), block all other incoming traffic by default
Implement egress filtering: control outbound traffic, prevent malware from communicating with command servers
Design DMZ (demilitarized zone): place public servers in DMZ between internet and internal network

sub_topics.name: Intrusion Detection and Prevention
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding IDS (monitors for attacks) and IPS (blocks attacks), signature-based vs anomaly-based detection.
example_tasks: Explain IDS operation: monitors network traffic, compares against signatures of known attacks, alerts on suspicious activity
Understand IPS: like IDS but actively blocks detected threats, can prevent attacks in real-time
Compare detection methods: signature-based (known attacks) vs anomaly-based (detects unusual behavior)

sub_topics.name: VPN and Secure Tunneling
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how VPNs encrypt traffic, protocols (IPSec, OpenVPN), using VPNs for remote access and privacy.
example_tasks: Explain VPN operation: creates encrypted tunnel through public network, all traffic encrypted end-to-end
Compare VPN protocols: OpenVPN (open source, flexible), IPSec (industry standard), WireGuard (modern, fast)
Implement VPN use case: secure remote access to company network, encrypt traffic on public WiFi

sub_topics.name: Ethical Hacking Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding penetration testing, reconnaissance, vulnerability scanning, and ethical hacking methodologies.

sub_topics.name: Ethical Hacking Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding difference between ethical hacking and malicious hacking, legal and ethical considerations, authorized testing.
example_tasks: Explain ethical hacking: authorized testing to find vulnerabilities before attackers do, always get written permission
Understand legal boundaries: Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, unauthorized access is illegal even with good intentions
Follow responsible disclosure: report vulnerabilities to organization privately, give time to fix before public disclosure

sub_topics.name: Information Gathering
sub_topics.short_description: Passive and active reconnaissance, using public information, WHOIS, DNS enumeration, port scanning.
example_tasks: Perform passive reconnaissance: gather public information without directly interacting with target (Google, social media, WHOIS)
Use nmap for port scanning: nmap -sV target_ip to identify open ports and running services
Enumerate DNS: use dig or nslookup to find subdomains, mail servers, name servers for target domain

sub_topics.name: Vulnerability Scanning
sub_topics.short_description: Using automated tools to identify known vulnerabilities, understanding CVEs, interpreting scan results.
example_tasks: Run vulnerability scanner: use tools like Nessus or OpenVAS to scan for known vulnerabilities
Interpret scan results: understand severity ratings (critical, high, medium, low), prioritize remediation
Research CVEs: look up Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures, understand impact and available patches

sub_topics.name: Penetration Testing Methodology
sub_topics.short_description: Following structured approach: planning, reconnaissance, scanning, exploitation, reporting.
example_tasks: Plan penetration test: define scope, get authorization, establish rules of engagement, set objectives
Follow testing phases: reconnaissance (gather info), scanning (identify vulnerabilities), exploitation (test vulnerabilities), post-exploitation (assess impact)
Document findings: create detailed report with vulnerabilities found, risk ratings, evidence, remediation recommendations

sub_topics.name: Security Best Practices
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing defense in depth, security by design, incident response, and maintaining security awareness.

sub_topics.name: Defense in Depth
sub_topics.short_description: Using multiple layers of security controls so if one fails, others still protect, avoiding single point of failure.
example_tasks: Implement layered security: firewall, IDS, encryption, authentication, access control, monitoring work together
Design security layers: perimeter (firewall), network (segmentation), host (antivirus), application (input validation), data (encryption)
Understand redundancy: if firewall bypassed, IDS detects intrusion; if password compromised, MFA prevents access

sub_topics.name: Security by Design
sub_topics.short_description: Building security into systems from the beginning rather than adding it later, threat modeling, secure defaults.
example_tasks: Perform threat modeling: identify assets, threats, vulnerabilities during design phase, plan mitigations
Use secure defaults: deny by default (allow only what's needed), fail securely (deny access on error), least privilege
Design for security: minimize attack surface, validate all inputs, encrypt sensitive data, log security events

sub_topics.name: Incident Response
sub_topics.short_description: Preparing for security incidents, detection, containment, eradication, recovery, and lessons learned.
example_tasks: Create incident response plan: define roles, establish communication channels, document procedures for different scenarios
Follow IR phases: preparation, detection, analysis, containment, eradication, recovery, post-incident review
Handle security incident: isolate affected systems, preserve evidence, investigate root cause, restore from clean backups

sub_topics.name: Security Awareness
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that humans are weakest link, training users, recognizing social engineering, security culture.
example_tasks: Identify social engineering tactics: phishing emails, pretexting phone calls, baiting with USB drives, tailgating into buildings
Train users: regular security awareness training, phishing simulations, clear security policies, report suspicious activity
Build security culture: make security everyone's responsibility, reward good practices, learn from incidents without blame

grade_11_12.name: Data Science & Analytics
grade_11_12.short_description: Data analysis with Python, pandas library, data visualization, statistical analysis, and introduction to machine learning concepts.

sub_topics.name: Data Analysis with Pandas
sub_topics.short_description: Using pandas library for data manipulation, DataFrames, Series, reading/writing data, filtering, grouping, and aggregating.

sub_topics.name: DataFrames and Series
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pandas data structures, creating DataFrames and Series, accessing data with indexing.
example_tasks: Create DataFrame from dictionary: df = pd.DataFrame({'name': ['Alice', 'Bob'], 'age': [25, 30], 'city': ['NYC', 'LA']})
Access data: df['name'] for column, df.loc[0] for row by label, df.iloc[0] for row by position
Understand Series: one-dimensional array with index, DataFrame is collection of Series sharing an index

sub_topics.name: Reading and Writing Data
sub_topics.short_description: Loading data from CSV, Excel, JSON, SQL databases and saving processed data to various formats.
example_tasks: Read CSV file: df = pd.read_csv('data.csv'), explore with df.head(), df.info(), df.describe()
Write to different formats: df.to_csv('output.csv'), df.to_excel('output.xlsx'), df.to_json('output.json')
Read from SQL database: df = pd.read_sql('SELECT * FROM table', connection)

sub_topics.name: Data Selection and Filtering
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting columns, filtering rows based on conditions, using boolean indexing and query methods.
example_tasks: Filter rows: df[df['age'] > 25] to get rows where age greater than 25
Multiple conditions: df[(df['age'] > 25) & (df['city'] == 'NYC')] using bitwise operators
Use query method: df.query('age > 25 and city == "NYC"') for more readable filtering

sub_topics.name: GroupBy and Aggregation
sub_topics.short_description: Grouping data by categories, computing aggregate statistics, pivot tables for multi-dimensional analysis.
example_tasks: Group by single column: df.groupby('city')['age'].mean() to get average age by city
Multiple aggregations: df.groupby('city').agg({'age': ['mean', 'min', 'max'], 'salary': 'sum'})
Create pivot table: df.pivot_table(values='salary', index='department', columns='year', aggfunc='mean')

sub_topics.name: Data Cleaning
sub_topics.short_description: Handling missing values, removing duplicates, data type conversion, renaming columns.
example_tasks: Handle missing values: df.dropna() to remove, df.fillna(0) to replace with value, df.fillna(df.mean()) with statistics
Remove duplicates: df.drop_duplicates(subset=['column']) to keep first occurrence of duplicate rows
Convert data types: df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date']), df['price'] = df['price'].astype(float)

sub_topics.name: Data Visualization
sub_topics.short_description: Creating visualizations with matplotlib and seaborn, choosing appropriate chart types, creating informative plots.

sub_topics.name: Matplotlib Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Creating basic plots: line plots, scatter plots, bar charts, histograms using matplotlib.
example_tasks: Create line plot: plt.plot(x, y); plt.xlabel('X'); plt.ylabel('Y'); plt.title('Title'); plt.show()
Create scatter plot: plt.scatter(df['age'], df['salary']), useful for showing correlation between variables
Create histogram: plt.hist(df['age'], bins=20) to show distribution of values

sub_topics.name: Statistical Visualization with Seaborn
sub_topics.short_description: Using seaborn for attractive statistical graphics, exploring relationships, distributions, and categorical data.
example_tasks: Create box plot: sns.boxplot(x='category', y='value', data=df) to show distribution by category
Correlation heatmap: sns.heatmap(df.corr(), annot=True) to visualize correlations between variables
Pair plot: sns.pairplot(df, hue='category') to explore relationships between all numeric variables

sub_topics.name: Choosing Appropriate Visualizations
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting right chart type for data: trends (line), distribution (histogram), comparison (bar), correlation (scatter).
example_tasks: Choose chart for time series: line chart to show trends over time, possibly with multiple lines for comparison
Show composition: pie chart or stacked bar for parts of whole, tree map for hierarchical data
Compare categories: bar chart for comparing values across categories, grouped bar for multiple variables

sub_topics.name: Customizing Plots
sub_topics.short_description: Adding titles, labels, legends, colors, adjusting figure size, creating subplots for multiple visualizations.
example_tasks: Customize appearance: set colors, line styles, markers, adjust figure size with plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
Add annotations: plt.annotate('Note', xy=(x,y), xytext=(x2,y2), arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle='->')) to highlight points
Create subplots: fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12,10)) to show multiple related plots together

sub_topics.name: Statistical Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding descriptive statistics, measures of central tendency and spread, correlation, basic probability concepts.

sub_topics.name: Descriptive Statistics
sub_topics.short_description: Computing mean, median, mode, standard deviation, quartiles, and understanding what they reveal about data.
example_tasks: Calculate central tendency: mean = df['age'].mean(), median = df['age'].median(), mode = df['age'].mode()
Measure spread: std = df['age'].std() for standard deviation, var = df['age'].var() for variance
Compute quartiles: df['age'].quantile([0.25, 0.5, 0.75]) to understand distribution

sub_topics.name: Correlation Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring relationships between variables using correlation coefficients, understanding causation vs correlation.
example_tasks: Calculate correlation: df.corr() to get correlation matrix, df['age'].corr(df['salary']) for two variables
Interpret correlation: -1 to 1 scale, close to 1 (strong positive), close to -1 (strong negative), near 0 (weak)
Understand limitations: correlation doesn't imply causation, outliers can affect correlation, only measures linear relationships

sub_topics.name: Data Distributions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding normal distribution, skewness, outliers, and visualizing distributions with histograms and box plots.
example_tasks: Identify distribution shape: use histogram to check if data normally distributed, skewed left/right, or multimodal
Detect outliers: use box plot to identify outliers (points beyond 1.5 * IQR from quartiles)
Calculate skewness: df['column'].skew() to measure asymmetry, 0 is symmetric, >0 right-skewed, <0 left-skewed

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Hypothesis Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding basic hypothesis testing concepts, null hypothesis, p-values, statistical significance.
example_tasks: Understand hypothesis testing: null hypothesis (no effect), alternative hypothesis (there is effect), use data to decide
Interpret p-value: probability of observing data if null hypothesis true, p < 0.05 typically considered significant
Perform t-test: from scipy import stats; stats.ttest_ind(group1, group2) to compare means of two groups

sub_topics.name: Data Preprocessing
sub_topics.short_description: Preparing data for analysis: handling missing values, outliers, normalization, encoding categorical variables, feature engineering.

sub_topics.name: Handling Missing Data
sub_topics.short_description: Strategies for dealing with missing values: deletion, imputation with mean/median/mode, forward/backward fill.
example_tasks: Analyze missing data: df.isnull().sum() to count missing values per column, visualize with heatmap
Impute with statistics: df['age'].fillna(df['age'].mean()) for numeric, df['category'].fillna(df['category'].mode()[0]) for categorical
Time series imputation: df.fillna(method='ffill') for forward fill, df.fillna(method='bfill') for backward fill

sub_topics.name: Outlier Detection and Treatment
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying outliers using statistical methods, deciding whether to remove, cap, or keep outliers.
example_tasks: Detect outliers with IQR: Q1 = df['value'].quantile(0.25); Q3 = df['value'].quantile(0.75); outliers = df[(df['value'] < Q1-1.5*IQR) | (df['value'] > Q3+1.5*IQR)]
Use z-score: outliers more than 3 standard deviations from mean
Cap outliers: replace extreme values with percentile values rather than removing to preserve data size

sub_topics.name: Normalization and Scaling
sub_topics.short_description: Scaling features to similar ranges using min-max normalization or standardization for machine learning.
example_tasks: Min-max scaling: from sklearn.preprocessing import MinMaxScaler; scaler = MinMaxScaler(); df_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(df) scales to [0,1]
Standardization: from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler; scaler = StandardScaler(); df_standardized = scaler.fit_transform(df) to mean=0, std=1
Understand when to scale: required for algorithms sensitive to feature magnitude (KNN, neural networks), not needed for tree-based models

sub_topics.name: Encoding Categorical Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Converting categorical data to numeric format using one-hot encoding, label encoding, ordinal encoding.
example_tasks: One-hot encoding: pd.get_dummies(df['category']) creates binary columns for each category value
Label encoding: from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder; encoder = LabelEncoder(); df['category_encoded'] = encoder.fit_transform(df['category'])
Choose encoding: one-hot for nominal (no order), label/ordinal for ordinal data (low, medium, high)

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding machine learning concepts, supervised vs unsupervised learning, training and testing models, basic algorithms.

sub_topics.name: Machine Learning Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what machine learning is, types of ML (supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement), ML workflow.
example_tasks: Explain supervised learning: algorithm learns from labeled examples (input-output pairs) to predict outputs for new inputs
Explain unsupervised learning: algorithm finds patterns in unlabeled data, clustering similar items, dimensionality reduction
Understand ML workflow: collect data, preprocess, split train/test, train model, evaluate, tune, deploy

sub_topics.name: Training and Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Splitting data into training and testing sets, understanding overfitting and underfitting, cross-validation.
example_tasks: Split data: from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split; X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2)
Understand overfitting: model performs well on training data but poorly on test data, too complex for data
Use cross-validation: from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score to evaluate model on multiple train/test splits

sub_topics.name: Linear Regression
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and implementing linear regression for predicting continuous values, interpreting coefficients.
example_tasks: Train linear regression: from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression; model = LinearRegression(); model.fit(X_train, y_train)
Make predictions: predictions = model.predict(X_test) to predict values for test data
Evaluate model: from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score; calculate MSE and R² to assess performance

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Classification
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding classification problems, logistic regression, decision trees, evaluating with accuracy and confusion matrix.
example_tasks: Train logistic regression: from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression; model = LogisticRegression(); model.fit(X_train, y_train)
Evaluate classification: from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, confusion_matrix; calculate accuracy and examine confusion matrix
Understand decision trees: from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier; model = DecisionTreeClassifier(); visualize decision boundaries

sub_topics.name: Clustering with K-Means
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to unsupervised learning, K-means clustering algorithm, choosing number of clusters.
example_tasks: Apply K-means: from sklearn.cluster import KMeans; kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=3); clusters = kmeans.fit_predict(X)
Visualize clusters: plot data points colored by cluster assignment, show cluster centers
Choose K: use elbow method plotting inertia vs number of clusters to find optimal K

sub_topics.name: Data Ethics and Privacy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ethical considerations in data collection and use, privacy concerns, bias in data and algorithms.

sub_topics.name: Ethical Data Collection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding informed consent, transparency, data minimization, and responsible data collection practices.
example_tasks: Apply data minimization: collect only data necessary for specific purpose, avoid collecting sensitive data unnecessarily
Ensure informed consent: clearly explain what data collected, how used, allow opt-out, respect user preferences
Practice transparency: be clear about data collection, processing, and use, provide privacy policies

sub_topics.name: Privacy Protection
sub_topics.short_description: Anonymization, de-identification, differential privacy concepts, complying with privacy regulations (GDPR, CCPA).
example_tasks: Anonymize data: remove personally identifiable information (names, IDs, addresses) before analysis or sharing
Understand re-identification risk: even anonymized data can sometimes be re-identified by combining with other datasets
Apply k-anonymity: ensure each record indistinguishable from at least k-1 other records for sensitive attributes

sub_topics.name: Bias in Data and Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how bias enters data and algorithms, detecting bias, strategies for creating fair ML systems.
example_tasks: Identify bias sources: biased training data, biased feature selection, biased algorithm design, feedback loops
Detect bias: examine model performance across different demographic groups, check for disparate impact
Mitigate bias: collect representative data, use fairness metrics, audit algorithms regularly, diverse development teams

sub_topics.name: Responsible AI Use
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding societal impact of AI/ML, accountability, explainability, and developing AI ethically.
example_tasks: Consider societal impact: who benefits, who might be harmed, unintended consequences, exacerbating inequalities
Ensure accountability: clearly define who responsible for AI decisions, have human oversight for high-stakes decisions
Prioritize explainability: use interpretable models when possible, explain how model makes decisions, avoid black boxes for critical applications

grade_11_12.name: Mobile Application Development
grade_11_12.short_description: Introduction to mobile platforms, understanding mobile UI/UX design, building basic mobile applications, responsive design principles.

sub_topics.name: Mobile Platforms Overview
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding iOS and Android platforms, platform differences, native vs cross-platform development.

sub_topics.name: iOS vs Android
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing iOS and Android ecosystems, development tools, languages, and market considerations.
example_tasks: Compare platforms: iOS (Swift/Objective-C, Xcode, App Store) vs Android (Kotlin/Java, Android Studio, Google Play)
Understand market differences: iOS users higher spending, Android larger market share, geographic distributions
Identify platform-specific features: iOS (Face ID, AirDrop) vs Android (widgets, customization, file system access)

sub_topics.name: Native vs Cross-Platform Development
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing native development vs cross-platform frameworks (React Native, Flutter), tradeoffs in performance and development speed.
example_tasks: Compare approaches: native (best performance, platform-specific), cross-platform (code sharing, faster development)
Evaluate frameworks: React Native (JavaScript), Flutter (Dart), Xamarin (C#) for building cross-platform apps
Choose approach: native for performance-critical or platform-specific, cross-platform for business apps, rapid prototyping

sub_topics.name: Setting Up Development Environment
sub_topics.short_description: Installing and configuring development tools, emulators, testing on devices.
example_tasks: Set up Android development: install Android Studio, configure SDK, create virtual devices (AVD) for testing
Configure iOS development: install Xcode (Mac required), set up simulator, register as Apple Developer
Test on real devices: enable developer mode, connect device, deploy app for testing on actual hardware

sub_topics.name: Mobile UI/UX Design
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding mobile design principles, touch interfaces, navigation patterns, responsive layouts for different screen sizes.

sub_topics.name: Mobile Design Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Designing for small screens, touch targets, thumb zones, minimizing clutter, mobile-first thinking.
example_tasks: Design touch-friendly UI: minimum 44x44 pixels for tap targets, spacing between interactive elements, large buttons
Consider thumb zones: place important actions in easy-to-reach areas, avoid top corners on large phones
Minimize cognitive load: one primary action per screen, progressive disclosure, clear visual hierarchy

sub_topics.name: Mobile Navigation Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding common mobile navigation: tab bars, navigation drawers, bottom sheets, back buttons.
example_tasks: Implement tab bar: iOS-style tabs at bottom for main sections (4-5 items), current tab highlighted
Use navigation drawer: Android-style hamburger menu for additional options, primary navigation still visible
Design navigation flow: minimize depth, provide clear back navigation, use breadcrumbs for complex hierarchies

sub_topics.name: Responsive Layouts
sub_topics.short_description: Creating layouts that adapt to different screen sizes and orientations, using flexible grids and constraints.
example_tasks: Use constraint-based layouts: define relationships between UI elements that adapt to different screens
Handle orientation changes: design both portrait and landscape layouts, test rotation behavior
Support multiple screen sizes: test on small phones, large phones, tablets, use relative sizes not fixed pixels

sub_topics.name: Platform Design Guidelines
sub_topics.short_description: Following iOS Human Interface Guidelines and Material Design for Android, maintaining platform conventions.
example_tasks: Apply Material Design: use elevation, ripple effects, floating action buttons, material icons on Android apps
Follow iOS guidelines: use standard navigation bars, tab bars, system fonts, iOS-style controls
Respect platform conventions: back button behavior, share sheets, notifications style appropriate for platform

sub_topics.name: Building Basic Mobile Apps
sub_topics.short_description: Creating simple mobile applications with UI components, handling user input, navigation between screens.

sub_topics.name: UI Components
sub_topics.short_description: Using common UI elements: buttons, text fields, labels, images, lists, understanding component lifecycle.
example_tasks: Create basic UI: add buttons, text fields, labels, images using interface builder or declarative UI
Handle button clicks: set up event handlers/listeners to respond to user interactions
Display lists: implement scrollable lists (RecyclerView on Android, UITableView on iOS) showing dynamic data

sub_topics.name: Navigation Between Screens
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing navigation between multiple screens, passing data between screens, navigation stacks.
example_tasks: Navigate to new screen: use navigation controller to push/present new view controller or activity
Pass data between screens: send data when navigating, receive in destination screen, display or process
Implement back navigation: handle back button press, pop from navigation stack, pass data back to previous screen

sub_topics.name: Handling User Input
sub_topics.short_description: Getting input from text fields, validating input, showing alerts and dialogs, keyboard management.
example_tasks: Get text input: read values from text fields when button clicked, validate format (email, phone number)
Show alerts: display alert dialogs for confirmations, errors, information, handle user response
Manage keyboard: dismiss keyboard when done, avoid keyboard covering input fields, handle keyboard showing/hiding

sub_topics.name: Local Data Storage
sub_topics.short_description: Storing data locally using UserDefaults/SharedPreferences, file storage, introduction to local databases.
example_tasks: Store preferences: save user settings using UserDefaults (iOS) or SharedPreferences (Android)
Save to files: write data to local files, read back when app launches, handle file paths correctly
Use local database: introduction to SQLite or Core Data for structured data storage on device

sub_topics.name: Common Mobile App Features
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing common features: camera access, location services, notifications, working with device sensors.

sub_topics.name: Camera and Photo Library
sub_topics.short_description: Accessing device camera, taking photos, selecting from photo library, displaying images in app.
example_tasks: Request camera permission: ask user for camera access, handle permission denied case
Take photo: launch camera, capture image, receive image data in app, display or save
Access photo library: let user select existing photos, handle multiple selection, get image data

sub_topics.name: Location Services
sub_topics.short_description: Getting device location, requesting location permissions, displaying location on map, geofencing basics.
example_tasks: Request location permission: ask for location access (when in use or always), explain why needed
Get current location: access GPS coordinates, handle location updates, display latitude/longitude
Display on map: integrate map view (Google Maps or Apple Maps), show user location, add markers

sub_topics.name: Push and Local Notifications
sub_topics.short_description: Sending local notifications, understanding push notification basics, notification permissions.
example_tasks: Schedule local notification: set notification to trigger at specific time, include title and message
Request notification permission: ask user for permission to send notifications, handle permission states
Understand push notifications: server sends to device via APNs (iOS) or FCM (Android), app receives and displays

sub_topics.name: Device Sensors
sub_topics.short_description: Accessing accelerometer, gyroscope, and other sensors, using sensor data in applications.
example_tasks: Access accelerometer: detect device movement, shake detection, tilt detection for games or utilities
Use gyroscope: measure rotation, orientation changes, enhance motion-based features
Apply sensors: create step counter, compass, level tool, or motion-controlled game features

sub_topics.name: App Publishing Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding app store submission process, app icons, screenshots, descriptions, versioning.

sub_topics.name: Preparing App for Release
sub_topics.short_description: Creating app icons, splash screens, configuring app metadata, testing on multiple devices.
example_tasks: Create app icon: design icon in multiple sizes for different devices and contexts (home screen, settings, notifications)
Configure app metadata: set app name, bundle identifier, version number, required device capabilities
Test thoroughly: test on different devices, screen sizes, OS versions, fix bugs before submission

sub_topics.name: App Store Requirements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding App Store and Google Play requirements, review guidelines, preparing screenshots and descriptions.
example_tasks: Review guidelines: understand prohibited content, technical requirements, design requirements for each platform
Prepare store listing: write compelling description, create screenshots showing key features, prepare promotional graphics
Set up developer account: register as developer (Apple Developer Program, Google Play Console), pay fees

sub_topics.name: App Submission Process
sub_topics.short_description: Submitting app for review, responding to reviewer feedback, updating published apps.
example_tasks: Submit for review: upload app binary, provide required information, submit for App Store or Play Store review
Handle rejections: read reviewer feedback, fix issues, resubmit with changes and explanation
Update published app: increment version number, document changes, submit update through same process

grade_11_12.name: Cloud Computing & Distributed Systems
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding cloud service models, deploying applications to cloud, serverless computing, distributed system concepts, scalability and reliability.

sub_topics.name: Cloud Computing Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cloud service models (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS), deployment models, benefits and challenges of cloud computing.

sub_topics.name: Cloud Service Models
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding IaaS (Infrastructure), PaaS (Platform), SaaS (Software) service models and when to use each.
example_tasks: Explain IaaS: rent virtual machines, storage, networks (AWS EC2, Azure VMs), manage OS and applications yourself
Explain PaaS: platform manages infrastructure, you deploy applications (Heroku, Google App Engine), focus on code
Explain SaaS: fully managed applications (Gmail, Salesforce), just use the service, no infrastructure management

sub_topics.name: Cloud Deployment Models
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding public cloud, private cloud, hybrid cloud, and community cloud deployment models.
example_tasks: Compare deployment models: public (shared infrastructure), private (dedicated), hybrid (combination), community (shared by group)
Identify use cases: public for startups (cost-effective), private for sensitive data (control), hybrid for enterprises (flexibility)
Understand tradeoffs: public (cheap, less control), private (expensive, more control), hybrid (complex, balanced)

sub_topics.name: Benefits and Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding advantages of cloud computing and potential challenges like vendor lock-in and data security.
example_tasks: Identify benefits: pay-as-you-go pricing, scalability, global reach, reduced capital expenses, managed services
Understand challenges: vendor lock-in, data security/privacy concerns, compliance requirements, internet dependency
Calculate cost-benefit: compare cloud vs on-premise costs including infrastructure, personnel, electricity, space

sub_topics.name: Deploying to Cloud Platforms
sub_topics.short_description: Deploying applications to cloud platforms (AWS, Heroku, Google Cloud), using cloud services, managing deployments.

sub_topics.name: Deploying Web Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Deploying web applications to platforms like Heroku, Netlify, or AWS, configuring environment variables, domains.
example_tasks: Deploy to Heroku: create app, push code with git, configure buildpacks, set environment variables, access deployed app
Deploy static site: use Netlify or GitHub Pages for static websites, configure custom domain, enable HTTPS
Deploy to AWS: use Elastic Beanstalk for easy deployment or EC2 for more control, configure security groups

sub_topics.name: Cloud Databases
sub_topics.short_description: Using managed database services (AWS RDS, Cloud SQL), understanding benefits of managed vs self-hosted databases.
example_tasks: Set up managed database: create RDS instance (PostgreSQL, MySQL), configure security, connect from application
Understand managed benefits: automatic backups, patching, scaling, high availability without manual management
Compare options: managed database (easy, more expensive) vs database on VM (more control, more work)

sub_topics.name: Static Site Hosting
sub_topics.short_description: Hosting static websites on S3, Netlify, or GitHub Pages, understanding CDN benefits for static content.
example_tasks: Host on S3: upload static files to S3 bucket, configure for static website hosting, set bucket policy for public access
Use CDN: configure CloudFront or similar CDN to cache and serve content from edge locations worldwide
Optimize delivery: enable compression, set cache headers, minimize file sizes for faster loading

sub_topics.name: Continuous Integration/Deployment
sub_topics.short_description: Setting up CI/CD pipelines to automatically test and deploy code changes to cloud platforms.
example_tasks: Set up GitHub Actions: create workflow that runs tests on push, deploys to production on merge to main branch
Configure deployment pipeline: build → test → deploy, automatic rollback if deployment fails
Understand benefits: faster releases, fewer manual errors, consistent deployments, quick feedback on code changes

sub_topics.name: Serverless Computing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding serverless architecture, AWS Lambda, cloud functions, event-driven computing, use cases and limitations.

sub_topics.name: Serverless Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what serverless means, function-as-a-service, event-driven architecture, when to use serverless.
example_tasks: Explain serverless: cloud provider manages servers, you write functions that execute in response to events
Understand pricing: pay only for execution time and resources used, no charge when idle, can be very cost-effective
Identify use cases: APIs, data processing, scheduled tasks, webhooks, image processing, chatbots

sub_topics.name: AWS Lambda Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and deploying serverless functions with AWS Lambda, triggering functions with events.
example_tasks: Create Lambda function: write function code, configure runtime (Python, Node.js), set memory and timeout
Trigger with events: HTTP requests (API Gateway), file uploads (S3), database changes (DynamoDB), scheduled (CloudWatch)
Handle function input: receive event data, process, return response or store results

sub_topics.name: Serverless Limitations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cold starts, execution time limits, statelessness, and when serverless isn't appropriate.
example_tasks: Understand cold starts: first invocation slow while container initializes, optimize by keeping functions warm
Work within limits: maximum execution time (AWS Lambda: 15 minutes), memory limits, payload size limits
Recognize when not to use: long-running processes, stateful applications, predictable high load (traditional servers cheaper)

sub_topics.name: Distributed Systems Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding distributed system concepts, microservices, scaling strategies, CAP theorem introduction.

sub_topics.name: Microservices Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding breaking applications into small, independent services that communicate via APIs.
example_tasks: Compare monolith vs microservices: single codebase vs multiple services, scaling entire app vs scaling services independently
Design microservices: separate by business domain (users, products, orders), each service has own database
Understand benefits: independent deployment, technology diversity, fault isolation, easier scaling

sub_topics.name: Scaling Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding horizontal scaling (adding more servers) vs vertical scaling (bigger servers), load balancing.
example_tasks: Compare scaling approaches: vertical (upgrade server hardware, limited by single machine) vs horizontal (add more servers, nearly unlimited)
Implement load balancing: distribute requests across multiple servers, use load balancer (nginx, AWS ELB)
Design for horizontal scaling: stateless services, externalize session storage, use distributed databases

sub_topics.name: CAP Theorem Introduction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance tradeoffs in distributed systems.
example_tasks: Explain CAP: Consistency (all nodes see same data), Availability (system always responds), Partition tolerance (works despite network issues)
Understand tradeoff: can only guarantee 2 of 3, network partitions happen so choose between consistency and availability
Apply CAP: banking (choose consistency), social media (choose availability), design systems based on requirements

sub_topics.name: Data Replication and Consistency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding data replication across servers, eventual consistency, strong consistency tradeoffs.
example_tasks: Explain replication: copy data to multiple servers for availability and performance
Understand consistency models: strong (all replicas immediately consistent), eventual (replicas become consistent over time)
Apply replication: replicate database across regions for disaster recovery, use read replicas to distribute query load

grade_11_12.name: Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning Basics
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding AI concepts, neural networks introduction, ethical considerations in AI, exploring AI applications, and responsible AI development.

sub_topics.name: AI Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what AI is, types of AI, narrow vs general AI, AI history and current applications.

sub_topics.name: What is Artificial Intelligence
sub_topics.short_description: Defining AI, understanding different approaches (symbolic AI, machine learning, deep learning), AI vs human intelligence.
example_tasks: Define AI: systems that can perform tasks requiring human intelligence - learning, reasoning, perception, language understanding
Compare approaches: rule-based systems (expert systems), machine learning (learning from data), deep learning (neural networks)
Distinguish narrow vs general AI: narrow AI excels at specific tasks (chess, image recognition), general AI (not yet achieved) would match human intelligence across domains

sub_topics.name: Brief History of AI
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding AI development from early programs to modern deep learning, AI winters and recent progress.
example_tasks: Trace AI milestones: Turing Test (1950), expert systems (1970s-80s), IBM Deep Blue (1997), AlphaGo (2016), GPT/ChatGPT (2020s)
Understand AI winters: periods of reduced funding and interest when AI failed to meet expectations
Identify recent breakthroughs: deep learning revolution, image recognition, natural language processing, game playing

sub_topics.name: AI Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring current AI applications in healthcare, transportation, education, entertainment, and daily life.
example_tasks: Identify AI in daily life: recommendation systems (Netflix, Spotify), virtual assistants (Siri, Alexa), spam filters, autocomplete
Explore domain applications: medical diagnosis, autonomous vehicles, personalized education, fraud detection, language translation
Understand AI impact: improving efficiency, enabling new capabilities, but also raising concerns about jobs, privacy, bias

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Neural Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding biological inspiration, artificial neurons, layers, activation functions, basic neural network architecture.

sub_topics.name: Artificial Neurons
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding neuron model: weighted inputs, sum, activation function, inspired by biological neurons.
example_tasks: Explain artificial neuron: receives multiple inputs, multiplies each by weight, sums weighted inputs, applies activation function
Compare to biological neuron: dendrites (inputs), cell body (processing), axon (output), inspired by but simplified from biology
Implement simple neuron: calculate weighted sum of inputs, apply activation function (sigmoid, ReLU) to produce output

sub_topics.name: Neural Network Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding layers (input, hidden, output), connections between neurons, feedforward networks.
example_tasks: Design network structure: input layer (features), hidden layer(s) (processing), output layer (predictions)
Understand connections: each neuron in layer connects to all neurons in next layer (fully connected)
Count parameters: calculate total weights and biases in network based on layer sizes

sub_topics.name: Activation Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sigmoid, ReLU, tanh activation functions and why non-linearity is important.
example_tasks: Explain activation functions: introduce non-linearity allowing networks to learn complex patterns
Compare functions: sigmoid (0 to 1, good for probabilities), ReLU (faster, avoids vanishing gradient), tanh (-1 to 1)
Understand necessity: without activation functions, network would be just linear transformation regardless of depth

sub_topics.name: Training Neural Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding forward propagation, loss functions, backpropagation concept, gradient descent basics.
example_tasks: Explain forward propagation: pass inputs through network, calculate outputs at each layer, produce final prediction
Understand loss function: measures difference between predictions and actual values (MSE for regression, cross-entropy for classification)
Introduce backpropagation: algorithm that calculates gradients and adjusts weights to minimize loss, enables learning

sub_topics.name: Deep Learning Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding deep neural networks, convolutional networks for images, recurrent networks for sequences, applications of deep learning.

sub_topics.name: Deep Neural Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding networks with many layers, why depth matters, challenges of training deep networks.
example_tasks: Explain deep learning: neural networks with multiple hidden layers can learn hierarchical representations
Understand depth benefits: early layers learn simple features (edges), deeper layers combine into complex features (faces)
Identify challenges: vanishing gradients in deep networks, requires more data and computation, techniques like dropout prevent overfitting

sub_topics.name: Convolutional Neural Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding CNNs for image processing, convolutional layers, pooling, applications in computer vision.
example_tasks: Explain CNNs: specialized for processing grid-like data (images), use convolution to detect features like edges, textures
Understand convolution: apply filters/kernels that slide across image detecting specific patterns
Identify applications: image classification, object detection, facial recognition, medical image analysis

sub_topics.name: Recurrent Neural Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding RNNs for sequential data, maintaining state, applications in language and time series.
example_tasks: Explain RNNs: networks with loops allowing information to persist, process sequences of varying length
Understand applications: language modeling, translation, speech recognition, time series prediction
Identify limitation: struggle with long sequences, led to LSTM and transformer architectures

sub_topics.name: Transfer Learning
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding using pre-trained models, fine-tuning for specific tasks, why transfer learning is powerful.
example_tasks: Explain transfer learning: use model pre-trained on large dataset, adapt for specific task with less data
Apply transfer learning: start with ImageNet-trained model, fine-tune last layers for specific image classification task
Understand benefits: requires less training data, faster training, often better performance than training from scratch

sub_topics.name: Natural Language Processing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how computers process language, text preprocessing, sentiment analysis, language models, chatbots.

sub_topics.name: Text Preprocessing
sub_topics.short_description: Tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, removing stop words, preparing text for ML models.
example_tasks: Tokenize text: split text into words or subwords, handle punctuation: 'Hello, world!' → ['Hello', ',', 'world', '!']
Remove stop words: filter common words (the, is, at) that don't carry much meaning
Apply stemming/lemmatization: reduce words to root form (running → run, better → good) for consistent representation

sub_topics.name: Text Representation
sub_topics.short_description: Converting text to numbers: bag of words, TF-IDF, word embeddings (Word2Vec, GloVe).
example_tasks: Create bag of words: represent text as vector of word counts, each dimension represents different word in vocabulary
Calculate TF-IDF: weight words by importance, downweight common words, upweight distinctive words
Understand embeddings: dense vector representations where similar words have similar vectors, capture semantic meaning

sub_topics.name: Sentiment Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying text as positive, negative, or neutral, understanding sentiment in reviews, social media.
example_tasks: Build sentiment classifier: train model on labeled reviews (positive/negative), predict sentiment of new text
Extract features: identify words/phrases that indicate sentiment (great, terrible, love, hate)
Apply to real data: analyze customer reviews, social media posts, survey responses to understand opinions

sub_topics.name: Language Models
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding models that predict next word, generate text, power chatbots and translation systems.
example_tasks: Explain language models: learn probability distribution over sequences of words, predict likely next word given context
Understand applications: text generation, autocomplete, machine translation, chatbots, question answering
Explore modern models: GPT (generative pre-trained transformer), BERT (bidirectional encoder), understand scale and capabilities

sub_topics.name: AI Ethics and Societal Impact
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ethical challenges in AI, bias and fairness, transparency, accountability, impact on employment and society.

sub_topics.name: Bias and Fairness in AI
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how bias enters AI systems, detecting and mitigating bias, ensuring fair treatment across groups.
example_tasks: Identify bias sources: biased training data, biased labels, biased features, societal biases reflected in data
Detect bias: test model performance across demographic groups, identify disparate impact or treatment
Mitigate bias: collect diverse training data, use fairness constraints, audit models regularly, diverse development teams

sub_topics.name: Transparency and Explainability
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding black box problem, importance of explainable AI, techniques for interpreting model decisions.
example_tasks: Explain black box problem: complex models (deep neural networks) make accurate predictions but humans can't understand why
Understand explainability importance: critical for high-stakes decisions (medical, legal, financial), building trust, debugging
Explore XAI techniques: feature importance, attention visualization, LIME, SHAP for understanding model decisions

sub_topics.name: Accountability and Governance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding who is responsible for AI decisions, need for human oversight, regulation and governance.
example_tasks: Define accountability: clearly assign responsibility for AI system decisions and outcomes to specific people/organizations
Implement human oversight: keep humans in the loop for critical decisions, AI assists but doesn't replace human judgment
Understand governance: need for regulations, standards, auditing of AI systems, especially in high-risk applications

sub_topics.name: Societal Impact of AI
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding AI's effect on employment, privacy, surveillance, inequality, and broader social implications.
example_tasks: Consider employment impact: AI automates jobs (manufacturing, customer service), creates new jobs (AI development), need for retraining
Understand privacy concerns: AI enables mass surveillance, facial recognition, behavioral tracking, need for privacy protections
Address inequality: AI could exacerbate inequality (access to technology, benefits flow to tech companies) or reduce it (democratize access to services)

sub_topics.name: Responsible AI Development
sub_topics.short_description: Principles for developing AI ethically, inclusive design, testing for harm, considering stakeholders, AI safety.

sub_topics.name: Ethical AI Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding principles: beneficence, non-maleficence, autonomy, justice, explicability.
example_tasks: Apply beneficence: AI should benefit people, improve wellbeing, solve important problems
Apply non-maleficence: AI should not harm people, consider unintended consequences, prevent misuse
Ensure autonomy: AI should respect human decision-making, provide meaningful control, obtain informed consent

sub_topics.name: Inclusive AI Design
sub_topics.short_description: Designing AI that works for diverse populations, considering accessibility, cultural context, varied use cases.
example_tasks: Design for diversity: ensure AI works for different ages, abilities, cultures, languages, not just dominant groups
Test with diverse users: include underrepresented groups in testing, gather feedback, identify issues before deployment
Consider accessibility: ensure AI interfaces accessible to people with disabilities (screen readers, voice control)

sub_topics.name: Testing for Potential Harm
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying ways AI could be harmful or misused, red-teaming, stress testing, failure mode analysis.
example_tasks: Conduct risk assessment: identify potential harms (bias, privacy violations, security risks, misuse scenarios)
Implement red-teaming: adversarial testing to find vulnerabilities, edge cases, failure modes before deployment
Plan mitigation: design safeguards, monitoring, ability to intervene or shut down if AI causes harm

sub_topics.name: Stakeholder Engagement
sub_topics.short_description: Involving affected communities, experts, policymakers in AI development, participatory design.
example_tasks: Identify stakeholders: who will use AI, who will be affected, who has relevant expertise, who should have voice in development
Gather input: consult with affected communities, domain experts, ethicists, incorporate diverse perspectives
Practice participatory design: involve stakeholders in design process, not just as subjects but as partners

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Programming Concepts
grade_11_12.short_description: Advanced topics including recursion mastery, dynamic programming, regular expressions, concurrency basics, and code optimization techniques.

sub_topics.name: Recursion Mastery
sub_topics.short_description: Advanced recursive problems, multiple recursive calls, tree recursion, optimizing recursive solutions.

sub_topics.name: Tree Recursion
sub_topics.short_description: Functions with multiple recursive calls creating tree-like call structure, Fibonacci, combinatorics.
example_tasks: Implement Fibonacci recursively: fib(n) = fib(n-1) + fib(n-2), visualize recursion tree showing overlapping subproblems
Generate combinations: use tree recursion to generate all ways to choose k items from n items
Count paths in grid: calculate number of paths from top-left to bottom-right moving only right and down

sub_topics.name: Tail Recursion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tail-recursive functions where recursive call is last operation, optimization potential.
example_tasks: Convert to tail recursion: refactor factorial from simple recursion to tail-recursive with accumulator parameter
Understand tail call optimization: some languages optimize tail recursion to constant stack space
Compare performance: measure stack usage and speed of tail-recursive vs regular recursive implementations

sub_topics.name: Optimizing Recursive Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Using memoization to cache results, converting recursion to iteration, understanding recursion tradeoffs.
example_tasks: Add memoization: cache Fibonacci results in dictionary to avoid recomputing: if n in cache: return cache[n]
Convert to iteration: rewrite recursive solution using loops and stack/queue data structure
Analyze tradeoffs: recursion elegant but uses stack space, iteration more verbose but better performance for some problems

sub_topics.name: Dynamic Programming
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding overlapping subproblems, optimal substructure, memoization vs tabulation, solving DP problems.

sub_topics.name: Dynamic Programming Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding when DP applies: overlapping subproblems and optimal substructure properties.
example_tasks: Identify overlapping subproblems: problems where same subproblems solved multiple times (Fibonacci calls fib(n-2) twice via different paths)
Identify optimal substructure: optimal solution contains optimal solutions to subproblems
Recognize DP candidates: optimization problems, counting problems, many divide-and-conquer problems with overlaps

sub_topics.name: Top-Down (Memoization)
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing DP using recursion with caching, solving problems naturally in recursive form.
example_tasks: Implement memoized solution: add cache dictionary, check cache before computing, store result after computing
Solve coin change: find minimum coins to make amount using memoization, cache min_coins[amount]
Implement longest common subsequence: recursively with memoization caching LCS[i][j] for string positions i, j

sub_topics.name: Bottom-Up (Tabulation)
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing DP using iteration and table, building solutions from base cases up to final answer.
example_tasks: Build table iteratively: create array/table, fill base cases, iterate filling table using previously computed values
Solve knapsack problem: build table of max values for each capacity and item subset
Implement edit distance: build table showing minimum operations to transform one string into another

sub_topics.name: Classic DP Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Solving well-known DP problems: knapsack, longest increasing subsequence, matrix chain multiplication.
example_tasks: Solve 0/1 knapsack: maximize value without exceeding capacity, choose whether to include each item
Find longest increasing subsequence: DP[i] = length of LIS ending at position i
Optimize matrix multiplication: find optimal parenthesization to minimize scalar multiplications

sub_topics.name: Regular Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding regex syntax, pattern matching, using regex for text processing, validation, and extraction.

sub_topics.name: Regular Expression Syntax
sub_topics.short_description: Learning regex metacharacters, character classes, quantifiers, anchors, groups.
example_tasks: Understand metacharacters: . (any char), * (zero or more), + (one or more), ? (zero or one), ^ (start), $ (end)
Use character classes: [a-z] (lowercase), [0-9] (digits), \d (digit), \w (word char), \s (whitespace)
Create groups: (pattern) to capture, | for alternatives: (cat|dog) matches cat or dog

sub_topics.name: Pattern Matching
sub_topics.short_description: Using regex to find, match, and search for patterns in text.
example_tasks: Find email addresses: import re; re.findall(r'\w+@\w+\.\w+', text) to extract all emails
Validate formats: use re.match(r'^\d{3}-\d{3}-\d{4}$', phone) to check if string matches phone number format
Search in text: re.search(r'pattern', text) to find first occurrence, re.findall() to find all occurrences

sub_topics.name: Text Extraction and Substitution
sub_topics.short_description: Extracting data from text, replacing patterns, cleaning and transforming text with regex.
example_tasks: Extract data: use capturing groups re.findall(r'(\w+)@(\w+)\.(\w+)', text) to extract username, domain, tld separately
Replace patterns: re.sub(r'\s+', ' ', text) to replace multiple spaces with single space
Clean data: remove HTML tags re.sub(r'<.*?>', '', html), extract numbers re.findall(r'\d+\.\d+', text)

sub_topics.name: Regex Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Using regex for validation, parsing log files, data extraction, text processing tasks.
example_tasks: Validate user input: check password strength (length, uppercase, numbers, symbols), validate email format
Parse log files: extract timestamps, error codes, IP addresses from server logs using regex patterns
Process data: extract specific fields from CSV, clean text data, standardize formats across dataset

sub_topics.name: Concurrency Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding processes vs threads, parallel vs concurrent execution, basic multithreading, race conditions.

sub_topics.name: Processes vs Threads
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding difference between processes and threads, when to use each, resource sharing.
example_tasks: Compare processes: separate memory space, heavy to create, true parallelism vs threads: shared memory, lightweight, concurrency
Understand use cases: processes for CPU-intensive tasks, threads for I/O-bound tasks, processes for isolation
Create threads in Python: import threading; thread = threading.Thread(target=function); thread.start()

sub_topics.name: Parallel vs Concurrent
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding parallel execution (multiple tasks simultaneously) vs concurrent (interleaved execution).
example_tasks: Explain parallel: multiple tasks execute at exact same time on multiple cores/processors
Explain concurrent: multiple tasks in progress, CPU switches between them, gives illusion of simultaneity
Identify scenarios: web server handles multiple requests concurrently, video encoding uses parallel processing

sub_topics.name: Basic Multithreading
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and managing threads, joining threads, passing data to threads.
example_tasks: Create multiple threads: spawn threads for different tasks, each executing function concurrently
Join threads: main thread waits for worker threads to complete before continuing: thread.join()
Pass data to threads: use function arguments, be careful about shared data access

sub_topics.name: Race Conditions and Synchronization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding race conditions when threads access shared data, using locks for synchronization.
example_tasks: Identify race condition: two threads incrementing shared counter simultaneously may lose updates
Use locks: import threading; lock = threading.Lock(); with lock: modify shared data safely
Understand deadlock: circular wait for locks can freeze program, design to avoid: consistent lock ordering

sub_topics.name: Code Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding performance optimization, profiling code, algorithm complexity review, choosing efficient data structures.

sub_topics.name: Profiling Code
sub_topics.short_description: Using profiling tools to identify performance bottlenecks, measuring execution time, memory usage.
example_tasks: Profile with cProfile: import cProfile; cProfile.run('function()') to see which functions take most time
Measure execution time: import time; start = time.time(); execute_code(); elapsed = time.time() - start
Identify bottlenecks: focus optimization on code that takes most time (80/20 rule), don't optimize prematurely

sub_topics.name: Algorithm Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing better algorithms, reducing time complexity, using appropriate data structures.
example_tasks: Replace O(n²) with O(n log n): use merge sort instead of bubble sort for large datasets
Use hash tables: replace O(n) list search with O(1) dictionary lookup for frequent lookups
Apply caching: memoize expensive function calls that are called repeatedly with same arguments

sub_topics.name: Space Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Reducing memory usage, using generators instead of lists, in-place algorithms.
example_tasks: Use generators: yield instead of building entire list in memory, process large files line by line
In-place algorithms: sort list in-place rather than creating new sorted list to save memory
Free unused memory: delete large objects when done: del large_object, consider garbage collection

sub_topics.name: When to Optimize
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding premature optimization dangers, measuring before optimizing, readability vs performance tradeoffs.
example_tasks: Profile first: measure actual performance before optimizing, identify real bottlenecks not assumed ones
Maintain readability: don't sacrifice code clarity for minor performance gains, optimize critical paths only
Understand tradeoffs: sometimes slower but clearer code is better, optimize when performance actually matters

grade_11_12.name: Emerging Technologies & Innovation
grade_11_12.short_description: Exploring cutting-edge technologies: IoT, blockchain, AR/VR, quantum computing awareness, staying current with technology trends.

sub_topics.name: Internet of Things (IoT)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding IoT devices, sensors, connectivity, smart homes, industrial IoT, security challenges.

sub_topics.name: IoT Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what IoT is, components (sensors, connectivity, data processing), IoT architecture.
example_tasks: Explain IoT: network of physical devices with sensors, connectivity, exchanging data, enabling smart applications
Identify components: sensors collect data, connectivity sends to cloud, processing analyzes data, actuators take actions
Understand architecture: edge devices → gateways → cloud platforms → applications, processing at different levels

sub_topics.name: IoT Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring smart homes, wearables, smart cities, industrial IoT, healthcare applications.
example_tasks: Smart home examples: thermostats (Nest), lights (Philips Hue), security cameras, voice assistants controlling devices
Industrial IoT: predictive maintenance (sensors detect equipment failure), supply chain tracking, factory automation
Wearables and health: fitness trackers, smartwatches, medical monitors sending data to healthcare providers

sub_topics.name: IoT Communication Protocols
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding MQTT, CoAP, Bluetooth, Zigbee, and other protocols for device communication.
example_tasks: Compare protocols: MQTT (lightweight messaging), HTTP (web standard), CoAP (constrained devices), Bluetooth/WiFi (local)
Understand MQTT: publish-subscribe model, broker coordinates messages, efficient for resource-constrained devices
Choose protocol: MQTT for cloud communication, Bluetooth for local device-to-device, WiFi for higher bandwidth

sub_topics.name: IoT Security Challenges
