sub_topics.short_description: Understanding security vulnerabilities in IoT devices, importance of updates, privacy concerns.
example_tasks: Identify vulnerabilities: weak default passwords, unencrypted communication, no security updates, physical access
Understand risks: botnet attacks (Mirai), privacy invasion (cameras, microphones), ransomware on connected devices
Apply security practices: change default passwords, encrypt communication, segment IoT network, regular updates

sub_topics.name: Blockchain Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding blockchain technology, distributed ledger, cryptocurrencies, smart contracts, blockchain applications.

sub_topics.name: Blockchain Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how blockchain works: blocks, chains, hashing, distributed consensus, immutability.
example_tasks: Explain blockchain structure: blocks contain transactions, each block references previous block via hash, forming chain
Understand immutability: changing past block breaks chain (hash mismatch), would require recomputing all subsequent blocks
Describe distributed consensus: network agrees on transaction validity without central authority, prevents double-spending

sub_topics.name: Cryptocurrencies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Bitcoin, Ethereum, how cryptocurrencies work, mining, wallets, blockchain as foundation.
example_tasks: Explain cryptocurrency: digital currency using cryptography for security, blockchain for decentralized record-keeping
Understand mining: computers solve cryptographic puzzles to validate transactions and create new blocks, receive rewards
Describe wallets: software storing private keys, enabling sending/receiving cryptocurrency, custodial vs non-custodial

sub_topics.name: Smart Contracts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding self-executing contracts with code, use cases, platforms like Ethereum.
example_tasks: Explain smart contracts: code that automatically executes when conditions met, runs on blockchain, no intermediary needed
Identify use cases: automated payments, supply chain tracking, decentralized applications (DApps), token creation
Understand Ethereum: blockchain platform designed for smart contracts, uses Solidity programming language

sub_topics.name: Blockchain Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring blockchain beyond cryptocurrency: supply chain, voting, identity, healthcare records.
example_tasks: Supply chain tracking: record product journey from manufacture to consumer, verify authenticity, prevent counterfeiting
Digital identity: self-sovereign identity, control personal data, verify credentials without central authority
Understand limitations: scalability challenges, energy consumption, regulatory uncertainty, not solution for all problems

sub_topics.name: Augmented and Virtual Reality
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding AR vs VR, hardware requirements, applications, development basics, future potential.

sub_topics.name: AR vs VR
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding augmented reality (overlay on real world) vs virtual reality (immersive virtual environment).
example_tasks: Compare AR: adds digital elements to real world view (Pokémon Go, Snapchat filters) vs VR: replaces real world with virtual (Oculus, VR games)
Understand hardware: AR uses phones/tablets/AR glasses, VR requires headsets (Oculus, HTC Vive, PlayStation VR)
Identify MR (Mixed Reality): blends physical and digital worlds, digital objects interact with real environment (HoloLens)

sub_topics.name: AR Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring AR uses: gaming, education, retail, navigation, maintenance and repair.
example_tasks: Gaming and entertainment: Pokémon Go, AR board games, social media filters
Practical applications: furniture visualization (IKEA Place), navigation overlays, medical training, remote assistance
Education: interactive 3D models, virtual field trips, anatomy visualization

sub_topics.name: VR Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring VR uses: gaming, training simulations, therapy, virtual meetings, design visualization.
example_tasks: Entertainment: immersive games, virtual concerts, 360° videos, social VR spaces
Training: flight simulators, medical procedure practice, dangerous scenario training without risk
Therapy: exposure therapy for phobias, PTSD treatment, pain management

sub_topics.name: AR/VR Development Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to developing AR/VR applications using Unity, ARKit, ARCore.
example_tasks: Understand development tools: Unity game engine with AR/VR plugins, Unreal Engine for high-end experiences
AR frameworks: ARKit (iOS), ARCore (Android) for building AR mobile apps, detecting surfaces, tracking motion
Identify challenges: motion sickness in VR, tracking accuracy in AR, performance optimization for real-time 3D

sub_topics.name: Quantum Computing Awareness
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding quantum computing basics, qubits, superposition, potential applications, current state and future.

sub_topics.name: Quantum Computing Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how quantum computers differ from classical, qubits, superposition, entanglement concepts.
example_tasks: Explain qubits: quantum bits can be 0, 1, or both simultaneously (superposition), unlike classical bits (0 or 1)
Understand superposition: qubit exists in multiple states until measured, enables parallel computation
Describe entanglement: qubits correlate in ways impossible classically, state of one immediately affects another

sub_topics.name: Quantum Computing Potential
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding problems quantum computers could solve: cryptography, optimization, drug discovery, material science.
example_tasks: Cryptography impact: quantum computers could break current encryption (RSA), need for quantum-resistant cryptography
Optimization problems: finding best solution from vast possibilities (logistics, financial modeling, traffic optimization)
Scientific applications: simulate molecular interactions for drug discovery, material design, understanding quantum systems

sub_topics.name: Current State and Limitations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding quantum computers are early stage, require extreme conditions, limited practical applications currently.
example_tasks: Understand limitations: require near absolute zero temperatures, error-prone (decoherence), limited qubits currently available
Identify current state: NISQ era (Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum), quantum supremacy claims, research stage not practical deployment
Realistic timeline: practical quantum computers likely decades away, classical computers still vastly superior for most tasks

sub_topics.name: Staying Current with Technology
sub_topics.short_description: Strategies for continuous learning, following tech news, experimenting with new technologies, building learning mindset.

sub_topics.name: Learning Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Using online courses, documentation, tutorials, developer communities, conferences to learn new technologies.
example_tasks: Identify learning platforms: Coursera, edX, Udemy for structured courses, YouTube for tutorials, official documentation
Join communities: Stack Overflow, Reddit, Discord servers, local meetups for learning and networking
Follow tech news: Hacker News, TechCrunch, technology blogs, podcasts to stay informed about trends

sub_topics.name: Hands-On Learning
sub_topics.short_description: Learning by building projects, experimenting with new frameworks, contributing to open source.
example_tasks: Build projects: best way to learn is doing, create small projects with new technology, gradually increase complexity
Experiment freely: try new languages, frameworks, tools on side projects without pressure of production use
Contribute to open source: read others' code, fix bugs, add features, learn from code reviews

sub_topics.name: Developing Learning Mindset
sub_topics.short_description: Embracing continuous learning, dealing with rapid change, focus on fundamentals that transfer across technologies.
example_tasks: Embrace change: technology constantly evolves, specific tools change but fundamental concepts remain
Learn fundamentals: strong foundation in CS concepts, algorithms, architecture applies across languages and frameworks
Be comfortable with discomfort: learning new things is challenging, persist through confusion, growth happens outside comfort zone

grade_11_12.name: Capstone Project & Portfolio Development
grade_11_12.short_description: Planning and executing comprehensive capstone project, professional portfolio development, technical presentations, career preparation in technology field.

sub_topics.name: Capstone Project Planning
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting meaningful project, defining scope, creating project proposal, timeline planning, identifying requirements.

sub_topics.name: Selecting Capstone Project
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing project that demonstrates skills, interests, and career goals, balancing ambition and feasibility.
example_tasks: Brainstorm ideas: identify problems worth solving, projects that excite you, areas where you want to demonstrate expertise
Evaluate feasibility: assess project scope, required skills, available time, access to resources and data
Align with goals: choose project relevant to career interests, uses technologies you want to master, impressive to employers

sub_topics.name: Writing Project Proposal
sub_topics.short_description: Creating detailed proposal: problem statement, objectives, approach, deliverables, timeline.
example_tasks: Define problem: clearly articulate problem being solved, why it matters, who benefits from solution
Specify objectives: concrete, measurable goals for project, features to implement, success criteria
Outline approach: technologies to use, architecture design, development methodology, testing strategy

sub_topics.name: Requirements Specification
sub_topics.short_description: Documenting functional and non-functional requirements, user stories, acceptance criteria.
example_tasks: List functional requirements: specific features and capabilities system must have, user actions it must support
Define non-functional requirements: performance (response time), security, usability, scalability, compatibility
Create user stories: describe features from user perspective with acceptance criteria for each story

sub_topics.name: Creating Project Timeline
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking project into phases, setting milestones, creating realistic schedule with buffer for challenges.
example_tasks: Define milestones: major checkpoints (design complete, core features working, testing done, deployment ready)
Create schedule: assign time estimates to tasks, identify dependencies, account for other commitments
Plan iterations: agile approach with 1-2 week sprints, deliverable increment each sprint, flexibility to adjust

sub_topics.name: Executing Capstone Project
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing project using professional practices, tracking progress, adapting to challenges, maintaining documentation.

sub_topics.name: Iterative Development
sub_topics.short_description: Building project incrementally, regular testing and feedback, adapting based on results.
example_tasks: Implement in iterations: complete features in priority order, working software each iteration, demonstrate progress regularly
Test continuously: write tests for features, run tests frequently, fix bugs immediately rather than accumulating
Gather feedback: demo to potential users, instructors, peers regularly, incorporate feedback into next iteration

sub_topics.name: Technical Documentation
sub_topics.short_description: Maintaining documentation: code comments, API docs, architecture diagrams, setup instructions.
example_tasks: Document architecture: create diagrams showing system components, data flow, technology stack, design decisions
Write developer documentation: setup instructions, how to run/test, code organization, how to contribute
Document APIs: if creating API, document endpoints, parameters, responses, authentication, provide examples

sub_topics.name: Professional Version Control
sub_topics.short_description: Using Git professionally: meaningful commits, branches for features, pull requests for review.
example_tasks: Maintain clean history: atomic commits with clear messages, branch for each feature, merge with pull requests
Use GitHub professionally: organize with issues, project board, README, contribution guidelines, proper branching strategy
Practice collaboration workflow: even solo project, use PRs for self-review, maintain professional repository appearance

sub_topics.name: Overcoming Project Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Dealing with technical obstacles, scope creep, time management, knowing when to seek help.
example_tasks: Debug systematically: when stuck, isolate problem, search for solutions, try alternatives, ask for help if needed
Manage scope: resist adding features mid-project, prioritize core functionality, track scope creep
Stay organized: maintain task list, track time spent, adjust plan when falling behind, communicate about delays

sub_topics.name: Professional Portfolio Development
sub_topics.short_description: Creating comprehensive portfolio showcasing skills and projects, online presence, GitHub profile, resume.

sub_topics.name: Portfolio Website
sub_topics.short_description: Building professional portfolio website showcasing projects, skills, about section, contact information.
example_tasks: Design portfolio site: clean, professional design, easy navigation, responsive for mobile, fast loading
Showcase projects: for each project include description, technologies used, screenshots/demos, link to code and live site
About section: introduce yourself, background, skills, interests, career goals, what makes you unique

sub_topics.name: GitHub Profile Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing GitHub profile: pinned repositories, profile README, consistent quality across projects.
example_tasks: Create profile README: introduce yourself, highlight skills, showcase contributions, pin best projects
Organize repositories: archive old experiments, pin 4-6 best projects showing diverse skills
Ensure quality: all pinned projects have good READMEs, clear code, recent commits show active development

sub_topics.name: Technical Resume
sub_topics.short_description: Creating resume highlighting technical skills, projects, education, tailored for tech positions.
example_tasks: Structure resume: contact info, summary, skills, projects, education, keep to 1-2 pages
Highlight projects: describe what you built, technologies used, impact/results, quantify when possible
Technical skills section: list languages, frameworks, tools, databases organized by category or proficiency

sub_topics.name: Professional Online Presence
sub_topics.short_description: Managing LinkedIn profile, contributing to communities, blogging about technical topics.
example_tasks: LinkedIn profile: professional photo, headline, detailed experience including projects, skills endorsements, recommendations
Technical blog: write about projects, what you learned, solutions to problems, teaching reinforces learning
Community participation: answer questions on Stack Overflow, contribute to discussions, help others

sub_topics.name: Technical Presentation Skills
sub_topics.short_description: Preparing and delivering presentations about technical work, explaining complex topics clearly, demo skills.

sub_topics.name: Preparing Technical Presentation
sub_topics.short_description: Structuring presentation: introduction, problem, solution, demo, results, lessons learned.
example_tasks: Structure presentation: hook audience, state problem, explain solution approach, demonstrate working project, discuss results and learning
Create slides: minimal text, visuals and diagrams, code snippets only when necessary, demo not slides when possible
Prepare demo: practice demo multiple times, have backup plan if live demo fails, record video demo as fallback

sub_topics.name: Explaining Technical Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Making complex topics accessible, using analogies, knowing your audience, avoiding jargon.
example_tasks: Know your audience: adjust technical depth based on audience expertise, explain terms that may be unfamiliar
Use analogies: explain complex concepts with familiar comparisons, make abstract concrete
Show don't just tell: use diagrams, visualizations, code examples, demonstrations to illustrate concepts

sub_topics.name: Presentation Delivery
sub_topics.short_description: Speaking clearly, maintaining eye contact, handling questions, managing time, dealing with nerves.
example_tasks: Practice delivery: rehearse multiple times, time yourself, practice with feedback from others
Manage nerves: deep breathing, remember audience wants you to succeed, focus on message not perfection
Handle questions: listen carefully, repeat question for audience, okay to say 'I don't know' and offer to follow up

sub_topics.name: Effective Demonstrations
sub_topics.short_description: Preparing live demos, what to show, handling technical difficulties, backup plans.
example_tasks: Prepare demo environment: test beforehand, clear unnecessary data, have accounts/data ready, check connectivity
Show key features: demonstrate most important functionality, user's perspective, highlight what makes project unique
Have contingencies: video recording of demo, screenshots, explain what would happen if something fails

sub_topics.name: Career Preparation
sub_topics.short_description: Preparing for technology careers: internship search, interview preparation, networking, continuous learning plan.

sub_topics.name: Finding Internships and Opportunities
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying opportunities, crafting applications, leveraging networks, following up professionally.
example_tasks: Research companies: identify companies aligned with interests, research their tech stack, culture, products
Craft applications: tailor resume and cover letter to each position, highlight relevant projects and skills
Use networks: inform teachers, family, friends about job search, attend career fairs, reach out to alumni

sub_topics.name: Technical Interview Preparation
sub_topics.short_description: Practicing coding problems, behavioral questions, system design basics, understanding interview process.
example_tasks: Practice coding problems: use LeetCode, HackerRank, solve common patterns (arrays, strings, trees, dynamic programming)
Prepare behavioral answers: STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) for common questions about challenges, teamwork, leadership
Understand interview types: phone screen, coding challenge, technical interview, behavioral interview, what to expect in each

sub_topics.name: Professional Networking
sub_topics.short_description: Building professional relationships, attending events, informational interviews, maintaining connections.
example_tasks: Attend meetups: join local tech meetups, hackathons, conferences, meet people in industry
Conduct informational interviews: reach out to professionals for advice, learn about their career path, build relationships
Follow up: connect on LinkedIn after meeting, send thank you notes, maintain relationships over time

sub_topics.name: Continuous Learning Plan
sub_topics.short_description: Creating plan for ongoing skill development, identifying areas to improve, resources for learning.
example_tasks: Assess current skills: identify strengths and gaps, areas of interest, skills in demand for target positions
Set learning goals: specific skills to develop (new language, framework, domain knowledge), timeline for learning
Plan learning activities: online courses, books, projects, contribution to open source, teaching others
